publication.title: CNSistent integration and feature extraction from somatic copy number profiles
publication.authors: Adam Streck, Roland F Schwarz

dataset.provenance:
TCGA data obtained from ASCATv3 at: https://github.com/VanLoo-lab/ascat/tree/master/ReleasedData
Publication: https://www.pnas.org/doi/full/10.1073/pnas.1009843107

PCAWG data obtained from: https://dcc.icgc.org/releases/PCAWG/consensus_cnv 
Publication: https://www.nature.com/articles/s41587-019-0055-9

TRACERx data obtained from: https://zenodo.org/records/7649257
Publication: https://www.nature.com/articles/s41586-023-05729-x

COSMIC cancer set obtained from: https://cancer.sanger.ac.uk/census
Publication: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6450507

Human genome gene set obtained using PyENSEMBL (2023). 
Publication: https://academic.oup.com/nar/article/51/D1/D933/6786199

Cytoband, Gap data obtained from: https://genome.ucsc.edu 
Publication: https://www.nature.com/articles/35057062
dataset.splits:
The full dataset has 5172 samples with the following class labels: lung adenocarcinoma (LUAD, n=1314), breast invasive carcinoma (BRCA, n=1157), lung squamous cell carcinoma (LUSC, n=996), ovarian cancer (OV, n=618), prostate adenocarcinoma (PRAD, n=563), and kidney renal cell carcinoma (KIRC, n=513).

Accuracy is validated using 5-fold cross-validation, i.e. the dataset is separated into 5 equally sized subsets with a 4:1 train-test ratio. The resulting accuracies are the mean of the 5 training runs. As the number of patients per cancer type varies, the classes are imbalanced. To avoid a possible bias due to an overrepresentation of one class, stratified split is used, meaning that the ratio of the individual cancer classes is preserved across the 5 subsets.

The distribution of the source dataset is plotted, the distributions of train/test are no.t
dataset.redundancy: Some samples are obtained through multi-region sampling. While the samples from different regions show different profiles, there is a risk of being able to  guess the class based on the similarity to the original profile. This is prevented by sample grouping where each group (in this case patient) can only be part of one subset. The splitting is done using the StratifiedGroupKFold object from scikit-learn v1.4.1.
dataset.availability: Dataset available on Zenodo under CC0: https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.14547455

model.interpretability: The model is interpretable. The manuscript contains an example of using Captum Integrated Gradients package to determine genes of highest importance.
model.duration: Each training took between 13 and 26 seconds on a desktop PC using RTX 4090 GPU.
model.availability: The model, training, and analysis code, together with the training logs are available under MIT license on Zenodo: https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.14546761

optimization.algorithm: For training we used the PyTorch 2 library, torch package v2.2.1, accelerated using CUDA v12.1. Optimization was conducted using the Adam optimizer with a learning rate of 0.001 and weight decay of 0.01. The error is evaluated using cross-entropy loss. The training was limited to 1000 epochs. The training process was accelerated by an early stopping strategy where the minimum loss is recorded and if past 10 epochs lead to a training loss higher than the existing global minimum, the training stops.
optimization.meta: No, this model does not use data from other ML algorithms.
optimization.config: The model and training code is available under MIT license on Zenodo: https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.14546761
optimization.encoding: The copy number values of each sample are normalized, i.e. features = (dataset - mean(dataset))/stddev(dataset)
optimization.features: Two dimensional input is used. The second dimension is 2. For the first dimension, input size varies between 22 and 19430.
optimization.fitting: Fifteen different input feature sizes are tested. The f/p ratio varies between ~0.01 and 7.5. The effect size of f on difference between test and train accuracy is shown in the text. The f/p ratio of ~1 is shown to be best performing.
optimization.parameters: Fifteen different input feature sizes are tested, with parameters count varying between 7198 and 1870366.
optimization.regularization: The model contains a batch normalization and dropout (p=0.8) regularizers. The training process was accelerated by an early stopping strategy where the minimum loss is recorded and if past 10 epochs lead to a training loss higher than the existing global minimum, the training stops.

evaluation.method:
We have conducted two experiments:
1. Used 5-fold cross-validation. 
2. Used three independent datasets (different studies), always testing and training on separate datasets.
evaluation.measure: We report the mean train/test accuracy under the above specified evaluation methods. Based on the tasks the model either matches or outperforms previous results.
evaluation.comparison:
One of the goals of the publication was to create a benchmark dataset. 

Comparison to Random Forest is performed, visual separation is provided using UMAP.
evaluation.confidence: The mean value from 5-fold cross-validation is reported. Confidence interval is not reported. The optimization is conducted using 15 different input sizes derived from data, demonstrating monotonous relationship between input size and training accuracy.
evaluation.availability: The model, training, and analysis code, together with the training logs, comparison to baselines, statistical code and confusion matrices are available under MIT license on Zenodo: https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.14546761

publication.title: NanoMnT: An STR Analysis Tool for Oxford Nanopore Sequencing Data Driven by a Comprehensive Analysis of Error Profile in STR regions
publication.authors: Gyumin Park, Hyunsu An, Han Luo, and Jihwan Park

dataset.provenance: Whole-genome sequencing dataset of the CHM13 cell line (generated by the T2T Consortium) was processed using in-house scripts to obtain the STR flanking sequence and its associated sequencing accuracy. The data is numerical and consists of 39,594 (Ax10 STR), 7,660 (ATx10 STR), and 5,916 (ACx10 STR) data points. This data has not been used in any other paper.
dataset.splits: Training-validation ratio of 9:1 was used for each group of STR (e.g., 6894:766 for ATx10 STR). Separate validation set was not used. The distribution of data types in the training and test sets are very similar and they have been randomly selected using Python Pandas Package.
dataset.redundancy: The training and test sets are independent: data points to be used as the training set were selected first, and the remaining data points were employed as the test set.
dataset.availability:
The data used to train and test our model is available on GigaDB, which is the repository used to host data and tools associated with articles in GigaScience Press. 
This section will be updated after publication (e.g., link to GigaDB repository).

model.interpretability: The model is black box.
model.duration: Prediction is almost instant, in both a high-performing computing cluster and a M2 MacBook Air.
model.availability: The source code is available under the GigaDB repository. The link will be provided after publication.

optimization.algorithm: A sequential neural network featuring a 1D convolutional layer with 48 filters and a kernel size of 2, followed by a flattening layer and two dense layers with 120 and 40 nodes was implemented using TensorFlow, (Martín Abadi et al., 2015). The algorithm is not new, but was chosen as our goal was to simply check if there is any association between STR flanking sequences and their associated sequencing accuracy.
optimization.meta: No meta-predictors are present in our model.
optimization.config: No such parameters were used.
optimization.encoding: Flanking sequences (string consisting of A,T,G,C) were one-hot encoded to be used as input.
optimization.features: Flanking sequences that are 12 letters long were one-hot-encoded, creating a 4x12 matrix per sequence. Feature selection was not performed.
optimization.fitting: p is indeed larger than the number of training points (74,553 vs. 39,594), but overfitting was mitigated through early stopping.
optimization.parameters: 74,553 parameters are used in the model. Different number of parameters (e.g., by adjusting kernel sizes, filters) were experimented, and the model that gave the best results were chosen. We note that changing the parameters did not drastically improve prediction results.
optimization.regularization: Early stopping was used (tensorflow.keras.callbacks.EarlyStopping) to prevent overfitting.

evaluation.method: We evaluated the results through a separate analysis using an orthogonal method (Uniform Manifold Approximation and Projection analyses), which is available in our paper. We tested the findings made through the ML model in an independent dataset, by measuring the detection of a biological process. Furthermore, to ensure that the ML model was learning from the data points and not overfitted, we tested the ML model using different DNA sequences as inputs as a sanity check.
evaluation.measure: Pearson correlation values were presented.
evaluation.comparison: Unfortunately, comparisons were not performed, as they are not the scope of our study.
evaluation.confidence: P-values of the obtained Pearson correlation indicated statistical significance. No other metrics were used.
evaluation.availability: The source code is available under the GigaDB repository. The link will be provided after publication.

publication.title: SurGen: 1020 H&E-stained Whole Slide Images With Survival and Genetic Markers
publication.authors: Craig Myles, In Hwa Um, Craig Marshall, David Harris-Birtill, David J Harrison

dataset.provenance: Samples were provided via Lothian BioResource and digitised in St Andrews. The dataset includes diverse cancer types and patient demographics, detailed in the associated labels.csv files. Further information can be accessed at https://www.ebi.ac.uk/biostudies/bioimages/studies/S-BIAD1285 and https://github.com/CraigMyles/SurGen-Dataset
dataset.splits: 60:20:20 Train, Val, Test. Stratified over various labels. Full details in paper.
dataset.redundancy: 60:20:20 Train, Val, Test. Cases are not duplicated or leaked across splits.
dataset.availability:
More info on dataset: https://github.com/CraigMyles/SurGen-Dataset
Download data here: https://doi.org/10.6019/S-BIAD1285

model.interpretability: Deep learning model.
model.duration: Utilising a single V100, x1 sample can be evaluated and predicted upon in 0.084 seconds
model.availability: https://github.com/CraigMyles/SurGen-Dataset

optimization.algorithm: Weakly supervised multiple instance learning with rich features extracted from histopathology pre-trained foundation models.
optimization.meta: Model accepts data from any feature format. Models can be loaded on the fly from hugging face or loaded from a model checkpoint.
optimization.config: Exact commands for reproducing the experiments can be found in the reproducibility section of the GitHub repository: https://github.com/CraigMyles/SurGen-Dataset/blob/main/reproducibility/README.md.
optimization.encoding: Foundation models and/or ImageNet pretained ResNet models. Encoding is flexible.
optimization.features: Again this varies depending on the approach. Generally, 768-1024-dim feature vectors. The counts depend on the area of tissue within each whole slide image.  Experiments can be exactly recreated using the reproducibilty documentation within https://github.com/CraigMyles/SurGen-Dataset
optimization.fitting: Pipeline utilises pretrained models ranging from 25M params to 0.3B params. There are 1020 samples.
optimization.parameters: Model parameters varies depending on hyperparameter selection.
optimization.regularization: Models trained to 200 epoch but with checkpointing at highest validation AUROC score.

evaluation.method: Hold-out test set.
evaluation.measure: AUROC
evaluation.comparison: Results were evaluated to similar results using partitions of SurGen dataset for purpose of benchmarking.
evaluation.confidence: We explored the effects of thresholding on sensitivity and specificity to optimise model performance metrics. Confidence intervals can be produced for AUROC, but were not the primary focus of this study.

publication.title: A Novel Dataset for Nuclei and Tissue Segmentation in Melanoma with baseline nuclei segmentation and tissue segmentation benchmarks
publication.authors: Mark Schuiveling, Hong Liu, Daniel Eek,  Gerben E. Breimer,  Karijn P.M. Suijkerbuijk, Willeke A.M. Blokx,  Mitko Veta

dataset.provenance:
The dataset consists of 155 primary and 155 metastatic melanoma manually selected ROIs, scanned at 40× magnification (0.22 µm/px) with a size of 1024 × 1024 pixels. For these ROIs, annotations of both tissue and nuclei are supplied, as well as a context ROI of 5120 × 5120 pixels centered around the ROI. Annotations were created by a medical expert and checked and corrected by a dermatopathologist.  All cases were digitized in a large melanoma referral center, however 76 cases are revisions or consultations originating from other treatment hospitals. Annotations are in the .GeoJSON format, making annotations easily visualizable with the opensource pathology image viewer Qupath. 

The following nuclei categories were used:  tumor, stroma, vascular endothelium, histiocyte, melanophage, lymphocyte, plasma cell, neutrophil, apoptotic and epithelium and the following tissue categories were used: tumor, stroma, epidermis, necrosis, blood vessel, and background. A total of 147 739 nuclei are manually annotated.
dataset.splits:
The PUMA dataset contains 103 primary melanoma ROIs and 103 metastatic melanoma ROIs in the training set, with a total of 97,429 nuclei. 
The test set includes 52 primary melanoma ROIs and 52 metastatic melanoma ROIs, comprising 50,490 nuclei. 

In the manuscript the distribution of metastatic sites, nuclei and tissue annotations is plotted in the data description paragraph.
dataset.redundancy: The sets were split randomly. As each sample is a histological specimen from a different patient the training and test dataset are independent.
dataset.availability: The training dataset is available on zenodo (https://zenodo.org/records/10940194) with a CC-BY 4.0 licence.

model.interpretability: The model outputs segmentation annotations, which are fully interpretable by pathologists.
model.duration: Less than 30 seconds
model.availability: https://github.com/tueimage/PUMA-challenge-baseline-track1, https://github.com/tueimage/PUMA-challenge-baseline-track2

optimization.algorithm:
In this study, two algorithm classes are used. The first class consists of models for nuclei instance segmentation, while the second class includes semantic segmentation models for medical image analysis. The nuclei instance segmentation algorithms offer advantages over classic models due to post-processing techniques like watershed segmentation, which help separate densely packed nuclei. Additionally, these algorithms can be applied to whole slide images instead of tiles. 

For tissue annotation semantic segmentation, two models were used. The first is nnU-Net, which is designed for supervised medical image segmentation. The second is Mask2Former2, a transformer segmentation algorithm which can be used for supervised semantic segmentation. For this experiment the backbone was replaced by a foundation model that is better able at feature extraction from histopathology images.
optimization.config: The original training code of the models used was not adjusted. Weights for the baseline solution of the PUMA challenge are supplied on Zenodo (https://zenodo.org/records/13881999).
optimization.encoding: Annotations are supplied in the .geoJSON format. For training of Hover-Net and Hover-Next the .geoJSON and .TIFF images were recoded to numpy array masks. For tissue segmentation the .geoJSON were encoded to .PNG masks.
optimization.features: No explicit feature selection was performed. The models used the raw input from the images without reducing or selecting specific features. Therefore, the entire dataset, including both tissue and nuclei information, was used for training without separate feature selection steps.
optimization.fitting: In this study, due to the use of different models, it’s hard to directly compare p (parameters) and f (input features) with the number of training points. The models were used to establish a baseline without detailed tuning. Overfitting was countered by 5-fold cross-validation and the use of an independent test set, though specific model-related techniques were not addressed.
optimization.parameters: The models in this research used default configurations for the number of parameters. The goal was to establish a baseline for the dataset, providing a reference point for the PUMA challenge. The community is then invited to improve upon these baseline models in future work. No manual tuning or selection of the number of parameters (p) was performed.
optimization.regularization: To decrease the risk of overfitting we used data-augmentation and 5-fold cross validation to define a training and validation set in the original training set. We took the mean of these models on the independent test set.

evaluation.method: Independent dataset
evaluation.measure:
For the calculation of the F1 score, the center distance between the predicted nuclei and the ground truth nuclei was used. For each ground truth nucleus, predictions within a 15 pixel (3.3 μm) were identified. This radius is smaller than the average size of lymphocytes, which form the smallest nuclei in the dataset. Matching was performed based on the highest predictive score (if available) or the shortest distance. After matching, the ground truth was censored until all ground truth nuclei were either matched or classified as a false negative. Using the identified true positives, false positives, and false negatives, precision (all correct predictions divided by all predictions) and recall (all correct predictions divided by all ground truth nuclei) were calculated. The class F1 score was computed as the harmonic mean of precision and recall, ranging from 0 to 1. Finally to compare models, micro F1  (aggregation of TP, FP, and FN over all classes, followed by F1 score calculation) and Average F1  (the average of class F1 scores) were calculated [40]. Results are shown with a 95% confidence interval which is calculated through bootstrapping the samples. 

Both models and intra- and interobserver agreement were evaluated using the DICE score. The DICE score is a harmonic mean between 0 and 1, in which 1 is a perfect segmentation prediction, and 0 is no correct prediction. This can result in inflated high average DICE scores if a tissue class is only present in a few samples, as the DICE score is 1 in the case of a correct absent prediction. To accommodate this, we calculated not only the average DICE score over all samples but also the micro average DICE. This is the DICE score for all predictions concatenated along one axis, resulting in a prediction mask of 1024 × 96.256 pixels. Results are shown with a 95% confidence interval which is generated through bootstrapping the sample results. 

Metrics are in line with literature (Maier-Hein, L., Reinke, A., Godau, P. et al. Metrics reloaded: recommendations for image analysis validation. Nat Methods 21, 195–212 (2024). https://doi.org/10.1038/s41592-023-02151-z)
evaluation.comparison:
Yes, a comparison with publicly available methods has been performed (NN192, Hover-Net and Hover-NeXt trained on the PanNuke dataset). 
No publicly available method exists able at segmenting skin tissue on H&E stained histopathology images.
evaluation.confidence: The results are bootstrapped for generation of confidence intervals. This is not performed in the final public evaluation code for the PUMA challenge due to reducing computational burden. The difference in performance between the used models is statistically significant.

publication.title: SqueezeCall: Nanopore basecalling using a Squeezeformer network
publication.authors: Zhongxu Zhu

dataset.provenance:
Human raw data and basecall datasets (FAF04090, FAF09968, FAB42828) are available at https://github.com/nanopore-wgs-consortium/NA12878/blob/master/Genome.md; bacterial raw data and lambda phage data are available at https://github.com/marcpaga/nanopore_benchmark/tree/main/download; ONT chunk dataset are available at https://cdn.oxfordnanoportal.com/software/analysis/bonito/example_data_dna_r9.4.1_v0.zip.
This data has been used in previous papers.
dataset.splits:
Human data: train/test: 80,000/5,000 reads
bacterial data: train/test: 40,000/5,000 reads
ont chunk data: train/dev: 1.22 million /20,000 chunks
dataset.redundancy:
Human data/ont chunk data: split into train/test randomly.
bacterial data: The training dataset consists of 50 individual species genomes, consisting of 30 Klebsiella pneumoniae genomes, 10 genomes of other species of Enterobacteriaceae, and 10 genomes from other families of Proteobacteria. The test dataset is composed of nine species, including three Klebsiella pneumoniae, Shigella sonnei, Serratia marcescens, Haemophilus haemolyticus, Acinetobacter pittii, Stenotrophomonas maltophilia, and Staphylococcus aureus. 
Training and test sets are independent.

model.interpretability: It is a black box.
model.duration: 3 days with 4 NVIDIA A100 GPUs on a high-performance computing cluster.
model.availability: https://github.com/ProfessionalFarmer/SqueezeCall/tree/main

optimization.algorithm: An end-to-end Squeezeformer-based model for accurate nanopore basecalling
optimization.meta: This model is not a meta-predictor.
optimization.config: https://github.com/ProfessionalFarmer/SqueezeCall/tree/main
optimization.encoding: Reads were sliced in non-overlapping chunks of 3,600 data points, then fed into the end-to-end model
optimization.features:
Use only raw electrical current.
No feature selection strategy was performed.
optimization.fitting: The model's parameter count is approximately 6 times the number of training data points. Early stopping was adopted to stop training once the model performance was no longer improved on the validation dataset for three consecutive epochs to avoid overfitting.
optimization.parameters: 95M parameters
optimization.regularization: Early stopping was adopted to stop training once the model performance was no longer improved on the validation dataset for three consecutive epochs to avoid overfitting.

evaluation.method: It was evaluated by an independent test dataset.
evaluation.measure: SqueezeCall-L achieved the highest identity rate, at 93.97%, on average.
evaluation.comparison: Compare with Bonito-Transformer, Bonito-LSTM, CATCaller, and SACall
evaluation.confidence: No

publication.title: Quantitative Detection of DNA Methylation from Nanopore Sequencing Data without Raw Signals
publication.authors: Zhixing Feng, Chenxi Zhang, Shuo Jin, Jiale Niu, and Huijuan Feng

dataset.provenance:
The training data are nanopore sequencing data of chromosome 10 obtained from Human pangenome project (HG01109, https://github.com/human-pangenomics/hpgp-data ) and ONT open datasets (https://labs.epi2me.io/gm24385-5mc for R9 data, https://labs.epi2me.io/askenazi-kit14-2022-12 for R10 4kHz data, and https://labs.epi2me.io/giab-2023.05 for R10 5kHz data).

The mode is a regression model, and there are 2,344,753 real value points in the training data. The data were previously published but not used for training this model or a similar model.
dataset.splits: Training data has 2,344,753  data points and testing data has 46,895,182 data points per individual. The distributions of the data types in the training and test sets are identical.
dataset.redundancy: For each model, the training data are the data from chromosome 11 of a individual, and the rest of the data are test sets. They are independent and have no overlaps. There are no such model or published ML datasets previously.
dataset.availability: All these data are published. The ONT open dataset’s MinION R9.4.1 flowcell data were obtained from https://labs.epi2me.io/gm24385-5mc. The PromethION R9.4.1 flowcell data released by Human Pangenome Project were obtained from https://github.com/human-pangenomics/hpgp-data. The ONT open dataset’s PromethION R10.4.1 flowcell 4kHz and 5kHz data were obtained from https://labs.epi2me.io/askenazi-kit14-2022-12 and https://labs.epi2me.io/giab-2023.05 respectively.

model.interpretability: Boosting is a black box model.
model.duration: It takes 12~48 hours each individual depending the machine.
model.availability: Yes, https://gitee.com/zhixingfeng/NanoFreeLunch.jl.

optimization.algorithm: The ML algorithm is Grandient Boosting. The ML algorithm itself is a well established.
optimization.config: Yes, the hyperparameter, optimization schecule are available in the manuscript. The model files are available at the model folder of https://gitee.com/zhixingfeng/NanoFreeLunch.jl
optimization.encoding: There are two classes of features used in the work: 1. base QV, there are used by the ML algorithm as-is without encoding; 2. DNA sequence. Each base is binary encoded, i.e. A=00, C=01, G=10, T=11
optimization.features: The total number of featues is 12411. No feature selection.
optimization.fitting: The number of sample points is larger than number of features. We used XGBoost to train the model and it has internal mechanism to prevent overfitting. The evaluation on indepenet test datasets demonstrate that there is no obviously overfiting or underfitting.
optimization.parameters: The number of parameters in boosting models is fixed.
optimization.regularization: XGBoost has internal mechanism to prevent overfitting and no overfitting is confirmed in testing the model on independent data.

evaluation.method: Independent dataset.
evaluation.measure: PCC (pearson correlation coefficient) are used for performance metrics. This is commonly used metric for evaluating algorithm detect DNA methylation quantitatively.
evaluation.comparison: No similar model has been previously published.
evaluation.confidence: There is no confidence intervals reported, but performance metrics are evaluated by a large number of testing data points. No similar methods previously published.
evaluation.availability: The evaluation is described in the manuscript and code is available at https://gitee.com/zhixingfeng/nfl-demo/tree/main/demo.

publication.title: ViralBindPredict: Empowering Viral Protein-Ligand Binding Sites through Deep Learning and Protein Sequence-Derived Insights
publication.authors: C. Marques-Pereira, T. Almeida, N. Rosário-Ferreira, A. M. B. Amorim, H. S. Pinto, C. Vaz, A. Francisco and I.S. Moreira

dataset.provenance:
The dataset was obtained from the Protein Data Bank (PDB), specifically from viral protein-ligand complexes. 
The dataset contains 5,908,887 residue samples, with 287,001 positive (interacting) and 5,621,886 negative (non-interacting) samples. 
The   dataset   is   newly   curated   and   specifically   designed   for ViralBindPredict.
dataset.splits:
The dataset was split into training and validation sets.
The training set contains 80% of the total samples, while the validation set contains 20%.
The dataset is highly imbalanced, with approximately 1 positive (interacting) residue   for   every   20   negatives   (non-interacting).  This   imbalance  was considered in model training.
dataset.redundancy:
Independently, ensuring that training and validation sets remained separate.
Yes, the splits were designed to prevent overlap of protein chains and ligand interactions. By   ensuring   protein-ligand   complexes   were   separated   across   splits, redundancy was minimized.
The dataset follows the general trend of biological datasets.
dataset.availability:
The full dataset is publicly available at https://www.dropbox.com/scl/fo/nq47acmr2ty62iflu9rwn/AJhe9a9gqoKblgH
kYDMf_Gk?dl=0&e=1&rlkey=dcivaufhohazumpetifq9chkj&st=ac9imrzl

model.interpretability: Blackbox.
model.duration:
The training time depends on the specific model, the machine used, and the availability of computational resources at the time. 
A new prediction will take seconds to minutes on a desktop PC.
model.availability: The code is available on GitHub, allowing users to run it in their preferred environment. GitHub:  https://github.com/MoreiraLAB/VirHostAI/. Users can utilize the repository to generate new predictions using our method.

optimization.algorithm: A Multilayer Perceptron (MLP) model. It is optimized for viral ligand-binding site (LBS) prediction.
optimization.config: Yes. Manuscript and Github: https://github.com/MoreiraLAB/VirHostAI/
optimization.encoding: Features were extracted using Mordred (ligand descriptors), SPOTONE (protein sequence features), and PSSM (evolutionary conservation features). Dimensionality reduction was performed using an autoencoder.
optimization.features:
615 ligand features, plus 60 protein sequence features after dimensionality reduction.
Feature selection was performed, using an autoencoder for dimensionality reduction.
Feature selection was applied considering the entire pipeline to ensure fair evaluation.
optimization.fitting: No, the number of parameters (p) is much smaller than the number of training points. Overfitting and underfitting were assessed by analyzing the line charts of loss evolution for both the training and validation sets.
optimization.parameters:
The parameters tested (enconder_layers, latent_vector, activation, criterion, optimizer, learning_rate, splits, epochs, batch_size) are available in the config files on GitHub: https://github.com/MoreiraLAB/VirHostAI/
The selection of p was based on an understanding of how an autoencoder functions. The specific values were determined through experimentation, balancing model complexity and generalization performance using grid
search optimization of the MLP architecture.
optimization.regularization: Yes, early stopping.

evaluation.method: Using the validation set.
evaluation.measure: Accuracy, AUC-ROC, F1-Score, Precision, and Recall are reported as performance metrics, and the set is representative.
evaluation.comparison: NA. No benchmark datasets for viral protein–ligand interaction.
evaluation.confidence: No confidence intervals. No available benchmarks specialized in viral protein-ligand interactions.
evaluation.availability: Evaluation   results   are   covered   in   the   manuscript.   GitHub repository: https://github.com/MoreiraLAB/VirHostAI/.

publication.title: High-fidelity Wheat Plant Reconstruction using 3D Gaussian Splatting and Neural Radiance Fields
publication.authors: Lewis A G Stuart, Darren M Wells, Jonathan A Atkinson, Simon Castle-Green, Jack Walker, Michael P Pound

dataset.provenance:
We used a robot system to capture data of a set of different wheat plants, captured over a series of different timesteps. All individual data captured of each plant, at each timestep, was encapsulated into their own directories. 
The main data consists of RGB images and depth maps of each plant, captured from positions equidistance around the centre of each plant. Each position for each image was recorded and stored as a transform file and COLMAP point cloud, which ensures that these images can be utilised for 3D reconstruction using Neural Radiance Fields, 3D Gaussian Splatting or other supported models/frameworks.
Approximately 320 images and depth maps were captured for each plant instance- this would vary depending on if the robot setup failed to reach some of the positions. For each of the plant instances, we also include all model weights and training parameters, which can be executed using NeRFStudio.
This dataset is novel and is introduced along with the supported manuscript.
dataset.splits:
For each plant, there are around 35 images used for evaluation (284 images for training). These datasets were distributed evenly based on our capturing process (see IV.3).
Images assigned to the training set or evaluation sets are labelled with '_train' or '_eval' in each file name. Furthermore, separate transform files have been generated for both training and evaluation images. Validation sets are not required for training view synthesis models (at least in this instance).
dataset.redundancy: We chose to implement a 8:1 split between our training and evaluation (test) images. These images were added to each set sequentially during capturing, meaning that after 8 training images were captured, the next was added to the evaluation set. Our capturing process takes images around the plant in a linear path, meaning that the evaluation images were evenly distributed around the plant (resulting in accurate evaluation results). These splits are similar to other multi-view image datasets (such as the original NeRF Dataset).
dataset.availability:
All of the data is publicly available via this link: [TO ADD]
We also have supporting scripts for executing NeRFStudio models on this data on this Github Repo link: https://github.com/Lewis-Stuart-11/3D-Plant-View-Synthesis

model.interpretability: We used two models for training, 3D Gaussian Splatting and Neural Radiance Fields, both supported by NeRFStudio. Neural Radiance Field models utilise a neural network to represent a given scene, meaning that these models are black box. However, 3D Gaussian Splatting models utilise gradient descent to position, reshape and recolour a set of Gaussians to fit a complex scene. Since these Gaussians are explicit data structure, this is an interpretable model
model.output: The model predicts an RGB image of a scene from a given camera position (view synthesis). These models can also generate point clouds and meshes.
model.duration:
For a Desktop PC rendering a 1920x1080 image:
3DGS model: ~0.05 seconds
NeRF model: 2.0 seconds
These times will vary based on the specifications of the computer running the model, as well as the size of the image to be rendered
model.availability: We utilised NeRFStudio for training on our dataset, which is available via this link: https://docs.nerf.studio/index.html. We also offer a scripts for easily running these models on our dataset, which is available via this link: https://github.com/Lewis-Stuart-11/3D-Plant-View-Synthesis

optimization.algorithm:
We used two methods for training on our dataset: Neural Radiance Fields and 3D Gaussian Splatting. Both of these methods are utilised for performing view synthesis, which allow novel views to be generated that are not included in the original training set. These models also perform 3D reconstruction.
NeRFStudio, a framework that offers functionality for training data on view synthesis models, was used for all training and evaluation of the dataset. We utilised two of their methods for training:
- NeRFacto: an implementation of NeRF that includes enhancements from various other established models
- Splatfacto: an implementation of Gaussian Splatting with some optimisations
Both of these methods offer state-of-the-art performance compared to other popular models, while also have a large range of functionality such as a real-time renderer, evaluation functionality and exportation capabilities
optimization.meta: No data from other ML algorithms were used
optimization.config: Yes, our parameter configurations and weights are publicly available on our dataset, that can be accessed using this link: [TO ADD]
optimization.encoding: The data was not encoded before training
optimization.features: Roughly 320 RGB images were used for these models. 284 images were used for training.
optimization.fitting: View synthesis models, at least in the way we utilised them with this dataset, are designed to reconstruct a specific scene. Hence, these models are meant to overfit based on the images of the scene.
optimization.parameters: Each model has a large number of parameters (roughly 100). These are all the default values generated when running these NeRFStudio models. These parameters are stored in a config file for each trained model on our dataset
optimization.regularization: No, as we did not need to prevent overfitting

evaluation.method: For evaluation, we rendered a set of images using these models, and compared these to the ground truth images. The evaluation images were not included during training, ensuring that our evaluations effectively measure how accurate these reconstructions are.
evaluation.measure:
The metrics we used were PSNR, LPIPS and SSIM. These were generated using NeRFStudio's evaluation functionality and can be compared to other standardised models.
We also include a new metric we call PSNR Masked, which only calculates the PSNR of pixels included in a mask (which excludes the background). We provide scripts for calculating this on our Github, which can be accessed via this link: https://github.com/Lewis-Stuart-11/3D-Plant-View-Synthesis
evaluation.comparison: No, we did not compare this to other datasets, since we are not providing that these NeRFStudio models are more efficient than other publicly available models. Rather, we compared the accuracy of point cloud generated via these models to point clouds generated using Structure from Motion (SfM)
evaluation.confidence: We showed that these methods produce better 3D reconstructions than other standard 3D reconstruction methods such as Structure from Motion (SfM)
evaluation.availability: Yes, these are available on our dataset which is available via this link: [TO ADD].

model.interpretability: The models are simple enough to allow intepretation. However, interpretation of the models is not important for our study
model.output: We fit a Ridge model for each dataset. We have two regression tasks (for the HCP and IXI datasets) and two classification tasks (for the ABIDE and BCW datasets)
model.duration: Depends on the adaptivesplit package configuration file. The program allows a fast mode to speed up computation but lowering precision.
model.availability: The maintained version of the software, for general use, is available in the following GitHub repository: https://github.com/pni-lab/adaptivesplit

optimization.algorithm:
RidgeCV, as implemented in Scikit-Learn
https://scikit-learn.org/stable/modules/generated/sklearn.linear_model.RidgeCV.html
optimization.config: configuration files and analysis scripts with used parameters are present in the following GitHub repository: https://github.com/pni-lab/AdaptiveSplitAnalysis
optimization.encoding: All features are standard scaled.
optimization.features: All the features present in each dataset.
optimization.fitting: We use only the default "alphas" parameter from RidgeCV. Overfitting is ruled out by cross validation.
optimization.parameters:
On each dataset we fit a simple Ridge Regressor (HCP, IXI) / Classifier (ABIDE, BCW) with a default alphas parameter:

RidgeCV scoring = “neg_mean_absolute_error” (for regression datasets: HCP, IXI); “accuracy” (for classification datasets: ABIDE, BCW)
RidgeCV alphas = “(0.1, 1.0, 10.0)”

The Adaptivesplit package includes a configuration file with parameters that define the "stopping rule".
Depending on the "stopping rule", the adaptivesplit algorithm finds the optimal splitting strategy to define the boundaries between what can be used as training data and what can be used as external validation. This is extremely useful during prospective data acquisition. 
When the algorithm finds the optimal splitting strategy it stops (this is why we talk about "stopping rule").

AdaptiveSplit parameters:

min_training_sample_size = 0
max_training_sample_size = inf
target_power = 0.8
alpha = 0.05
min_score = -inf
min_relevant_score = 0
min_validation_sample_size = 12

window_size= 6
step = 1
cv = 5

bootstrap_samples = 100
power_bootstrap_samples = 1
n_jobs = -1
scoring = “neg_mean_squared error” (regression); “accuracy” (classification)
total_sample_size = highest sample size budget (depends on each dataset)
optimization.regularization: L2 regularization, as implemented in scikit-learn's Ridge Regression

evaluation.method: cross-validation, novel experiments
evaluation.measure:
1. negative mean squared error for regression tasks
2. accuracy for classification tasks
3. p-values to evaluate the statistical significance
evaluation.comparison: We compare Ridge Regression with AdaptiveSplit against Ridge with fixed splitting methods: Pareto Split, Half Split and 90/10 Split
evaluation.confidence: we run each model on 100 different permutation of the data for each sample size budget. Final results are shown with using SEM as confidence intervals (See Fig.3 of the manuscript)
evaluation.availability: A dedicated repository with analysis code is present at https://github.com/gallg/AdaptiveSplitAnalysis
