Contrast learning is implemented by the explicit comparison of the d-dimensional embedding (where d = 128 by default) of a cell on two modalities on a unit hypersphere.  Positive sample pairs are created by taking two modal representations of a cell and pulling them together, while negative samples are created by taking different cells and widening the distance between them. The above process is quantified using NT-Xent loss (the normalized temperature-scaled cross-entropy loss). To avoid underfitting of the model, we set the minimum batch size to 32. As the number of training iterations increases, the NT-Xent loss will gradually decrease. To avoid overfitting of the model, we set the maximum epoch to 20.
optimization.parameters: The parameter that needs to be defined in the model is the dimension of embedding, and we set the dimension of the embedding to 128. Comparative experiments are detailed in Table S6.
optimization.regularization: To avoid overfitting of the model, we set the maximum epoch to 20.

evaluation.method:
To demonstrate the performance of Attune, we benchmark it against other multimodal integration methods (repeated five times with different random seeds) on matched scRNA-seq and scATAC-seq datasets, such as 10x Multiome and SHARE-seq, with several established metrics, most of which have been widely embraced and validated in previous single-cell integration tasks, such as graph connectivity (GC) in the NeurIPS 2021 competition and average silhouette width (ASW) in scJoint. We also quantify the alignment performance between modalities using the Fraction Of Samples Closer Than the True Match (FOSCTTM) on both datasets.
In cross-modal prediction, we compare it against state-of-the-art cross-modal prediction methods such as BABEL and Polarbear, using the 10x Multiome dataset (PBMC10k, n=11,909). We randomly divide cells into training (n=9527) and testing (n=2382) sets (bootstrapping five times), and evaluate the method using gene-wise Pearson correlation and gene-wise Spearman’s correlation.
evaluation.measure: Integration endeavors are assessed through an array of metrics, including mean average precision (MAP), cell type ASW, neighbor consistency (NC), Seurat alignment score (SAS), Batch ASW, graph connectivity (GC), biology conservation, omics mixing, overall integration score and FOSCTTM. Most of which have been widely embraced and validated in previous single-cell integration tasks, such as graph connectivity (GC) in the NeurIPS 2021 competition and average silhouette width (ASW) in scJoint and FOSCTTM in MMD-MA.
evaluation.comparison: We benchmark with GLUE, uniPort, Seurat, Cobolt, MinNet, scJoint, MultiVI, sciCAN, Babel and Polarbear on PBMC 10k dataset and SHARE-seq dataset.
evaluation.confidence: The performance metrics have confidence intervals and it can claim that the method is superior to others. We benchmark against other multimodal integration methods on PBMC 10k and SHARE-seq dataset (repeated five times with different random seeds). We benchmark against other cross-modal prediction methods on PBMC 10K and NeurIPS dataset (bootstrapping five times).
evaluation.availability: The evaluation code is shown in https://github.com/melobio/Attune. The evaluation results reported in this paper are available in Supplementary_Table.xlsx.

publication.title: DeepAnnotation: A novel interpretable deep learning-based genomic selection model that integrates comprehensive functional annotations
publication.authors: Wenlong Ma, Weigang Zheng, Shenghua Qin, Chao Wang, Bowen Lei and Yuwen Liu

dataset.provenance: We include genome, epigenome, and gene function data in our study. All datasets are public avaliable. Totally, i) the genotype data containing 11,633,164 SNPs from 1,940 samples; ii) the phenotype data containing three pork production traits from 1940 samples; iii) The processed ATAC-seq driven includes five pig tissues (muscle, liver, fat, spleen, and heart) from four breeds including Duroc, Enshi Black (ES), Large White (LW), and Meishan (MS), as well as eight Yorkshire tissues (adipose, cerebellum, cortex, hypothalamus, liver, lung, muscle, spleen); iv) 31,908 genes from 177 samples with high-quality normalized transcripts per million expression levels were prepared; v) pig reference genome Sscrofa11.1 was download from NCBI; vi) 186,152 records together covering 20,037 genes and 15,017 terms from GO and KEGG databases; vii) the functionally conserved annotation (including gene body, intergenic, and promoter coordinates) of pig was downloaded from Kern’s study (https://www.nature.com/articles/s41467-021-22100-8).
dataset.splits: 1700 samples were used for 5-fold cross validation experiment. In each fold, 80% samples are used for training the model and the rest 20% samples are used for testing the model performance. We also used additional 240 independent test set to evaluate the prediction performance, which never appeared during the training process.
dataset.redundancy: We split total 1900 samples into two parts, including 1700 samples for training the model and 240 independent test samples for robustness evaluation. 5-fold cross validation experiment is used to training the model. The independent test set never appeared in the training process.
dataset.availability: The datasets we used in our study are all public avaliable. All the relevant details can be found in the manuscript.

model.interpretability: DeepAnnotation is interpretable. We clearly describe the interpretability in our manuscript.
model.duration: The training elasped time usually takes serval hours for one 5-fold cross validation experiment. We report the running time in our manuscript.
model.availability: We release the source code and example data at GitHub (https://github.com/mawenlong2016/DeepAnnotation), and all data used for reproducing our results at Zenodo (https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.15055481). Moreover, we provide a docker image with configured environment at DockerHub (https://hub.docker.com/r/wenlong2023/deepannotation).

optimization.algorithm: DeepAnnotation is a novel genomic selection approach which consists of 7 layers, each dedicated to processing distinct types of omics data. These layers encompass genotype data, epigenomic features, RNA secondary structure data, transcriptomic profiles, gene function annotations, regulatory module metaterms, and additional high-order features, represented by two hidden layers.
optimization.meta: Specifically, the input data for training the DeepAnnotation model was organized into four distinct components: 1) Genotype data: 590,342 potential non-coding cis-regulatory SNPs within open chromatin regions and 65,706 coding SNPs. 2) SNP functional impacts: Predicted by DeepSEA for non-coding SNPs and RNAfold for coding SNPs to assess their potential biological effects. 3) Gene annotations: Derived from 4,111 annotated genes located in conserved regions, encompassing 227 GO and KEGG terms, all with AUC value exceeding 0.9, as determined by easyMF. 4) Metaterm regulatory modules: 31 metaterms extracted from a pool of 27,797 genes, excluding the 4,111 genes from (3), spread across 14,996 terms using easyMF.
optimization.config: Yes, we report the results of the hyperparameter optimization in the main manuscript and could be found in our supplementary data.
optimization.encoding: The genotype and SNP functional impacts are saved in three dimensional matrix with 'h5' format, the gene annotations and metaterm regulatory modules are saved in two dimensional matrix with 'h5' format, the phenotypes are saved in 'txt' format.
optimization.features: The input features including: i) 656048 genotype matrix; ii) 590342 non-coding SNPs with predicted DeepSEA scores and 65706 coding SNPs with MFE scores; iii) 4111 genes' predicted scores in 227 funtional terms; iv) 14996 functional terms' scores in 31 metaterms. These features driven from four distinct components including genotype data, SNP functional impacts, gene annotations and metaterm regulatory modules.
optimization.fitting: The number of parameters is much larger than the number of features. We reduce the overfitting by employing ReLU activate function and early stop the training process based on the performance on the validation set.
optimization.parameters: Totally, 1667805154 parameters are estimated in the DeepAnnotation model when utilizing all functional annotations. These parameters are corresponding to the weights and biases in each layer.
optimization.regularization: Yes, we employ the ReLU activation function and early stop the training process based on the performance on the validation set. The validation set is splited as the 20% training set in each round of 5-fold cross validation.

evaluation.method: We use 5-fold cross validation to evaluate the prediction performance, and utilize an independent data set to evaluate the robustness of our method.
evaluation.measure: Yes, we report the prediction performance of our model compared with seven well established models in our manuscript.
evaluation.comparison: Yes, we compared with seven classical GS models, including rrBLUP, LightGBM, KAML, BLUP, BayesR, MBLUP, and BayesRC.
evaluation.confidence: Yes, we report the significant level as P-values calculated through Student test.
evaluation.availability: Yes, we provide all the raw data to reproduce the results reported in manuscript at Zenodo (https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.15055481).

publication.title: DUNE: a versatile neuroimaging encoder captures brain complexity across three major diseases: cancer, dementia and schizophrenia
publication.authors: Thomas Barba, Bryce A. Bagley, Sandra Steyaert, Francisco Carrillo-Perez, Christoph Sadée, Michael Iv, Olivier Gevaert

dataset.provenance:
Publicly available datasets : 
UK-Biobank dataset : https://www.ukbiobank.ac.uk/
UPenn-GBM dataset : https://www.cancerimagingarchive.net/collection/upenn-gbm/
UCSF-PDGM dataset : https://www.cancerimagingarchive.net/collection/ucsf-pdgm/
TCGA-LGG dataset : https://www.cancerimagingarchive.net/collection/tcga-lgg/
TCGA-GBM  dataset : https://www.cancerimagingarchive.net/collection/tcga-gbm/
ADNI dataset : https://adni.loni.usc.edu/data-samples/adni-data/neuroimaging/mri/mri-image-data-sets/
SchizConnect : https://med.isi.edu/
dataset.splits: Our model development utilized 3,814 3D-MRI images (T1, T1Gd, FLAIR) from three datasets, with an 80%/20% train/validation split. The training dataset was carefully balanced to include both morphologically normal brains from UKB (800 randomly selected cases yielding 1,600 scans) and abnormal brains from glioma cohorts UPENN (1,224 scans) and UCSF (990 scans). For model evaluation, we extracted embeddings from 21,102 individuals in the development datasets (19,955 from UKB) and 1,322 individuals across three independent validation cohorts: TCGA-GBM/LGG (n=168), ADNI (n=818), and SchizConnect (n=336). Using these extracted embeddings, we trained machine learning models to predict various clinical parameters, employing a 5-fold cross-validation procedure to ensure robust performance assessment. To address potential class imbalance in categorical variables, we implemented an oversampling approach during model training, ensuring balanced distributions between training and validation sets.
dataset.redundancy: Our autoencoder training and testing methodology ensured complete independence between data splits. The model development utilized scans from the UCSF and UPenn cohorts along with a subset of the UK Biobank dataset (800 randomly selected cases), implementing a standard 80%/20% train/validation split within this development dataset. To rigorously evaluate the generalizability of our autoencoders, we subsequently assessed their performance on entirely independent external datasets (ADNI, TCGA, and SchizConnect) that were not used in any capacity during model training.
dataset.availability: The datasets used in this study are all publicly available through established repositories. The UK Biobank data is accessible via their official portal (https://www.ukbiobank.ac.uk/) following an approved application (our access was under Application Number 51998). The glioma datasets (UCSF-PDGM, UPenn-GBM, TCGA-LGG, and TCGA-GBM) were obtained from The Cancer Imaging Archive (TCIA, https://www.cancerimagingarchive.net). The SchizConnect data (COBRE and MCIC datasets) is available through the COllaborative Informatics and Neuroimaging Suite Data Exchange tool (COINS; http://coins.mrn.org/dx). The ADNI dataset is accessible through the Alzheimer's Disease Neuroimaging Initiative database (http://adni.loni.usc.edu) for qualified researchers. While the raw data remains under the original licensing terms of these repositories, we have made our preprocessing pipelines and model architecture publicly available on GitHub (https://github.com/gevaertlab/DUNE).

model.interpretability: No
model.output: DUNE itself is neither a classification nor a regression model, but rather an unsupervised feature extraction framework based on autoencoder architectures. DUNE was designed to extract low-dimensional embeddings from full-sized brain MRI scans in an unsupervised manner through image reconstruction. These extracted embeddings were then used as inputs for downstream supervised machine learning tasks that included both classification and regression.
model.duration:
Brain extraction (skull stripping) = 2min30
Standardization = 1min30
Feature extraction < 5 sec
model.availability: The source code is available at https://github.com/gevaertlab/DUNE. No web server is currently available.

optimization.algorithm:
Our study employed multiple established ML algorithm classes in a complementary approach. The primary feature extraction component of DUNE utilizes convolutional autoencoder architectures based on the well-established UNet framework, adapted for 3D neuroimaging. We systematically compared four variants: a standard UNet with skip connections, a UNet without skip connections (U-AE), a variational UNet (U-VAE), and a fully connected variational autoencoder (VAE). These architectures were selected for their proven capabilities in medical image processing rather than developing entirely new algorithms. Importantly, autoencoders offer advantages over Vision Transformers (ViT) for our application as they require significantly less training data, making them more suitable for the relatively modest size of brain MRI datasets available in medical research contexts.

For the downstream clinical prediction tasks, we implemented intentionally simple and easily trainable ML algorithms: Ridge regression for quantitative variables, L2-penalized logistic regression for categorical variables, and random survival forests for survival analysis. This methodological choice was deliberate, as our primary objective was not to maximize absolute prediction performance, but rather to establish a standardized framework for comparing the quality of embeddings generated by each autoencoder architecture. By using consistent, straightforward algorithms across all prediction tasks, we could directly attribute performance differences to the underlying quality of the feature representations rather than to algorithmic complexity.
optimization.config: Yes. These data are available at : https://github.com/gevaertlab/DUNE
optimization.encoding: Brain MRI data underwent a preprocessing pipeline involving Advanced Normalization Tools (ANTs). The workflow began with conversion of DICOM files to NIFTI format when necessary. For each sequence (T1, T1Gd, FLAIR), we applied skull stripping using the ANTS Brain extractor tool with templates and probability masks from the OASIS dataset, followed by N4 bias field correction to address intensity non-uniformities. FLAIR images were co-registered to corresponding T1 scans to ensure spatial alignment. All images were then warped into a common MNI-152 T1 1mm template space, providing standardized spatial coordinates across all subjects. Final processed images had dimensions of [216,256,291] pixels (1px/mm, 1 grayscale channel) with Z-score normalized pixel intensities.
optimization.features: The model processes full-sized 3D brain MRI scans with dimensions of [216,256,291] pixels (1px/mm, 1 grayscale channel) after standardization. These preprocessed images serve as the direct input to the model, without any preliminary feature selection step. The autoencoder approach was specifically chosen to automatically learn relevant features from the raw imaging data in an unsupervised manner. For each patient, global brain MRI embeddings were generated by concatenating features extracted from multiple sequences (T1, T1Gd, and/or FLAIR). While no traditional feature selection was performed, the model architecture itself acts as a dimensionality reduction mechanism, compressing the high-dimensional input data to between 1,000-5,000 features for conventional autoencoders and exactly 2,048 features for variational autoencoders, which are then used for downstream clinical prediction tasks.
optimization.fitting: Yes, p is larger than the number of training points. Different strategies were employed to rule out overfitting. First, a careful balance of morphologically normal and abnormal brains was maintained in the training data by downsampling the UK Biobank dataset to match the size of the glioma datasets, which improved generalization. Second, the model's performance was validated on completely independent external datasets (TCGA, ADNI, and SchizConnect), demonstrating robust generalization across different disease areas and imaging protocols. The practical utility of the extracted embeddings was further confirmed through their successful application to multiple downstream clinical prediction tasks, including diagnosis of neurodegenerative and psychiatric disorders, prediction of molecular markers, and survival analysis in glioma patients.
optimization.parameters: The four compared candidate models (UNET, U-AE, U-VAE, and VAE) contained between 5 and 7 million trainable parameters, with the U-AE model that performed best in our evaluations having approximately 6.3 million parameters. This parameter count was not arbitrarily selected but emerged from our architectural design decisions, specifically the number of convolutional blocks (6), the channel expansion pattern (4, 8, 16, 32, 64, and 128 channels across successive blocks), and the 3D convolutional kernel sizes (3×3×3). We empirically determined this configuration through preliminary experiments that balanced model capacity against computational constraints and the risk of overfitting given our dataset size. The bottleneck layer was designed to generate between 1,000 and 5,000 features for conventional autoencoders, and exactly 2,048 features for variational autoencoders. These dimensionalities were selected to provide sufficiently rich representations while remaining tractable for downstream machine learning tasks.
optimization.regularization: No

evaluation.method: All clinical predictions were assessed using 5-fold cross-validation with hyperparameter optimization via GridSearchCV within each fold. Most importantly, we tested generalization on three completely independent external datasets: TCGA (gliomas, n=168), ADNI (Alzheimer's disease, n=818), and SchizConnect (schizophrenia, n=336).
evaluation.measure: For reconstruction quality evaluation, we used the structural similarity index measure (SSIM). For categorical variable predictions, we reported area under the receiver operating characteristic curve (AUROC) and weighted F1-scores. For quantitative variables, we used R² scores. For survival analysis in glioma patients, we reported concordance index (C-index) and Brier scores.
evaluation.comparison: Yes, we performed systematic comparisons with radiomics features as an established baseline method for feature extraction from medical images.
evaluation.confidence: Yes. Yes.
evaluation.availability: The source code for our DUNE models is publicly available on GitHub at https://github.com/gevaertlab/DUNE. Confusion matrices for classification tasks are included directly in the article. The raw evaluation files can be made available upon request to the corresponding authors.

publication.title: DisPredict3.0: Prediction of intrinsically disordered regions proteins using protein language model
publication.authors: Md Wasi Ul Kabir, Md Tamjidul Hoque
tags: Critical Assessment of Protein Intrinsic Disorder

dataset.provenance: DisPredict3.0 is trained and validated using the same dataset as the flDPnn method. However, test set differs from the flDPnn method, as they exclude a protein sequence (DP01026) that contains an unidentified amino acid (X). The authors of the flDPnn method curated the 745 proteins dataset from the DisProt 7.0 database. The ordered and disordered annotations are collected from the DisProt database. The regions not defined as disordered in the DisProt database are considered ordered.
dataset.splits: The training, test, and validation set contains 445, 175, and 100 proteins, respectively. In the training dataset, 77.1 % of the residues are ordered, while 22.9 % are disordered. Likewise, the test and validation datasets contain 73.1 % and 83.4 % ordered residues, respectively, and 26.9 % and 16.6 % disordered residues.
dataset.redundancy: The training and test set share less than 25 % pairwise sequence identity to avoid overlap between the train and test set.
dataset.availability: The DisPredict3.0 webserver is available at https://bmll.cs.uno.edu. The code and data related to the development of Dispredict3.0 can be found here https://github.com/wasicse/Dispredict3.0 .

model.interpretability: LightGBM is not fully interpretable, but feature importance, SHAP, and tree visualization could help make it somewhat explainable
model.output: The model outputs continuous values between 0 and 1, so it it a regression task. the values are then converted to binary classes using threshold.
model.duration: the average execution time per protein for the DisPredict3.0 method was approximately 3.3 min (estimated from the plot) when run within a Docker container. the predominant portion of time is spent loading the sizable language model into memory.
model.availability: The DisPredict3.0 webserver is available at https://bmll.cs.uno.edu. The code and data related to the development of Dispredict3.0 can be found here https://github.com/wasicse/Dispredict3.0 .

optimization.algorithm: Light Gradient Boosting Machine (LightGBM) algorithm is used. LightGBM is a popular gradient-boosting framework based on tree-based learning algorithms. The algorithm develops trees leaf by leaf and selects the leaf that it thinks would result in the highest reduction in loss.
optimization.meta: The model uses data features extracted by flDPnn as part of its input. The training data of initial predictors and meta-predictor are independent of test data for the meta-predictor
optimization.encoding: DisPredict3.0 leverages the flDPnn method to gather residue-level, window-level, and protein-level sequence information. In addition to this, they extract evolutionary data using the Transformer-based protein language model known as Evolutionary Scale Modeling (ESM) from Facebook AI Research.  DisPredict3.0 extracts representations from all 34 layers of the ESM-1b (esm1b_t33_650M_UR50S) pre-trained model, representing each residue with a matrix of size (34 × 1281). They used  incremental PCA to transform the dimensions (34 × 1281) into a vector size of 5124, preserving 96.02 % of the original data variance.
optimization.features: flDPnn ==> 	317 fetaures, ESM1-b after PCA ==> 5124  features, Total Features ==> 5441 features
optimization.regularization: They employ the grid search technique to explore different parameter values, ultimately selecting the best parameter value of n_estimators = 1000. For the remaining parameters, they utilize the default values provided by scikit-learn. They also used 10-fold cross validation.

evaluation.method: The method used 10-fold cross validation for training and an independent test set from flDPnn excluding the protein DP01026.
evaluation.measure: The performance of DisPredict3.0 is evaluated using a suite of metrics that are commonly adopted for handling imbalanced datasets. These include the Area Under the Receiver Operating Characteristic curve (AUC), F1-score, Mathews Correlation Coefficient (MCC), and Kappa score. These metrics are established metrics used in CAID challenge.
evaluation.comparison: A comparison with 40 other methods is available in the paper and in the supplementary materials.

publication.title: Probabilistic Annotations of Protein Sequences for Intrinsically Disordered Features
publication.authors: Nawar Malhis
tags: Critical Assessment of Protein Intrinsic Disorder

dataset.provenance: Sequences from DisProt 2023_12 are used in training, augmented by annotations from IDEAL and DIBS. Four datasets are made labeled as "linker", "protein(binding)", "nucleic acid(binding)", and "all(protein and binding)". 4-fold cross validation is used, and sequences are clustered by 90% identity. Finally, for each of the four groups, they doubled (for 'linker', 'protein', and 'all') and tripled (for nucleic) its sequences by adding random sequences from the remaining DisProt sequences.
dataset.splits: They included all of the 185 new DisProt release 2024_06 sequences that are not in the 2023_12 release. To eliminate potential data contamination related to test sequences homologous to those used in training, they used CD-HIT to filter out test sequences with more than 30% identity to those used in training. Then, they extend the annotations of these sequences from the MobiDB-LIP database.
dataset.redundancy: Training set was redundancy reduced by 90% identity, and test set was redundancy reduced against Training set by 30% identity using CD-HIT. HAM was applied too.
dataset.availability: Details are provided in supplementary materials.

model.interpretability: since the method uses CNN, it could be treated as a blakc-box.
model.output: the model outputs a probability for each residue for being protein-binding, nucleotide-binding, all-binding and linker, so it is regression.
model.duration: using an Intel Core i9, 8/16 cores/threads CPU with 40G DDR4 RAM, and an RTX 3080 GPU machine, it took IPA 4 hours, 9 minutes, and 1 second to process all of the SwissProt (2024_06) 572,619 sequences and generate nucleotide, protein, and all binding predictions. On average, 2,300 sequences per minute or 38.3 sequences per second. When using the CPU to run IPA on the same machine, processing these SwissProt sequences took 11 hours, 45 minutes, and 39 seconds. That is 812 sequences per minute or 13.5 sequences per second.
model.availability: software is available at orca.msl.ubc.ca/nmshare/ipa.tar.gz

optimization.algorithm: Convolutional Neural Network is used.
optimization.meta: pLDDT and RSA from AlphaFold2 are used in the features.
optimization.config: Details are provided in the paper and supplementary materials.
optimization.features:
Input features are divided into three categories: two affinity features, five DisProt features (F5 in short), and two alphaFold-2 features. IPA nucleic only utilizes the F5 features, IPA (protein and all) utilizes the affinity and the F5 features, and IPA-AF2 utilizes all nine. Affinity features are derived from P, a 20 x 20 energy predictor matrix. For each position p between 1 and the last in the sequence, one of the affinity features is the sum of the energy in P between the residue at p and the w1=10 residues on each side of p. The second is the sum of this energy between w1 and w2=w1+25, from p + w1 to p + w2 on each p side. The F5 features are the frequency of each of the 20 standard amino acids in each of the five classes in the DisProt/CAID datasets: IDR, nucleic binding (N_bind), protein binding (P_bind), and 'Linker' in the DisProt data and 'PDB' annotation in the combined CAID1 and CAID2 sequences, divided by the frequency of that amino acid in the entire dataset, Supplementary Table S3. Finally, the two AlphaFold-2 features are those
used by the AlphaFold-binding predictor [48] and collected from the AlphaFold-2 generated structures; the alphaFold-2 relative solvent accessibility, RSA, and the AlphaFold-2 prediction accuracy score, pLDDT.
optimization.regularization: 4-fold Cross validation and grid-search are used.

evaluation.method: Independent test sets were developed.
evaluation.measure: AUC and other common performance metrics established by CAID are reported.
evaluation.comparison:
the method was compared to DisoFLAG ,NSHROUD, AlphaFold_binding, DeepDISOBind, APOD, MoRFchibi_Light, MoRFchibi_web, ANCHOR2, DisoRDPbind,
OPAL, ProBiPred .
evaluation.availability: Details are provided in the supplementary materials.

publication.title: APOD: accurate sequence-based predictor of disordered flexible linkers
publication.authors: Zhenling Peng, Qian Xing, Lukasz Kurgan
tags: Critical Assessment of Protein Intrinsic Disorder

dataset.provenance: DisProt 8.0 is used to extract proteins with Disorder Flexible Linker (DFL). The annotation protocol is the same as in DFLPred. Using the functional annotations DisProt they annotated 5893 residues in 175 DFL regions that are located in 117 IDPs. They collected 131 proteins that have majority of their residues functionally annotated and where this annotation is not DFL.
dataset.splits: They cluster the corresponding 117 + 131 = 248 protein sequences using BLASTClust (Altschul et al., 1997) at the 25% sequence identity. They divide the resulting 194 clusters into training and test datasets at random, where the training set (TR166) includes 166 sequences with 3661 DFL residues, and the test set (TE82) is composed of 82 chains with 2223 DFL residues.
dataset.redundancy: They cluster the corresponding 117 + 131 = 248 protein sequences using BLASTClust (Altschul et al., 1997) at the 25% sequence identity. They divide the resulting 194 clusters into training and test datasets at random, where the training set (TR166) includes 166 sequences with 3661 DFL residues, and the test set (TE82) is composed of 82 chains with 2223 DFL residues. The placement of entire clusters into the two datasets ensures that training and test proteins share below 25% sequence similarity.
dataset.availability: The TR166 and TE82 datasets are available at https://yanglab.nankai.edu.cn/APOD/benchmark/.

model.interpretability: Since the model uses a SVM, it could be interpretable.
model.output: The predictions take form of numeric propensity scores, which quantify likelihood that a given residue is in the DFL region, and the corresponding binary score, which categorizes a given residue as either DFL or non-DFL.
model.duration: Not reported.
model.availability: a webserver is available at https://yanglab.nankai.edu.cn/APOD.

optimization.algorithm: A support vector machine (SVM) is used.
optimization.meta: APOD takes protein sequence as the only input and processes it in two steps to produce prediction for every residue. The first step involves use of several third-party programs to provide a rich sequence profile that characterizes relevant (putative) structural properties of the input chain. More precisely, these properties include the amino acid composition (AAC) extracted directly from the input sequence, CONS generated with PSI-BLAST (Altschul et al., 1997), putative SS and the relative solvent accessibility (RSA) predicted with SPARKS-X (Yang et al., 2011) and putative intrinsic disorder derived from the DISOPRED3 prediction (Meszaros et al., 2018), which includes the sliding window-based representation of disorder (SWdis) and protein-level DisCon value.
optimization.config: They are reported in the paper.
optimization.encoding: They use sequence profiles as inputs.
optimization.features: AAC = 40, CONS=56, SS+RSA_based=38, SWdis23, total number of features is 169.
optimization.parameters: They use the popular RBF kernel and they optimize values of two parameters: complexity constant C and width of the kernel γ. They set their values to 2i where i = −5, −4, …, 5. They also optimize the sliding window size ws by considering the values ranging between 9 and 25; the two values correspond to the 10 percentile and the median length of DFL in the training dataset, respectively. They select the optimal values for ws, C, γ  by maximizing the average AUC values calculated over the five test folds in the 5-fold cross validation on the training set TR166. The optimized APOD model applies ws = 13, C = 1 and γ  =  0.0625.
optimization.regularization: 5 fold cross validation was used in the training.

evaluation.method: The method was tested on an independent dataset, TE82.
evaluation.measure: Precision, Recall, AUC and MCC are reported.
evaluation.comparison: The method is compared with DFLPred, IUPred2, DISOPRED3, PredyFlexy, and FUpred.

publication.title: DFLpred: High-throughput prediction of disordered flexible linker regions in protein sequences
publication.authors: Fanchi Meng, Lukasz Kurgan
tags: Critical Assessment of Protein Intrinsic Disorder

dataset.provenance: The functionally annotated data were collected from the newest release 6.0.2 of DisProt that includes 694 sequences. They excluded DP00688 sequence that was too long (>18 000 residues) to predict with the PSIPRED ( Buchan et al. , 2013 ) to generate secondary structure. They selected 204 sequences, which include 82 proteins that have annotations of DFLs and 122 proteins that do not have DFL annotations but for which all residues are annotated.
dataset.splits: They divided the set of 204 proteins into five subsets and reduced sequence similarity between these subsets with BLASTClust ( Altschul et al. , 1990 ). First, They clustered the 204 sequences with sequence identity threshold at 25% and coverage of at least 10% of the sequence length. Second, the resulting 160 clusters that include similar sequences (>25% similarity) were divided at random between the five sub sets to ensure that each subset has similar number of sequences and similar ratio of DFL to NDFL residues. Four of these subsets were used in 4-fold cross-validation protocol to empirically design the predictor, i.e. to conceptualize and select inputs for the predictive model, and to select and parameterize this model. These data constitute the training dataset. The remaining fifth subset was used as an independent (never used in the design) test dataset.
dataset.redundancy: They clustered the 204 sequences with sequence identity threshold at 25% and coverage of at least 10% of the sequence length. Second, the resulting 160 clusters that include similar sequences (>25% similarity) were divided at random between the five sub sets to ensure that each subset has similar number of sequences and similar ratio of DFL to NDFL residues.
dataset.availability: The training and test datasets have 144 sequences and 60 sequences, respectively, and they are available at http://biomine.ece.ualberta.ca/DFLpred/ .

model.interpretability: The model is a logistic regression, so it is interpretable.
model.output: The prediction of DFLs results in a numeric score in the range between 0 and 1 representing propensity of each residue in the input sequence being in a DFL.
model.duration: On human proteome (20 193 sequences with an average length of 561), DFLpred takes 40min .
model.availability: the webserver is available at http://biomine.ece.ualberta.ca/DFLpred/

optimization.algorithm: Logistic regression is used.
optimization.meta: The model uses output from IUPred.
optimization.config: they are reported in the paper.
optimization.features: In the first layer, they represented every residue by its AA type, its physicochemical properties estimated based on the AA indices from the AAindex database ( Kawashima et al. , 2008 ), secondary structure predicted with PSIPRED ( Buchan et al. , 2013 ), intrinsically disordered and structured regions predicted with IUPred ( Dosztányi et al. , 2005 ) and sequence complexity computed with SEG. In the second layer, they generated numerical features that quantify the considered structural and sequence-based properties for each residue of the input AA sequence. they represented every residue by a feature vector calculated from a sliding window centered on that residue. The sliding window aggregates structural and sequence-based information by considering characteristics of AAs adjacent in the sequence. Consequently, they normalize values of features computed over the residues in the window by the size of the window. In total, they considered 2236 features including 40 features derived directly from the sequence, 2124 features derived from physicochemical properties of AAs quantified based on the AAindex database, 22 features generated from the putative secondary structure, 40 features from putative intrinsic disorder and structured regions and 10 features from the sequence complexity.
optimization.parameters: Parameters of logistic regression were selected with 4 fold cross-validation.
optimization.regularization: 4 fold cross-validation was used.

evaluation.method: an independent test set was used.
evaluation.measure: AUC is reported.
evaluation.comparison: on the same test set, it was compared with UMA, EspritzNMR, IUPred, PredBF, PredyFflexy, FlexPred, PROFbval, DynaMine, MFDp.
evaluation.availability: It is available in the supplementary materials.

publication.title: CLIP: accurate prediction of disordered linear interacting peptides from protein sequences using co-evolutionary information
publication.authors: Zhenling Peng, Zixia Li, Qiaozhen Meng, Bi Zhao, Lukasz Kurgan
tags: Critical Assessment of Protein Intrinsic Disorder

dataset.provenance: They use MobiDB 3.0 to collect the 2303 proteins that include manually curated LIPs. Following the annotation protocol from, they first cluster these 2303 sequences using CD-HIT with 100% sequence identity. They set the longest chain in a given cluster as a representative sequence and transfer annotations of LIPs in a given cluster into this chain. Altogether, this procedure introduces 69 additional LIP residues when compared with the annotation without the transfer, i.e. 0.19% increase in the amount of LIP annotations; Supplementary Materials provide further details. Second, they group the resulting 2285 sequences into 1440 clusters by applying CD-HIT with 25% sequence identity threshold, and select the longest sequence to represent each cluster. They divide these sequences into a training dataset TR1000 and a test dataset TE440 at random. The TR1000 dataset is composed of 1000 proteins that have 1380 LIPs (average of 1.38 LIP per protein) and 24 821 amino acids in the LIP regions. The remaining 440 proteins, which cover 612 LIPs (average of 1.39 LIP per protein) and 11 994 residues in the LIP regions, constitute the TE440 dataset.
dataset.splits: The TR1000 dataset is composed of 1000 proteins that have 1380 LIPs (average of 1.38 LIP per protein) and 24 821 amino acids in the LIP regions. The remaining 440 proteins, which cover 612 LIPs (average of 1.39 LIP per protein) and 11 994 residues in the LIP regions, constitute the TE440 dataset.
dataset.redundancy: CD-HIT with 25% redundancy was used.
dataset.availability: Data set is available at https://biomine.cs.vcu.edu/servers/CLIP/#Materials.

model.interpretability: The model uses linear regression in the end so it is interpretable, but to calculate the features it uses SVM and Random Forest.
model.output: The model outputs both a binary prediction and a propensity score for the residue to be disordered.
model.availability: The webserver of CLIP is freely available at http://biomine.cs.vcu.edu/servers/CLIP/ and the standalone code can be downloaded from http://yanglab.qd.sdu.edu.cn/download/CLIP/

optimization.algorithm: SVM, Random Forest and Logistic regression are used.
optimization.meta: The model uses outputs from DISOPRED3.
optimization.config: Details are provided in the paper.
optimization.features: The three types of inputs include co-evolutionary information (COEV), physiochemical characteristics of amino acids that are relevant to binding (PHYS) and disorder prediction generated with the popular DISOPRED3 method [81]. We produce these inputs at the residue level, combine them together into a 3-dimensional vector and process the resulting vector using sliding windows to produce inputs for the logistic regression.
optimization.parameters: They use logistic regression to combine the COEV, PHYS and disorder prediction inputs. They parametrize this model by identifying a favorable value of the ridge parameter based on the 5-fold cross-validation on the TR1000 dataset. More specifically, we consider ridge = 10^n where n = −5, −4, ……4, 5 and select the ridge value = 0.1 that produces the highest average AUC that we calculate over the five AUC scores from the five test folds in the cross-validation experiment.
optimization.regularization: 5 fold cross validation was used.

evaluation.method: the method used an independent dataset TE440 to evaluate the model on a LIP dataset. They used  another experimental MoRF dataset, EXP25, to compare the performance with MoRF predictors.
evaluation.measure: AUC, precision, recall and MCC are reported.
evaluation.comparison: It was compared to SPOT-MorF, MoRFCHiBi,  DisoRDPbind, and ANCHOR2 on EXP25 and TE440 datasets.

publication.title: flDPnn2: Accurate and Fast Predictor of Intrinsic Disorder in Proteins
publication.authors: Kui Wang, Gang Hu, Sushmita Basu and Lukasz Kurgan
tags: Critical Assessment of Protein Intrinsic Disorder

dataset.provenance: The dataset collection for flDPnn2 follows the process that they used for flDPnn (see Supplement for details) but using a much larger and publicly available collection of the disorder-annotated proteins from the version 9.1 of DisProt that they downloaded in March 2022.
dataset.splits: They randomly divided these 2,227 sequences into the training dataset (1,527 sequences), validation dataset (200 sequences), and test dataset (500 sequences). They designed the new predictive model using the training and validation datasets.
dataset.redundancy: Not reported.
dataset.availability: The training data is available in DisProt. The Disorder-NOX test set was used from CAID2 that is available at  https://caid.idpcentral.org/challenge/results

model.interpretability: The model contains a feed forward neural network, so it could be treated as not interpretable.
model.output: The model outputs continuous values, but also optimizes a threshold to assign binary states to each residue.
model.duration: The runtime is about 27s per proteins. A comparison between the runtimes of all CAID2 methods including flDPnn2 is reported in CAID2 paper: doi/10.1002/prot.26582
model.availability: flDPnn2 is freely available as a convenient web server at http://biomine.cs.vcu.edu/servers/flDPnn2/

optimization.algorithm: flDPnn2 model produces disorder predictions in three steps : 1) compute a sequence profile from the input sequence; 2) encode features from the profile; and 3) process the features via a deep neural network and an alignment module to generate putative propensities of disorder.
optimization.meta: The method uses the outputs of IUPred2, PSIPRED, DisoRDPbind (DNA-/RNA-/protein- binding), DFLPred, ANCHOR2. Since the method was tested on CAID2 Disorder-NOX dataset, the training data of the methods trained before CAID2's timeline do not have overlap with the test set.
optimization.config: They are reported in the paper.
optimization.encoding: They  use the profile to compute three feature sets: residue-level, window-level and protein-level
optimization.regularization: Dropout is used.

evaluation.method: The method is tested on the CAID2 Disorder-NOX reference set.
evaluation.measure: Inspired by the CAID2 assessment, they evaluate the binary predictions with F1 and MCC (Matthews correlation coefficient) and they use AUC (area under the receiver-operating characteristic (ROC) curve) and AUPRC (area under the precision-recall curve) to assess the propensities. Since the disordered residues are in minority (19.5% of amino acids), they follow related studies and compute lowAUCratio and lowPRCratio.
evaluation.comparison: The method was compared to all the methods in CAID1 and CAID2.
evaluation.confidence: Moreover, we assess statistical significance of differences between predictors, focusing on comparing other methods against flDPnn2They evaluate whether differences are consistent over a range of different test sets by performing 20 random selections of 50% of proteins from the Disorder-NOX dataset. They evaluate significance of differences over these 20 paired results using the student’s t-test if the measurements are normal, as evaluated with the Anderson-Darling test at 0.05 significance; otherwise they use the Wilcoxon test.
evaluation.availability: Evaluations are available in the paper and in the supplementary materials.

publication.title: PredIDR: Accurate prediction of protein intrinsic disorder regions using deep convolutional neural network
publication.authors: Kun-Sop Han, Se-Ryong Song, Myong-hyon Pak, Chol-Song Kim, Chol-Pyok Ri, Alessio Del Conte, Damiano Piovesan
tags: Critical Assessment of Protein Intrinsic Disorder

dataset.provenance: They obtain 8657 non-redundant, high-resolution protein sequences from the PDB database (August 09, 2019). Proteins were filtered so that their sequence identity is lower than 25 % and they are longer than 51 residues. Of the 8657 non-redundant PDB chains, 5997 (called “IDR chain”, see Additional file 2) have at least one IDR and 2660 (called “STR chain”, see Additional file 3) are fully structured.
dataset.splits: They randomly divided 5997 IDR chains into 2 datasets: one (called Train5400, see Additional file 4) includes 5400 chains, which will be used to make a training set together with 2660 STR chains, and the other includes 597 chains, which constitute a validation dataset (called Val597, see Additional file 5). Val597 dataset contains 151,203 residues and 950 disordered regions in 597 chains. Of 151,203 residues, 12,014 (7.95 %) residues are positives and 139,189 (92.05 %) residues are negatives. They use another two validation sets: one is CASP10 dataset (see Additional file 6) which was released in IDR category of CASP10 and the other is Val200 set (see Additional file 7), which consists of 200 protein chains with only the IDRs of at least ten residues, extracted from Val597 dataset.
dataset.redundancy: Proteins were filtered so that their sequence identity is lower than 25 % and they are longer than 51 residues.
dataset.availability: Details of data ids and train-test-validation splits are available at "additional files": https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ijbiomac.2024.137665

model.interpretability: Convolutional Neural Network is used, so it is not interpretable.
model.output: They used only one output node to predict the state of a residue where the output is 1 if the residue is disordered and 0 if predicted as ordered, so it's a binary classification.
model.duration: runtime of PredIDR is available in the CAID2 paper, along with the runtimes of all the predictors in CAID2.
model.availability: PredIDR can be freely used through the CAID Prediction Portal available at https://caid.idpcentral.org/portal or downloaded as a Singularity container from https://biocomputingup.it/shared/caid-predictors/

optimization.algorithm: Convolutional Neural Network is used.
optimization.meta: They do not use data from other predictors.
optimization.config: Details are provided in the paper.
optimization.encoding: They used a sliding window. All features in the sliding window are combined to form a feature tensor. The size of the tensor for each position in the window is 32 consisting of 21 frequency values (one for each amino acid type plus the gap symbol) as provided by the MSA profile, 8-dimensional vector for the 8-state secondary structure (SS8), one value for the predicted solvent accessibility (ACCDEC) and 2 values indicating whether the position is outside the sequence boundaries, i.e. before N-terminus or after C-terminus. In our experiments, they used a window of 15 residues, therefore, the size of the feature tensor for a single residue is 32 by 15.
optimization.features: represent each protein residue with three different features, evolutionary profile, secondary structure and solvent accessibility
optimization.regularization: They trained the convolutional neural network twenty times and the ten top-performing networks were chosen based on the performance in Val597 dataset and combined as an ensemble by averaging the predictions from ten top-performing neural networks. The outputs were then averaged.

evaluation.method: The model was tested on CAID1's Disorder-PDB, CAID2 Disorder-PDB, CAID2-NoX-PDB and CAID2-Xray-PDB
evaluation.measure: AUC and AUPR are reported in the paper, which aligns with the common metrics in CAID.
evaluation.comparison: The method is compared to all the methods of CAID1 and CAID2.
evaluation.confidence: Details are provided in the paper.
evaluation.availability: Details are provided in the paper.

publication.title: CODARFE: Unlocking the prediction of continuous environmental variables based on microbiome
publication.authors:
Murilo Caminotto Barbosa: [0000-0003-3528-1239]
João Fernando Marques Silva: [0000-0002-6559-9312]
Leonardo Cardoso Alves: [0000-0003-2078-7034]
Robert D. Finn: [0000-0001-8626-2148]
Alexandre Rossi Paschoal: [0000-0002-8887-0582]

dataset.provenance:
There are 3 main sources: 
- Group A: the original source is https://doi.org/10.1016/j.soilbio.2021.108472. 
- Grouo B: the original source is https://github.com/knights-lab/MLRepo/tree/master
- MGnify: https://www.ebi.ac.uk/metagenomics/about, ids: MGYS00000916, MGYS00001160, MGYS00000580, MGYS00001175, MGYS00001188, and MGYS00001255.

But all the sources processed and used during the work are public available at https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.14447515, under the folder "Data".

All values ​​are "True Values" meaning no data augmentation was used

Yes, all datasets have been previously used by other papers and recognized by the community.
dataset.splits:
Since it is a regression, all tests were performed using a suffle train-test split ten times. 

The exception was the cross-studies testing, which employed two (or four, depending on the experiment) datasets in a way that a model was trained on the entire dataset and then used to predict the second dataset. This procedure is repeated for every dataset.

For the non cross-studies, all the distributions are public available at suplemmentary material 1. 

The distribution was not plotted in other cases, but it can be done by the tool, without the use of external libraries.
dataset.redundancy:
The tests were performed using a suffle train-test split ten times. 

For the cross-studies the test sets were completly independent, since train and test were colledted from different projects.

for the non cross-studies, the distribution was the same as previously published ML datasets.
dataset.availability:
All the datasets are public available at https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.14447515. However, as it was suffled and split at random, the splits were not saved.
The license is CC0.

model.interpretability: The model is interpretable, since it is a regresison and the weights for each feature are visible. The program can also be used to plot a heat mat of feature relevance.
model.duration: For a small dataset (less than 10,000 columns), the duration is less than 10 minutes, and it is linear to the number of columns (features).
model.availability: Yes. there are 5 different ways to run the tool. All available at https://github.com/alerpaschoal/CODARFE under Apache License Version 2.0, January 2004

optimization.algorithm: The used ML algorithm are Huber Regression and Random forest regression.
optimization.config: Yes, they are all public available under the section "Material and Methods" on https://doi.org/10.1101/2024.07.18.604052 under a CC-BY-NC-ND 4.0 International license
optimization.encoding: The Center-Log-Ratio was used to remove the compositional effect.
optimization.features: The input dataset determines the number of features. The number of features is chosen by combining the Huber Regression with Recursive Feature Elimination.
optimization.fitting: Yes, p is much larger than the number off points. The overfitting was ruled out by combining four criteriato evaluate each set of features generated during the Recursive Feature Elimination: the R2 adjusted was chosen to determine the correlation strength with the target variable while selecting a concise number of predictors due to its penalization effect, collaborating to reduce the type 1 error during the fit process; BIC was chosen to differentiate models with similar R2 and with different predictor quantities, and it also helps keep low type 1 error due its penalization related to the number of predictors; Rooted Mean Squared Error (RMSE) was used in cross-validation to reduce overfitting,  and lastly, the p-value of the F-test is used to ensure the statistical significance of the selected predictors. All metrics were normalized using the “minmax” method and summed to create the model’s score. This occours at most 100 times and the best score is selected.
optimization.parameters: Using a grid-search the “epsilon” parameter, determining outlier influence, was set to 2, and the “alpha” value, controlling regularization, was set at 0.0003 for the Huber regresion, and  “n_estimators = 160” and “criterion = poisson” for the Random Forest.
optimization.regularization: Yes, mainly by the Rooted Mean Squared Error (RMSE) that was used in cross-validation to reduce overfitting during the model score creation. (See Fitting)

evaluation.method:
Shuffle train test split with ten repetitions.

For cross-studies , each dataset acts as an independent dataset.
evaluation.measure: Rooted mean squared error for the train-test split, and R² adjusted and Rooted mean squared error.
evaluation.comparison: Yes, the datasets were benchmarked using four recently published and freely available tools. Yes, the CLR-LASSO.
evaluation.confidence: All the p-values are reported by CODARFE, and all much smaller than 0.01.
evaluation.availability: No. However, the tool displays its own metrics, such as the p-value, and a 'hold-out' validation using a box plot.

publication.title: EpInflammAge: Deep Epigenetic-Inflammatory Clock for Disease-Associated Biological Aging
publication.authors: Alena Kalyakulina, Igor Yusipov, Arseniy Trukhanov, Claudio Franceschi, Alexey Moskalev, Mikhail Ivanchenko

dataset.provenance:
The study utilizes two groups of data: (1) concurrent inflammatory and epigenetic profile data for the same participants obtained by direct experiment, and (2) open-access epigenetic profile data downloaded from the NCBI GEO repository. Concurrent data were collected for 329 participants, and epigenetic profiles were used to estimate levels of inflammatory markers (100 features for each of 32 inflammatory markers, 2936 features in total). The open-access data from 17,195 participants (72 datasets from the NCBI GEO repository) were used to build a model for estimating biological age from inflammatory marker estimates. Some of the data obtained by direct experiment were previously used in [1, 2], and the epigenetic data from [1] are also in open access in the NCBI GEO repository under the accession number GSE234461. All open-access epigenetic data used in this work were previously published in the papers (references are given on the NCBI GEO repository pages of the corresponding datasets).
1. Kalyakulina, Alena, et al. "Epigenetics of the far northern Yakutian population." Clinical Epigenetics 15.1 (2023): 189.
2. Kalyakulina, Alena, et al. "Small immunological clocks identified by deep learning and gradient boosting." Frontiers in Immunology 14 (2023): 1177611.
dataset.splits: In both steps, prior to training the models, all data were split into two parts: 80% for training/validation and 20% for independent testing. During the training process, cross-validation was performed by sequentially dividing the data into training and validation sets at a ratio of 3:1, until all data were allocated to the training and validation sets. The final distribution was 60% of the data in the training set, 20% in the validation set and 20% as an independent test set. In the first step, concurrent data from a direct experiment was used to estimate inflammatory markers from epigenetic data. The training set contained 196 samples, the validation set contained 66 samples, and the test set contained 67 samples. In the second step, all individual GSE datasets were divided according to the same principle within each dataset. Stratification by age was employed to ensure representation of each dataset in all three sets wherever possible. If a dataset was too small or had a too narrow age range, it was put entirely into the test set. The final model was trained on 10,146 samples, validated on 3,390 samples, and tested on 3,659 samples. In addition, 7,842 samples from 13 different disease groups (according to ICD-11) were used to evaluate the sensitivity of the final model to various diseases. The final model results are plotted for both the training/validation and test datasets.
dataset.redundancy:
All data were divided into two parts: 80% for training/validation and 20% for independent testing. Age stratification was applied, dividing each dataset into five quintiles by age to ensure the independent test data were representative (covering a wide age range). Previous studies that have proposed epigenetic and inflammatory clocks models have employed similar distributions for splitting the data into training and test sets (GrimAge - 70/30 [1], Retro-age - 80/20 [2], IntrinClock - 75/25 [3], SImAge - 80/20 [4]).
1. Lu, Ake T., et al. "DNA methylation GrimAge strongly predicts lifespan and healthspan." Aging (albany NY) 11.2 (2019): 303.
2. Ndhlovu, Lishomwa C., et al. "Retro-age: A unique epigenetic biomarker of aging captured by DNA methylation states of retroelements." Aging Cell 23.10 (2024): e14288.
3. Tomusiak, Alan, et al. "Development of an epigenetic clock resistant to changes in immune cell composition." Communications Biology 7.1 (2024): 934.
4. Kalyakulina, Alena, et al. "Small immunological clocks identified by deep learning and gradient boosting." Frontiers in Immunology 14 (2023): 1177611.
dataset.availability: All data used in this paper are in the public domain. Concurrent inflammatory and epigenetic profile data for the same participants obtained by direct experiment are available in Supplementary Table S1 of the paper. Open-access epigenetic data are available in the NCBI GEO repository and can be freely downloaded. All corresponding datasets codes are located in Supplementary Table S6 of the paper.

model.interpretability: The deep neural network models in use are black boxes. However, explainable AI techniques (in particular, SHAP) were used to explain their outputs. The results of global and local explainability of SHAP values are provided in the text of the paper.
model.output: The two steps of the model building address the regression problem. Specifically, the first step involves regressing inflammatory markers, and the second step involves regressing age.
model.duration: The age estimation model proposed in this paper is available on the HuggingFace platform in a web interface format. The prediction execution time for a single sample is approximately 10 seconds (CPU Basic plan, 2vCPU, 16 GB RAM).
model.availability: The source code is available in the GitHub repository at https://github.com/GillianGrayson/EpInflammAge (MIT license). The model runs as a Gradio-based web interface on the HuggingFace platform at https://huggingface.co/spaces/UNNAILab/EpInflammAge, and this interface can also be run locally using code from the GitHub repository (app.py file).

optimization.algorithm: The published deep neural network architectures for tabular data were used: Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP), Deep Abstract Network (DANet), Feature Tokenizer and Transformer (FT-Transformer), Gated Adaptive Network for Deep Automated Learning of Features (GANDALF). The linear model ElasticNet was used as a baseline.
optimization.meta: The proposed algorithm in this paper is a two-step process. First, epigenetic data is used to estimate inflammatory markers. Second, these estimates are used to estimate biological age. The model estimating biological age uses the output of models estimating inflammatory markers from epigenetic data. The training data from the first group of models uses epigenetic profiles, while the second model uses estimates of inflammatory profiles. All training and test data are kept independent.
optimization.config: For hyperparameter optimization, we used optuna package [1], TPESampler [2]. Hyperparameter configurations, model files, optimizer parameters are available in the repository with the code accompanying the paper: https://github.com/GillianGrayson/EpInflammAge (MIT license). 1. Akiba, Takuya, et al. "Optuna: A next-generation hyperparameter optimization framework." Proceedings of the 25th ACM SIGKDD international conference on knowledge discovery & data mining. 2019. 2. Watanabe, Shuhei. "Tree-structured parzen estimator: Understanding its algorithm components and their roles for better empirical performance." arXiv preprint arXiv:2304.11127 (2023).
optimization.encoding: Functional normalization was used for open methylation data that had raw data. The levels of inflammatory markers that should have been predicted were log-transformed (target variable) to reduce skewness, bring the data distribution closer to normal, and improve the stability of the gradient flow during backpropagation. Missing values were imputed using the k nearest neighbors method.
optimization.features: The mRMR (minimum Redundancy - Maximum Relevance) method was used in the first step (estimation of inflammatory markers based on epigenetic data). The initial number of epigenetic features exceeded 400,000; mRMR reduced them to 100 for each evaluated inflammatory marker. A total of 2,936 epigenetic features were used to estimate all 32 inflammatory markers, with a small overlap between features. In the second step of the process (which estimated biological age based on inflammatory marker predictions), the Pearson correlation coefficient between real and predicted inflammatory marker values was used (threshold set at 0.5). The number of input inflammatory markers was reduced from 32 to 24.
optimization.fitting: We employ deep neural network architectures for tabular data, which have considerably more parameters than the number of training points. However, the design principles of their architectures allow them to combat overfitting. Specifically, DANet employs hierarchical abstraction to reduce noise, FT-Transformer utilizes a self-attention mechanism to focus on relevant features, and GANDALF uses adaptive gating. All models utilize dropout and batch normalization for regularization.
optimization.parameters: For the 24 models estimating levels of inflammatory markers, the number of parameters varied from 50,000 to 1 million, depending on the model. The final age estimation model had 336,000 parameters.
optimization.regularization: To prevent overfitting, a set of techniques were employed, including early stopping, cross validation, and the division of data into training, validation, and test sets.

evaluation.method: Cross validation and performance evaluation of the model for training, validation, and independent test data were used. Mean Absolute Error (MAE) and Pearson correlation coefficient were used as metrics. The developed model was benchmarked against other epigenetic clocks using these metrics for healthy samples. Furthermore, the model’s sensitivity to diseases was assessed. The Mann-Whitney U-test was used to assess the distribution of age acceleration between healthy controls and samples with specific diseases, controlling for false discovery rate (FDR) with a p-value less than 0.05. The number of diseases to which the model was sensitive was counted (a total of 76 tests were performed).
evaluation.measure:
The main performance metrics considered were MAE and Pearson correlation coefficient, as they are the most commonly used in papers proposing epigenetic and inflammatory clocks (Hannum [1], AltumAge [2], Retro-age [3], and SImAge [4]).
1. Hannum, Gregory, et al. "Genome-wide methylation profiles reveal quantitative views of human aging rates." Molecular cell 49.2 (2013): 359-367.
2. de Lima Camillo, Lucas Paulo, Louis R. Lapierre, and Ritambhara Singh. "A pan-tissue DNA-methylation epigenetic clock based on deep learning." npj Aging 8.1 (2022): 4.
3. Ndhlovu, Lishomwa C., et al. "Retro-age: A unique epigenetic biomarker of aging captured by DNA methylation states of retroelements." Aging Cell 23.10 (2024): e14288.
4. Kalyakulina, Alena, et al. "Small immunological clocks identified by deep learning and gradient boosting." Frontiers in Immunology 14 (2023): 1177611.
evaluation.comparison: This paper presents a comprehensive comparison of epigenetic clock models, assessing their performance on healthy controls and sensitivity to various disease groups. The analysis involved 25,000 samples and 34 models. Different deep neural network architectures were explored in model construction, including the baseline ElasticNet model, which is commonly used in aging clocks (and, as expected, demonstrated lower performance compared to deep neural network architectures for tabular data).
evaluation.confidence: Statistical significance was assessed for the sensitivity of the developed and compared approaches to different disease groups. For this purpose, we utilized the Mann-Whitney U-test with FDR-correction (Benjamini-Hochberg procedure), setting the significance threshold at 0.05.
evaluation.availability: The results for all compared models are presented in a large summary table in Figure 6 in the text of the paper. All corresponding files with the code used to calculate the metrics are provided in the GitHub repository https://github.com/GillianGrayson/EpInflammAge (MIT license).

publication.title: DeepDISOBind: accurate prediction of RNA-, DNA- and protein-binding intrinsically disordered residues with deep multi-task learning
publication.authors: Fuhao Zhang, Bi Zhao, Wenbo Shi, Min Li, Lukasz Kurgan
tags: Critical Assessment of Protein Intrinsic Disorder

dataset.provenance: DisProt Database is used.
dataset.splits: train = 238, validation=118, test=394
dataset.redundancy: data is redundancy reduced at 30% sequence similarity with CD-HIT.
dataset.availability: The datasets, including annotations of the DNA-, RNA- and protein-interacting IDRs, are freely available at https://www.csuligroup.com/DeepDISOBind/.

model.interpretability: The method uses CNN and FNN.
model.output: DeepDISOBind and other related tools produce putative propensities for the disordered DNA-, RNA- and protein-binding interactions for each residue in the input protein sequences. These real-valued propensities are accompanied by binary predictions, i.e. residues are classified as either DNA-/RNA-/protein-interacting or non-DNA-/RNA-/protein-interacting.
model.duration: The execution time is available in the CAID2 and CAID3 results.
model.availability: DeepDISOBind is available at https://www.csuligroup.com/DeepDISOBind/

optimization.algorithm: Convolutional Neurual Networks and Feed Forward Neurual Networks are used.
optimization.config: The details are availanble in the supplementary materials available at http://bib.oxfordjournals.org/
optimization.encoding: the profile includes 33 dimensions: 20 for one-hot encoding of sequence +3 sequence embedding values +5 RAAP values +3 secondary structure predictions +2 disorder predictions. They use sliding windows to predict the interaction propensity for the residues in the middle of the windows. We pad the windows at the sequence termini with zeros.
optimization.features: the profile includes 33 dimensions: 20 for one-hot encoding of sequence +3 sequence embedding values +5 RAAP values +3 secondary structure predictions +2 disorder predictions
optimization.parameters: The hyperparameters were tuned on the validation set.
optimization.regularization: They use early stopping, and dropout. more details are provided in the paper.

evaluation.method: The method was tested on independent dataset.
evaluation.measure: F1 score, sensitivity, and AUC are reported which are common metrics used in CAID.
evaluation.comparison: The method is compared toDisoRDPbind, MTDsites, ProNA2020, ANCHOR2, MoRFChibiLight, SCRIBER, BindN+, NCBRPred, TargetDNA, RNABindRPlus
evaluation.confidence: Statistical significance tests are performed and reported in the paper.
evaluation.availability: Details are provided in the paper and Supplementary materials.

publication.title: PredIDR2: Improving accuracy of protein intrinsic disorder prediction by updating deep convolutional neural network and supplementing DisProt data
publication.authors: Kun-Sop Han , Ha-Kyong Kim , Myong-Hyok Kim, Myong-Hyon Pak, Song-Jin Pak, Mun-Myong Choe, Chol-Song Kim
tags: Critical Assessment of Protein Intrinsic Disorder

dataset.provenance: They obtained 11,065 non-redundant protein sequences from Protein Data Bank (PDB) and Database of Protein Disorder (DisProt). These proteins have sequence identity <25 % among them and are longer than 50 residues. These include 8657 X-ray crystallography structures from PDB database (August 09, 2019) and 2408 protein sequences from DisProt database (DisProt release 2023_06).
dataset.splits: The validation set is the CAID1's Disorder-PDB dataset, except that 3 sequences DP01985, DP02003 and DP02027 were removed, along with 18 other proteins that were not in DisProt anymore. This results in 625 sequences.
dataset.redundancy: Training proteins have sequence identity <25 % among them.
dataset.availability: Details of dataset are available in "additional files".

model.interpretability: The model is a CNN, so it could be treated as a blackbox, although there are some methods for CNN interpretablility.
model.output: They used only one output node to predict the state of a residue where the output is 1 if the residue is disordered and 0 if it is ordered.
model.duration: Execution time is reported in the CAID prediction portal:  https://caid.idpcentral.org/challenge/results
model.availability: PredIDR2 series can be freely used through the CAID Prediction Portal available at https://caid.idpcentral.org/portal or downloaded as a Singularity container from https://biocomputingup.it/shared/caid-predictors/

optimization.algorithm: Convolutional Neural Network is used.
optimization.meta: No predictions from other methods is used.
optimization.config: Details are reported in the paper.
optimization.encoding: The encoding schema is the same as PredIDR.
optimization.features: PredIDR2-Prof_Art and PredIDR2-Prof_Rnd (called PredIDR2-Prof series) use the same input features as PredIDR: sequence profile, eight-state secondary structure and 20-class solvent accessibility. PredIDR2-Seq_Art and PredIDR2-Seq_Rnd (called PredIDR2-Seq series) also use three input features. In addition to two features employed in PredIDR: eight-state secondary structure and 20-class solvent accessibility, they use protein sequence rather than sequence profile for the purpose of providing faster speed than PredIDR2-Prof series
optimization.regularization: Details are reported in the paper. An Ensemble smoothing is used.

evaluation.method: The test set is CAID2's Disorder-PDB. The dataset contains 286,999 residues and 493 disordered regions in 348 chains. Of 286,999 residues, 37,072 (12.92 %) are positives, 93,805 (32.68 %) are negatives and 156,122 (54.40 %) are excluded. They also used two additional test sets created in our previous study PredIDR, CAID2-X-ray-PDB and CAID2-NoX-PDB, to inspect the predictor ability to detect two different flavors of disorder.
evaluation.measure: AUC, AUPRC, MCC, DC_mae are reported, which are common metrics established in CAID.
evaluation.comparison: Comparison with CAID2 methods is available.
evaluation.confidence: Not reported.
evaluation.availability: Details are provided in the paper and additional files.

publication.title: Protein intrinsically disordered region prediction by combining neural architecture search and multi-objective genetic algorithm
publication.authors: Yi-Jun Tang, Ke Yan, Xingyi Zhang, Ye Tian, Bin Liu
tags: Critical Assessment of Protein Intrinsic Disorder

dataset.provenance: The training dataset included 614 LDR proteins, 3024 SDR proteins, and 616 fully ordered proteins, which is constructed based on a training set derived from DeepIDP-2L and RFPR-IDP (They are obtained from DisProt and MobiDB).
dataset.splits: They constructed 5 validation sets with different ratios of SDR and LDR proteins.
dataset.redundancy: In this study, five commonly used datasets with different ratios between SDRs and LDRs were used to evaluate the performance of different methods., including MXD494, SL329, DISORDER723, CASP, and Disprot504(https://disprot.org/). To further test the generalization of various methods, the MSDCD independent test dataset was constructed by combining these five datasets. IDP-Fusion was also evaluated on the CAID1.
dataset.availability: All the data are available at http://bliulab.net/IDP-Fusion/benchmark/ . statistical information about data is availble in the additional file 1.

model.interpretability: The final model combines 6 neural network models, so it could be treated as a blackbox.
model.output: The individual models output continuous values that are then turned into binary labels.
model.duration: Runtime of a single protein is not available, but they compare the runtime with SPOT-Disorder2 on a dataset.
model.availability: A webserver is available at http://bliulab.net/IDP-Fusion/benchmark/

optimization.algorithm: IDP-Fusion fused six base methods to stably predict both the SDRs and LDRs . Among the six base methods, five models were derived from the field of natural language processing, including CAN , HAN , IDP-Seq2Seq , CNN-LSTM , and LSTM-CNN . CAN used the convolutional attention network to obtain the discrete distribution patterns of SDRs in protein sequences. HAN employed the hierarchical attention model to capture the sequence location of LDRs mainly located in the N’ and C’ of the sequences. IDP-Seq2Seq combined Seq2Seq and attention mechanism to capture the global and non-local correlation features of residues in IDRs. Convolutional neural networks (CNN) was used to extract local features of IDRs, and long short-term memory (LSTM) was used to extract global features of IDRs. The CNN and LSTM were combined to obtain both the local features and global features of IDRs. Two models CNN-LSTM and LSTM-CNN were constructed inspired by SPOT-Disorder2. They employed the neural architecture search (NAS) model DARTS to capture the hidden features of protein sequences
optimization.encoding: Three types of features were combined into IDP-Fusion, including residue-profile features, evolutionary features, and structural features. Residue-profile features included seven commonly used amino acid physic-chemical properties. Evolutionary-level features included position-specific frequency matrix (PSFM) and position-specific scoring matrix (PSSM).  The PSSM, PSFM, and HMM features are 20-dimensional features. Structural-level features included 8-dimensional secondary structure (SS), 2-dimensional CN, and 4-dimensional HSE predicted by using SPIDER2 software tool , 21-dimensonal predicted residue-residue contacts (CCMs) predicted by using CCMpred software tool, and 1-dimensional solvent accessibility (SA) predicted by using the Sable Version 2 software tool.
optimization.features: Three types of features were combined into IDP-Fusion, including residue-profile features, evolutionary features, and structural features. Details of the number of gathered features are available in the paper.

evaluation.method: The method was tested on various independent datasets.
evaluation.measure: All the common metrics that are established in CAID are reported.
evaluation.comparison: It was compared to most of the methods that participated in CAID. Details are provided in the additional file1.

publication.title: SeedGerm-VIG: an open and comprehensive pipeline to quantify seed vigour in wheat and other cereal crops using deep learning powered dynamic phenotypic analysis
publication.authors: Jie Dai; Zhenjie Wen; Mujiahid Ali; Shuchen Liu; Jianhua Zhao; Felipe Pinheiro; Changcai Yang; Bin Wang; Lingzhen Ye; Xueying Guan; Ji Zhou

dataset.provenance:
Wheat seed germination experiments were carried out in 2022 and 2023 in the UK. Two types of low-cost SeedGerm devices were built for time-lapse imaging of 21 wheat genotypes.
The 'SeedVig-phase' dataset contained 3,053 seed-level images, where 776 images at IMB, 720 at PRO, 784 during RE, and 773 during SE.
The 'SeedVig-traits' dataset was consisted of 1,932 seeds, 2,106 seeds with roots and seedlings, and 2,040 seedlings.
The data has not been used in any other paper.
dataset.splits:
A total of 151 images after augmentation (which compromised the 'SeedVig-phase' dataset) were randomly divided into training, testing, and validation sets in a 7:2:1 ratio.
The images in 'SeedVig-traits' dataset (96, 108, and 114 images for seeds without roots and seedlings, seeds with roots and seedlings, and seedlings after augmentation) were divided randomly into 70% (for training) and 30% (for testing).
The distribution of data in each sets are very similar.
dataset.redundancy: The training and test sets are independent: data points to be used as the training set were selected first, and the remaining data points were employed as the test set (validation set).
dataset.availability: The datasets used to train and test our models are available on github (https://github.com/The-Zhou-Lab/SeedGerm-VIG/releases) under the MIT license.

model.interpretability: Black box.
model.output:
The U-net model was classfication.
The YOLOv8x model was a combination of regression (predicting bounding box) and classfication (determining the class of each bounding box).
model.duration:
The phase identification of a 3280 * 2464 image takes around 0.2 s.
The mask prediction of a 3280 * 2464 image taks around 0.5 s.
The tasks were performed on a PC workstation (Inter(R) Core(TM) i7-10700F CPU, 16 GB RAM, and NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1660 Ti GPU).
model.availability: The executable files are released on github (https://github.com/The-Zhou-Lab/SeedGerm-VIG/releases) under the MIT license.

optimization.algorithm:
For identifying germination phases, we used the YOLOv8x model while predicting masks of seeds, seeds with roots and seedlings, and seedlings, we used the improved U-net model (Hasal et al., 2023).
Although neither of the machine learning algorithms represents the latest advancements, U-Net demonstrated superior performance compared to PSP-Net, HR-Net, and DeepLabV3+, while YOLOv8x outperformed SSD, Faster R-CNN, and RT-DETR.
optimization.meta: No data from other ML algorithms were used.
optimization.config: Yes, our model files and weights are publicly available on github (https://github.com/The-Zhou-Lab/SeedGerm-VIG/releases) under the MIT license.
optimization.encoding: The data was not encoded before training.
optimization.features:
