For YOLOv8x model, 105, 31, and 15 images are used for training, testing, and validation.
For U-net models, 67, 75, and 80 images are used as input to training models for predicting seeds, seeds with roots and seedlings, and seedlings.
optimization.fitting: p is indeed larger than the number of training points, but overfitting was mitigated through L2 regularization or early stopping.
optimization.parameters: 68,229,648 parameters are used in the YOLOv8x model. 28,800,069 parameters are used in the U-net model. These parameters were fine-tuned by training.
optimization.regularization: For U-net, we used L2 regularization to prevent overfitting. For YOLOv8x, we used early stopping to prevent overfitting.

evaluation.method:
For evaluation of YOLOv8x model, we rendered a set of images using this model, and compared these to the ground truth images. The evaluation images were not included during training.
For evaluation of U-net models, we used the traits extracted based on the predicted masks for correlation analysis.
evaluation.measure: Pearson correlation values were presented with p-values.
evaluation.comparison: Yes, both of the YOLOv8x and U-net models were compared based on the 'SeedVig-phase' and 'SeedVig-traits' datasets.
evaluation.confidence: The performance metrics didn't have confidence intervals. We used the mIoU, mPA and Precision to evaluate the performance of U-net, PSP-net, HR-Net, and DeepLabV3+. And used the Precision, Recall, mAP50, and F1 scores to evaluate the perfromance of YOLOv8x, SSD, Faster-RCNN, and RT-DETR.

publication.title: PUNCH2: Explore the strategy for intrinsically disordered protein predictor
publication.authors: Di Meng, Gianluca Pollastri
tags: Critical Assessment of Protein Intrinsic Disorder

dataset.provenance: PDB entries with missing residues and DisProt entries that are fully disordered are used as training dataset. The test sets include CAID1, CAID2, and CAID3. The details about the number of instances are provided in the paper.
dataset.splits: The details about all dataset splits are reported in the paper. The validation set was extracted from the training set.
dataset.redundancy: The test sets were independent and included the official test sets from CAID1, CAID2 and CAID3. The training sets were redundancy reduced at multiple levels.
dataset.availability: All dataset files are available at https://huggingface.co/datasets/deeeeeeeeee/PUNCH2_data.

model.interpretability: The model could be treated as a black box.
model.output: The model outputs a score for each amino acid to be disordered. they are converted to binary states using a threshold.
model.availability: the sever is available at https://alienlabs.ucd.ie/punch2/. The source code is available at https://github.com/deemeng/punch2 and https://github.com/deemeng/punch2_light. Docker images are available at https://hub.docker.com/r/dimeng851/

optimization.algorithm: Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) is used.
optimization.meta: The model used embeddings from ProtTrans(ProtT5) protein Language Models.
optimization.config: All the details are provided in the paper, at https://huggingface.co/datasets/deeeeeeeeee/PUNCH2_data.,  https://github.com/deemeng/punch2 and https://github.com/deemeng/punch2_light
optimization.encoding: Each amino acid was encoded to a an embedding using the protein Language Model. Additionally, an amino acid is converted to One-Hot encoding of 21 dimension (1 dimension for rare AAs ).
optimization.features:
One-Hot = 21
MSA-prob = 22 
MSA-probAA = 22 
MSA-prob-numTemp = 23
MSA-probAAnumTemp = 23 
ESM-2 = 1280 
MSA = Transformer 768 
ProtTrans = 1024
optimization.parameters: The training process was structured into two phases to develop robust predictors for intrinsically disordered regions (IDRs). Phase 1 focused on identifying the best combinations of embedding methods and network architectures, referred to as “best singles”. Phase 2 involved incremental improvements and the creation of ensemble predictors. The outcomes of Phase 1 include several optimal model solutions (single predictors), while Phase 2 yielded the final predictors, PUNCH2 and PUNCH2-light. These predictors were trained on larger datasets and benchmarked on CAID2, CAID3, and CAID1 datasets for validation.

evaluation.method: The method used independent datasets for testing.
evaluation.measure: AUCROC, APS, F1, MCC, and AUC-PR were reported, which are used in CAID.
evaluation.comparison: The comparison with other methods is available in the paper.

publication.title: NeProc predicts binding segments in intrinsically disordered regions without learning binding region sequences
publication.authors: Hiroto Anbo, Hiroki Amagai and Satoshi Fukuchi
tags: Critical Assessment of Protein Intrinsic Disorder

dataset.provenance: They used DM4229, which is a training dataset for the IDR prediction program, SPINE-D. DM4229 contains 4,229 sequences selected from PDB and DisProt. In the procedure to create DM4229, PDB structures, with resolution < 2 Å and length > 60 residues, were clustered at 25% sequence identity to select representative proteins with long contiguous IDRs from each cluster. These representative sequences were combined with fully disordered proteins from the IDP database, DisProt, and sequence redundancy was reduced again. The sequences identified in the test dataset (IDEAL) were excluded. The procedure produced 4,189 sequences consisting of 925,412 ordered and 100,284 disordered residues. Among these, 842 sequences were used to validate the hyperparameters of the neural networks, and the remaining 3,347 sequences were used to optimize the biases and weights.
dataset.splits: The procedure produced 4,189 sequences consisting of 925,412 ordered and 100,284 disordered residues. Among these, 842 sequences were used to validate the hyperparameters of the neural networks, and the remaining 3,347 sequences were used to optimize the biases and weights.
dataset.redundancy: Data was redundancy reduced at 25%

model.interpretability: The model could be interpretable since it combines neural networks and SVM.
model.output: The models output a three states labels of disorder, order or binding region,  so it is classification.
model.duration: Not reported
model.availability: Web server is available at http:// flab.neproc.org/neproc/index.html and also in the IDEAL database https://www.ideal-db.org/

optimization.algorithm: NeProc combined neural networks and support vector machines (SVM)
optimization.config: Details are provided in the supplementary materials.
optimization.encoding: The query sequence is converted to position specific scoring matrix (PSSM) using PSI-BLAST search against UniReg90.  . From a PSSM, they extracted the 21-dimensional vector for a site, including scores for each of the amino acid residues and one for the information per position, as with DISOPRED3.
optimization.features: Input features come from PSSM, and they are 21.
optimization.parameters: The hyperparameters were determined using the subset of the training dataset of 842 sequences. The parameters, weights and biases of the first and the second networks, were optimized using the subset of the remaining 3,347 sequences.
optimization.regularization: Adam optimizer with weight decay was used.

evaluation.method: The model was tested on an independent dataset (IDEAL and CheZOD and CASP10)
evaluation.measure: Sensitivity, precision, fscore, MCC is provided which are the common metrics used in CAID.
evaluation.comparison: The method was compared with ANCHOR2, MoRFchibi-web, DISOPRED3 and IUPred2
evaluation.availability: Evaluation results are available in the paper and in the supplementary materials.

publication.title: DISOPRED3: precise disordered region predictions with annotated protein-binding activity
publication.authors: David T. Jones and Domenico Cozzetto
tags: Critical Assessment of Protein Intrinsic Disorder

dataset.provenance:
For disorder prediction, the first database used was DisProt v5.0 (228 proteins). The other dataset was a 90% redundancy reduced subset of high resolution X-ray structures chains from PDB derived from PISCES. Chains shorter than 25 amino acids were discarded. Missing residues, including those with occupancy equal to zero, were treated as disordered.

For binding prediction in the disordered regions, A set of 840 peptides, with lengths between 5 and 25 amino acids and solved in complex with globular protein domains, was initially obtained from a previous study (Disfani et al., 2012). They discarded 196 peptides that couldn’t be mapped onto UniProtKB (UniProt,2014) sequences with SIFTS (Velankar et al., 2013)—because they were synthetic constructs, or the PDB files had been superseded, or the ATOM records mapped onto discontinuous fragments. They also removed 247 chains sharing 30% or more sequence identity to other regions, based on the BLASTP alignments generated with the recommended settings for short peptides (-seg no -matrix PAM30 -gapopen 10 -gapextend 1 -word_size 3). The positive training set was therefore made up of 5501 amino acids from 397 regions occurring in as many PDB chains (372 UniprotKB sequences). Just 104 of these UniProtKB chains were also used as positive examples for the new disordered residue prediction modules. Negative training examples were obtained from unbound protein domain linker regions in known protein structures. A total of 1164 linkers annotated in CATH v.3.5 . The negative training set consisted of 4930 amino acidsfrom 373 protein domain linkers occurring in 322 PDB chains (297UniprotKB sequences).
dataset.splits:
They built an independent benchmark set. They mined database annotations and scientific reports to collate 29 protein chains, which have been investigated using biophysical techniques and have been shown to be disordered in isolation and to fold upon protein binding. These sequences include 4077 disordered residues forming 36 regions, within which 37 protein-binding sites occur
spanning between 5 and 47 positions and comprising a total of 708 amino acids.
dataset.redundancy: data was redundancy reduced at 90%.
dataset.availability: All details are provided in the supplementary materials.

model.interpretability: The model is a combination of SVM and neural networks, with explainability approaches like SHAP analysis etc. could be interpretable.
model.output: The model outputs 3 states for disorder, binding and order, so it is a classification task.
model.availability: software is available at https://github.com/psipred/disopred

optimization.algorithm: The model uses neural networks and support vector machines.
optimization.meta: No the model doesn't use meta predictions.
optimization.encoding: Position-specific scoring matrix (PSSM) scores were calculated for each residue using three iterations of PSI-BLAST  running on the UniRef90 data bank (Suzek et al., 2007) with an inclusion E-value threshold of h = 0.001.
optimization.features: Features are obtained from PSSM matrix.
optimization.regularization: Cross validation was used.

evaluation.method:
They built an independent benchmark set. They mined database annotations and scientific reports to collate 29 protein chains, which have been investigated using biophysical techniques and have been shown to be disordered in isolation and to fold upon protein binding. These sequences include 4077 disordered residues forming 36 regions, within which 37 protein-binding sites occur
spanning between 5 and 47 positions and comprising a total of 708 amino acids.
evaluation.measure: Sensitivity, specifity, precision, MCC and f1 score is used, which are the common metrics used in CAID.
evaluation.comparison: The method was compared to DISOPRED2, MoRFpred, MFSPSSMpred, and ANCHOR
evaluation.availability: The evaluation results are available in the paper and in the supplementary materials.

publication.title: SETH predicts nuances of residue disorder from protein embeddings
publication.authors: Dagmar Ilzhöfer ,  Michael Heinzinger, and Burkhard Rost
tags: Critical Assessment of Protein Intrinsic Disorder

dataset.provenance: They used 2 datasets for training and testing available from ODiNPred, CheZOD1325 (training, 1325 proteins) and CheZOD117 (testing, 117 proteins). The train set was further redundancy reduced, and it contained 1174 proteins.
dataset.splits:
training set = 1174 proteins (Positive = 28% , Negative = 72%)
test set = 117 proteins (Positive = 69% , Negative = 31%)
dataset.redundancy: The training set (CheZOD1325) was redundancy reduced against the test set using MMseqs2 at 20% PIDE(percentage pairwise sequence identity). The CheZOD training data was already constructed such that all protein pairs had less than 50% PIDE.
dataset.availability: Datasets are available at https://github.com/DagmarIlz/SETH

model.interpretability: SETH uses a 2 layer CNN and in a separate model a linear regression, with AI explainability methods like SHAP analysisi could be interpretable.
model.output: The model predicts continuous values as CheZOD scores are, and uses threshold 8 to convert them to binary states.
model.duration: On a machine with one RTX A6000 GPU with 48GB RAM, predicting the nuances of disorder for each residue of the entire human proteome (20,352 proteins) from the individual protein sequences took approximately 23 min. For Swiss-Prot [566,969 proteins ], it took approximately 7 hours. SETH could predict disorder for approximately 10–20 proteins in 1 s, depending on the protein length. Even on smaller GPUs such as a single NVIDIA GeForce RTX 3060 with 12 GB vRAM, computing predictions for the human proteome still took only an hour. On an AMD Ryzen 5 5500U CPU, performing predictions for our test set CheZOD117 (average protein length 112) only took 12 min, showing that for small sets a GPU is not even necessary.
model.availability: SETH is freely publicly available at: https://github.com/Rostlab/SETH.

optimization.algorithm: They used linear regression, logistic regression and Convolutional Neural Networks.
optimization.meta: The use embeddings from ProtT5 protein language models.
optimization.config: Details are provided in the supplementary materials.
optimization.encoding: The embeddings from ProtT5  protein language model are 1024 dimensional real-valued vectors per residue in a protein.
optimization.features: Input features using ProtT5 pLM is 1024.
optimization.parameters: The parameters were selected with validation.

evaluation.method: The method was tested on CheZOD117 dataset.
evaluation.measure: The AUC is reported.
evaluation.comparison: The method is compared to AUCPred, DISOPRED2, DISOPRED3, DynaMine, ESpritz, GlobPlot, IUPred, MFDp2. RONN, SPOT-disorder, ODiNPred
evaluation.confidence: The confidence intervals at 95% are calculated.
evaluation.availability: The details are provided in the paper and supplementary materials.

publication.title: Protein embeddings and deep learning predict binding residues for various ligand classes
publication.authors: Maria Littmann, Michael Heinzinger, Christian Dallago, Konstantin Weissenow & Burkhard Rost
tags: Critical Assessment of Protein Intrinsic Disorder

dataset.provenance: Protein sequences with binding annotations were extracted from BioLiP9 . BioLiP provides bind-ing annotations for residues based on structural information from the Protein Data Bank (PDB), i.e., proteins for which several PDB structures with different identifiers exist may have multiple binding annotations. BioLiP annotated 104,733 structures with high enough resolution and binding annotations which could be mapped to 14,894 sequences in UniProt.
dataset.splits:

Supplementary Table S12)
dataset.redundancy: The BioLiP set was clustered to remove redundancy using UniqueProt with an HVAL < 0 (corresponding to no pair of proteins in the data set having over 20% pairwise sequence identity over 250 aligned residues

publication.title: Enhanced Genomic Transformer: A Technical Solution for Animal Quantitative Trait Predictions
publication.authors: Weixi Xiang,  Zhaoxin Li, Qixin Sun, Zhonglin Tang, Xiujuan Chai, Tan Sun

dataset.provenance:
The data used in the article originates from the following datasets:
AQT I: The Genus plc dataset, which contains dense genotypic, phenotypic, and estimated breeding value data for 3,534 individuals across five traits. This dataset has been used to evaluate genomic prediction methods such as BayesB and single-step genomic BLUP.
AQT II: The QTLMAS 2010 simulated dataset, which simulates genetic data for 3,226 individuals across five generations, including 10,031 SNP, 30 additive quantitative trait loci (QTL), 2 interacting QTL pairs, and 3 imprinted loci. It serves as a benchmark for QTL mapping and genomic breeding value estimation in complex genetic scenarios.
AQT III: A dataset from Huazhong Agricultural University exploring the genetic determinants of piglet mortality at birth across Yorkshire, Landrace, and Duroc sows. Through heritability estimation and Genome-Wide Association Studies (GWAS), it identifies 21 SNP and 19 candidate genes associated with piglet mortality.
AQT IV: A dataset constructed from 2,869 Duroc boars investigating the genetic basis of key agricultural traits, including Total teat number (TTN), Left teat number (LTN), Right teat number (RTN), and Back fat thickness at 100 kg (BF, mm). Genotypic data was generated via a Tn5 transposase-mediated low-coverage whole-genome sequencing strategy, yielding 11.3 million high-quality SNP after quality control, with GWAS identifying 14 QTL.
The dataset is primarily used for regression tasks, such as predicting the quantitative genetic traits of animals. The article does not specify the number of real-value points in the dataset. These datasets have been previously utilized by other papers. For example, the QTLMAS 2010 simulated dataset has been used as a benchmark for QTL mapping and genomic breeding value estimation in complex genetic scenarios. The Genus plc dataset has been employed to evaluate genomic prediction methods like BayesB and single-step genomic BLUP. The dataset from Huazhong Agricultural University has been used to explore the genetic determinants of piglet mortality at birth. The Duroc boars dataset has been used to investigate the genetic basis of key agricultural traits. These datasets are recognized by the community and serve as valuable resources for genomic prediction research.
dataset.splits:
The Animal Quantitative Traits (AQT) datasets used in the article were randomly split into training and test sets at a 7:3 ratio. Specifically:
AQT I: A total of 3,534 individuals, with 2,473 individuals in the training set and 1,061 individuals in the test set.
AQT II: A total of 3,226 individuals, with 2,258 individuals in the training set and 968 individuals in the test set.
AQT III: A total of 8,738 individuals, with 6,116 individuals in the training set and 2,622 individuals in the test set.
AQT IV: A total of 2,869 individuals, with 2,008 individuals in the training set and 861 individuals in the test set.
dataset.redundancy: The datasets were split into training and test sets at a 7:3 ratio. After the initial split, five - fold cross - validation was performed on the training set. The random split ensured that individuals were grouped by species, maintaining the true data distribution and ensuring that all individuals from the same dataset were either in the training/validation set or the test set.
dataset.availability:
The datasets supporting the results reported in the manuscript are available in the GigaDB repository. The specific datasets used in this study include:
AQT I: Genus plc dataset, containing dense genotypic, phenotypic, and estimated breeding value data for 3,534 individuals across five traits.
AQT II: QTLMAS 2010 simulated dataset, simulating genetic data for 3,226 individuals across five generations.
AQT III: Huazhong Agricultural University dataset, exploring the genetic determinants of piglet mortality at birth across Yorkshire, Landrace, and Duroc sows.
AQT IV: Duroc boars dataset, investigating the genetic basis of key agricultural traits in 2,869 individuals.
For complete details on data availability and usage terms, please refer to the GigaDB database terms of use. As for the data splits used, it is accessible at https://github.com/xwx1999/EGT. The project is licensed under the MIT License.

model.interpretability: The EGT model is not entirely a black box; it has elements of interpretability: Feature Importance via Self - Attention Mechanisms: The self - attention mechanism in the EGT model assigns weights to each SNP, capturing long - range dependencies and complex interactions within the sequence. This allows for an understanding of which SNPs are more important in predicting quantitative traits. By examining the attention weights, researchers can gain insights into the relative importance of different SNPs. QTL - guided Feature Engineering: The model uses QTL - guided feature engineering to identify SNPs associated with quantitative traits. This approach incorporates prior biological knowledge about the genetic markers linked to specific traits, making the feature selection process more interpretable. Researchers can understand which genetic markers are being used for predictions and their relevance to the traits of interest. Biological Interpretability through GWAS: The integration of GWAS analysis helps identify 14 QTL in the AQT IV dataset. This provides a biological basis for the model's predictions, allowing researchers to connect the genetic variations identified by the model with specific traits. Visualization of Predictions: The article provides examples where the EGT model successfully predicted animal quantitative traits, with predictions closely matching the Ground Truth values. These visualizations demonstrate the model's ability to make accurate predictions and offer a way to interpret its performance. However, it's important to note that the EGT model is a deep learning model, and while it incorporates elements of interpretability, it may still have some aspects that are not fully transparent. The model's interpretability is enhanced through the use of attention mechanisms, QTL - guided feature engineering, and biological validation, but the complex nature of deep learning models means that some level of interpretability challenge may still exist.
model.duration:
For specific inference times, the article provides the following information in Table 7:
EGT: Inference time of 0.12153 seconds on AQT I, 0.020164 seconds on AQT II, and 0.590318 seconds on AQT III.
These times are based on the EGT model running on four NVIDIA P100 16G GPUs. The exact inference time on a standard desktop PC or high-performance computing cluster may vary depending on the specific hardware configuration.
model.availability: The source code for the Enhanced Genomic Transformer (EGT) model is released and available on GitHub. You can access it at https://github.com/xwx1999/EGT. The project is licensed under the MIT License. The repository includes the source code and documentation necessary to run the algorithm. However, we do not release the availability of an executable, web server, or container instance for the EGT model.

optimization.algorithm:
The ML algorithm used in the article is a deep learning. We chose to develop and utilize EGT over better - known alternatives for several reasons:
Handling the sequential nature of genomic data: Traditional methods like GBLUP, LASSO, LGBM, CNN, and LSTM have limitations in effectively handling the sequential nature of genomic data and capturing the intricate relationships between Single Nucleotide Polymorphisms (SNP) and their phenotypic expressions. EGT leverages the power of the Transformer model's self - attention mechanisms to address this challenge.
Improved prediction accuracy: The custom loss function in EGT, which combines the R - squared correlation coefficient with Mean Squared Error (MSE), enhances prediction precision. Testing on diverse animal species demonstrated significantly improved prediction accuracy compared to conventional methods.
Better feature extraction capabilities: EGT's combination of autoencoders and self - attention mechanisms allows for more effective feature extraction and dimensionality reduction. This enables the model to learn more complex and abstract feature representations, leading to better performance in predicting quantitative traits.
Superior performance across multiple test datasets: The EGT model outperformed existing methods in terms of MSE and R - squared values across multiple test datasets, proving its effectiveness in accurately predicting animal quantitative traits.
The development of EGT was driven by the need to overcome the limitations of traditional methods and provide a more powerful solution for genetic selection and breeding programs.
optimization.meta: The EGT model does not use data from other ML algorithms as input. It primarily uses SNP (Single Nucleotide Polymorphism) sequences as input data. The model's architecture is designed to directly process and analyze the genomic data through its self - attention mechanisms and autoencoders, without relying on the output or predictions from other ML algorithms as input features.
optimization.config: Yes, these are accessible at https://github.com/xwx1999/EGT. The project is licensed under the MIT License.
optimization.encoding: The data used in the ML algorithm underwent several preprocessing steps: Ordinal Encoding: The nucleotide bases (A, T, G, C) were converted to numerical values using the NumPy package to enable mathematical operations on the SNP sequences. Missing Data Handling: Two approaches were employed - imputation to fill gaps using statistical methods and deletion to remove samples with extensive missing information. Dataset Split: The dataset was split into training and test sets at a 7:3 ratio. This ensured a robust and reliable foundation for model training and evaluation while maintaining the true data distribution. All individuals from the same dataset were either in the training/validation set or the test set. After the initial split, five - fold cross - validation was performed on the training set.
optimization.features: The EGT model uses SNP (Single Nucleotide Polymorphism) sequences as input features. The number of features (f) varies across the different datasets used in the study. The feature selection was performed as part of the data preprocessing pipeline, which included ordinal encoding, missing data handling, and dataset splitting. The dataset was split into training and test sets at a 7:3 ratio before any model training.
optimization.fitting: The number of parameters (p) in the EGT model is much larger than the number of training points. To rule out overfitting, the authors employed several strategies: Custom Loss Function: The EGT model uses a custom loss function that combines the R-squared correlation coefficient with Mean Squared Error (MSE). This helps the model focus on the correlation between predicted and observed quantitative traits, enhancing prediction precision. Regularization Techniques: The model incorporates residual connections before and after the MLP head. Residual connections help mitigate the vanishing gradient problem and allow the model to learn deeper and more abstract feature representations. Cross-Validation: Five-fold cross-validation was performed on the training set to ensure robust model generalization. Data Preprocessing: The data underwent rigorous preprocessing, including ordinal encoding, imputation of missing data, and deletion of samples with extensive missing information. This helps ensure the quality and consistency of the training data.
optimization.parameters: The EGT model contains approximately 47,067,001 parameters (p). The parameter selection follows typical values used in Transformer architectures, adapted for genomic data.
optimization.regularization: Yes, several overfitting prevention techniques were used in the EGT model. These include: Custom Loss Function: The EGT model uses a custom loss function that combines the R-squared correlation coefficient with Mean Squared Error (MSE). This helps the model focus on the correlation between predicted and observed quantitative traits, enhancing prediction precision. Regularization Techniques: The model incorporates residual connections before and after the MLP head. Residual connections help mitigate the vanishing gradient problem and allow the model to learn deeper and more abstract feature representations. Data Preprocessing: The data underwent rigorous preprocessing, including ordinal encoding, imputation of missing data, and deletion of samples with extensive missing information. This helps ensure the quality and consistency of the training data. Cross-Validation: Five-fold cross-validation was performed on the training set to ensure robust model generalization.

evaluation.method: The method was evaluated using a combination of cross-validation and testing on held-out datasets.
evaluation.measure:
The performance metrics reported in the study are:
Mean Squared Error (MSE): This metric measures the average squared difference between the predicted and actual values. It provides an indication of the model's prediction error. Lower MSE values indicate better model performance.
R-squared Correlation Coefficient (R²): This metric measures the proportion of the variance in the dependent variable that is predictable from the independent variables. It indicates how well the model explains the genetic variation. Higher R² values suggest a better model fit.
evaluation.comparison:
Yes, a comparison to publicly available methods was performed on benchmark datasets. The EGT model was compared with four state - of - the - art methods for predicting animal quantitative traits: Genomic Best Linear Unbiased Prediction (GBLUP), LASSO regression, Light Gradient Boosting Machine (LGBM), Convolutional Neural Network (CNN), and Long Short - Term Memory (LSTM). These methods are widely recognized and used in the field of genomic prediction and machine learning.
Additionally, the comparison included simpler baselines. GBLUP and LASSO can be considered simpler baseline methods compared to the more complex deep learning approaches like CNN, LSTM, and EGT. The results of these comparisons demonstrated that the EGT model outperformed the compared methods in most cases across the three AQT test datasets, showing superior predictive performance.
evaluation.confidence: To assess the statistical significance of the model performance, we employed Analysis of Variance (ANOVA) and Z - score analysis. The ANOVA yielded a P - value of 0.032, which is below the commonly used significance level of 0.05. This suggests that there are significant differences in predictive performance between the EGT model and other models. Additionally, a Z - score of 2.01 was obtained, which exceeds the critical value of 1.96 corresponding to a 95% confidence level. This indicates that the difference between the model's predicted values and the actual values is statistically significant.
evaluation.availability: The baselines are accessible at https://github.com/xwx1999/EGT. The project is licensed under the MIT License.

publication.title: SPOT-Disorder2: Improved Protein Intrinsic Disorder Prediction by Ensembled Deep Learning
publication.authors: Jack Hanson, Kuldip K. Paliwal, Thomas Litfin, Yaoqi Zhou
tags: Critical Assessment of Protein Intrinsic Disorder

dataset.provenance:
They obtained 4229 non-redundant, high-resolution protein sequences from the Protein Data Bank (PDB) and Database of Protein Disorder (DisProt). These include 4157 X-ray crystallography structures (deposited to the PDB prior to August 05, 2003) and 72 fully-disordered proteins from DisProt v5.0. 
For testing, they obtained three independent test datasets (SL250, Mobi9414, and DisProt228) . They removed long proteins (>700 residues) in these sets, and homologous proteins from the training set.
dataset.splits:
The data is randomly split into a training set (Training) of 2700 chains, a validation set (Validation) of 300 chains, and a testing set (Test) of 1229 chains. Sequence similarity among these proteins is <25% according to BLASTClust . They remove all proteins of length >700 from all datasets. This reduces our training, validation, and test sets to 2615, 293, and 1185 proteins, respectively. For convenience, they will label this test set as Test1185.
For test set, they obtained three independent test datasets (SL250, Mobi9414, and DisProt228) . They removed long proteins (>700 residues) in these sets, and homologous proteins from the training set.
dataset.redundancy: Data is non redundant. The sequence similarity in the entire dataset is less than 25%.
dataset.availability: Details are provided in the paper.

model.interpretability: The model is a combination of several neural networks, so it could be treated as a black-box.
model.output: The model is regression. It outputs the probability of an amino acid being disordered, so it's a value between 0 and 1.
model.availability: SPOT-Disorder2 is available as a web server and as a standalone program at https://sparks-lab.org/server/spot-disorder2/.

optimization.algorithm: The neural network topology employed in SPOT-Disorder2 consists of various models sequentially combining IncReSeNet, LSTM, and fully-connected (FC) topographical segments.
optimization.meta: They utilized the predicted structural properties from SPOT-1D. The features from SPOT-1D consist of 11 secondary structure probabilities (both three- and eight-state predicted secondary structure elements), 4 sine and 4 cosine θ, τ, φ, and ψ backbone angles, 1 relative solvent-accessible surface area (ASA), 1 contact number (CN), and 2 half-sphere exposure (HSE) values based on the carbon-α atoms.
optimization.config: All the details are available in the supplementary materials.
optimization.features:
SPOT-Disorder2 employed a similar set of features to SPOT-Disorder. Besides the same evolutionary content consisting of the position-specific substitution matrix (PSSM) profile from PSI-BLAST , SPOT-Disorder2 also includes the hidden Markov model (HMM) profile from HHblits [38]. The PSSM profile is generated by 3 iterations of PSI-BLAST against the UniRef90 sequence database (UniProt release 2018_03), and consists of 20 substitution values of each position for each AA residue type. The HMM profile consists of 30 values generated by using HHblits v3.0.3 with the UniProt sequence profile database from Oct 2017. These 30 values themselves consist of 20 AA substitution probabilities, 10 transition frequencies, and the number of effective homologous sequences of a given protein (Neff). In addition, they utilized the predicted structural properties from SPOT-1D. The features from SPOT-1D consist of 11 secondary structure probabilities (both three- and eight-state predicted secondary structure elements), 4 sine and 4 cosine θ, τ, φ, and ψ backbone angles, 1 relative solvent-accessible surface area (ASA), 1 contact number (CN), and 2 half-sphere exposure (HSE) values based on the carbon-α atoms.

In total there are 73 features in the input.
optimization.parameters: A large corpus of models with varying hyperparameters are trained and their performance is analyzed on a validation set. These hyperparameters are swept through in a grid search and include the layout of the network, the number of nodes in each layer (one parameter each for LSTM, IncReSeNet, and FC layers), and the number of layers for each layer type. The five top-performing models with hyperparameters are chosen from this validation period and used in the final ensemble for SPOT-Disorder2.
optimization.regularization: Dropout is used in different layers.

evaluation.method: They obtained three independent test datasets (SL250, Mobi9414, and DisProt228) . They removed long proteins (>700 residues) in these sets, and homologous proteins from the training set.
evaluation.measure: Sensitivity, precision, specifity, AUC ROC, AUC PR, and MCC are used, which are common metrics used in CAID.
evaluation.comparison: They compare SPOT-Disorder2 to several high-performing protein disorder predictors. These include the local versions of DISOPRED2 and DISOPRED3, MobiDB-lite, AUCpreD, s2D, GlobPlot, DisEMBLE, IUPred, AUCPred, JRONN, MFDp2, PONDR-VSL, SPOT-Disorder,  SPOT-Disorder-Single, ESpritz-D, ESpritz-N, ESpritz-X, and SPINE-D. They also used the webserver of NetSurfP-2.0.
evaluation.confidence: Statistical significance test is done and the results are statistically significant.
evaluation.availability: Details are available in the supplementary materials.

publication.title: A Case for Estradiol: Younger Brains in Women with Earlier Menarche and Later Menopause
publication.authors: Eileen Luders, Inger Sundström Poromaa, Claudia Barth, Christian Gaser

dataset.provenance:
UK Biobank: https://www.ukbiobank.ac.uk
Subset of n=3046 where two time points were available (about 2 years apart)
dataset.splits:
10-fold validation (no separate validation set used)
Distribution of age was adapted between test and training data
dataset.redundancy:
Test and training data are from the same database (UK Biobank), but are independent
Random splits while considering similar age distribution between test and training data
dataset.availability:
UK Biobank data are only available after registration and payment of access fee:
https://www.ukbiobank.ac.uk/enable-your-research/apply-for-access
The data IDs of the data used cannot be shared, since UK Biobank creates unique codes for each application separately. Our application ID is 42577.

model.interpretability: Gaussian Process Regression (GPR) is somewhat interpretable, but it's not as transparent as simple linear models. It's often seen as a semi-black-box model.
model.duration: ~100s on a desktop PC
model.availability: https://github.com/ChristianGaser/BrainAGE (Apache 2.0 license)

optimization.algorithm: Gaussian Process Regression
optimization.config: GPR code is available here: https://github.com/ChristianGaser/BrainAGE
optimization.encoding: Preprocessing of MRI data using CAT12 following these instructions: https://github.com/ChristianGaser/BrainAGE/blob/master/README.md
optimization.features: Feature reduction using PCA (based on singular value decomposition) to all the models using n–1 PCA components (n = minimum of voxel number or sample size)
optimization.fitting: GPR has quite low number of p
optimization.parameters: Hyperparameters: 100 for the constant mean function and -1 for the likelihood function
optimization.regularization: No

evaluation.method: cross-validation with 10-fold
evaluation.measure: Mean absolute error (MAE) which is quite common
evaluation.comparison: No
evaluation.confidence: No

publication.title: Comparing Linear and Nonlinear Finite Element Models of Vertebral Strength Across the Thoracolumbar Spine: A Benchmark from Density-Calibrated Computed Tomography
publication.authors: Matthias Walle, Bryn E. Matheson, Steven K. Boyd

dataset.provenance: The dataset consists of 160 clinical computed tomography (CT) scans from 141 patients, originally sourced from the publicly available VerSe 2019 dataset. It includes vertebrae from C1 to L6, totaling 1,725 individual vertebrae used for training. While the imaging data was not altered, new ground truth segmentation labels were generated for each vertebra, distinguishing the vertebral body and vertebral processes. Segmentation labels were created using an active learning approach: five vertebrae were manually segmented to initialize the model, and predictions on the remaining vertebrae were refined through manual correction as needed.
dataset.splits: 80% of the data was used for training and 20% for testing. A separate validation set was not used. Distributions of vertebral levels (C1 to L6), scanner types, and imaging protocols were not explicitly plotted, but care was taken to ensure a representative mix across training and test sets.
dataset.redundancy: Each CT scan and its associated vertebrae were assigned to only one of the two sets to avoid data leakage.
dataset.availability: The trained nnU-Net model is publicly available on Zenodo (https://zenodo.org/records/15238176).

model.interpretability: The model is considered a black box, no feature map visualizations or attention maps were generated.
model.output: The output is a multi-class semantic segmentation.
model.duration: We did not formally benchmark inference time, but based on typical nnU-Net performance and our system configuration, a single representative prediction (segmentation of one CT scan) requires approximately 2 minutes on a standard high-performance computing node with a modern GPU (e.g., NVIDIA A100 or equivalent). This includes preprocessing, model inference, and postprocessing.
model.availability: nnU-Net is available by the original creators on github: github.com/MIC-DKFZ/nnUNet

optimization.algorithm: The machine learning algorithm used is a 3D U-Net-based convolutional neural network, implemented via the nnU-Net framework. nnU-Net is not a new architecture, but rather a self-configuring segmentation framework that adapts U-Net hyperparameters and preprocessing steps to the dataset at hand. It has been extensively benchmarked and consistently outperforms custom pipelines across various biomedical segmentation challenges. We selected nnU-Net because of its strong, reproducible performance in medical image segmentation tasks, its widespread community acceptance, and its robust support for handling anisotropic 3D medical imaging data such as spine CT.
optimization.meta: No, the model does not use data from other machine learning algorithms as input.
optimization.config: All models are available on Zenodo:
optimization.encoding: Data were preprocessed using the standard nnU-Net pipeline.
optimization.features: The network learns a total of f = 320 feature maps at its deepest layer, starting from a base of 32 features at the first layer. The number of features doubles at each encoder stage up to a cap of 320, as configured by the nnU-Net framework. These feature maps represent internal representations learned by the convolutional layers during training. Feature selection was not performed in the traditional sense. All convolutional features are learned end-to-end from the training data as part of the model optimization process, without manual filtering or pruning.
optimization.fitting: Yes, the number of parameters p (~5.4 million) is considerably larger than the number of training instances (~1,380 vertebrae, i.e., 80% of 1,725), and the number of input features f = 1 (grayscale CT intensity).
optimization.parameters: The model has approximately 5.4 million trainable parameters in the 3D full-resolution configuration used. The number of parameters was not manually selected; instead, it was determined automatically by the nnU-Net framework, which adapts the network depth and width based on the input patch size, available GPU memory, and the complexity of the segmentation task.
optimization.regularization: Data augmentation: Real-time 3D augmentations—such as rotation, scaling, elastic deformation, noise, and intensity shifts—were applied during training to improve generalization.  Patch-based training: Training on randomly sampled patches increases the diversity of training inputs and mitigates overfitting to specific anatomical structures.

evaluation.method: The method was evaluated using an independent test set comprising 20% of the total dataset (160 CT scans of 1,725 vertebrae). This test set was held out during training to assess generalization performance.
evaluation.measure: We report Dice similarity coefficient (DSC) as the primary performance metric, which is standard for evaluating segmentation tasks in medical imaging.
evaluation.comparison: No comparisons to publicly available methods or simpler baselines were performed.
evaluation.confidence: No confidence intervals or statistical significance tests were reported, as the purpose of this work is not to claim superiority over other methods or baselines. The segmentation model is intended as a tool to enable anatomically detailed labeling for downstream biomechanical analysis, rather than as a benchmark to outperform existing approaches.
evaluation.availability: Raw evaluation files (e.g., statistical code, confusion matrices, or assignments for comparison) are not provided, as no formal benchmarking against other methods or statistical comparisons were performed. However, a training progress plot showing training and test performance over epochs is included in the Zenodo repository. All materials on Zenodo are shared under a CC0 license, ensuring unrestricted public access and reuse.

publication.title: Comparing Linear and Nonlinear Finite Element Models of Vertebral Strength Across the Thoracolumbar Spine: A Benchmark from Density-Calibrated Computed Tomography

optimization.algorithm: The machine learning algorithm used is a 3D U-Net-based convolutional neural network, implemented via the nnU-Net framework. nnU-Net is not a new architecture, but rather a self-configuring segmentation framework that adapts U-Net hyperparameters and preprocessing steps to the dataset at hand. It has been extensively benchmarked and consistently outperforms custom pipelines across various biomedical segmentation challenges. We selected nnU-Net because of its strong, reproducible performance in medical image segmentation tasks, its widespread community acceptance, and its robust support for handling anisotropic 3D medical imaging data such as spine CT.
optimization.meta: No, the model does not use data from other machine learning algorithms as input.
optimization.config: All models are available on Zenodo: https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.15238423
optimization.encoding: Data were preprocessed using the standard nnU-Net pipeline.
optimization.features: The network learns a total of f = 320 feature maps at its deepest layer, starting from a base of 32 features at the first layer. The number of features doubles at each encoder stage up to a cap of 320, as configured by the nnU-Net framework. These feature maps represent internal representations learned by the convolutional layers during training. Feature selection was not performed in the traditional sense. All convolutional features are learned end-to-end from the training data as part of the model optimization process, without manual filtering or pruning.
optimization.fitting: Yes, the number of parameters p (25.3 million parameters) is considerably larger than the number of training instances (80% of 1228), and the number of input features f = 1 (grayscale CT intensity).
optimization.parameters: The model has approximately 5.4 million trainable parameters in the 3D full-resolution configuration used. The number of parameters was not manually selected; instead, it was determined automatically by the nnU-Net framework, which adapts the network depth and width based on the input patch size, available GPU memory, and the complexity of the segmentation task.
optimization.regularization: Data augmentation: Real-time 3D augmentations—such as rotation, scaling, elastic deformation, noise, and intensity shifts—were applied during training to improve generalization.  Patch-based training: Training on randomly sampled patches increases the diversity of training inputs and mitigates overfitting to specific anatomical structures.

evaluation.method: The method was evaluated using an independent test set comprising 20% of the total dataset (160 CT scans of 1,725 vertebrae). This test set was held out during training to assess generalization performance.
evaluation.measure: We report Dice similarity coefficient (DSC) as the primary performance metric, which is standard for evaluating segmentation tasks in medical imaging.
evaluation.comparison: No comparisons to publicly available methods or simpler baselines were performed.
evaluation.confidence: No confidence intervals or statistical significance tests were reported, as the purpose of this work is not to claim superiority over other methods or baselines. The segmentation model is intended as a tool to enable anatomically detailed labeling for downstream biomechanical analysis, rather than as a benchmark to outperform existing approaches.
evaluation.availability: Raw evaluation files (e.g., statistical code, confusion matrices, or assignments for comparison) are not provided, as no formal benchmarking against other methods or statistical comparisons were performed. However, a training progress plot showing training and test performance over epochs is included in the Zenodo repository. All materials on Zenodo are shared under a CC0 license, ensuring unrestricted public access and reuse.

publication.title: Comparing Linear and Nonlinear Finite Element Models of Vertebral Strength Across the Thoracolumbar Spine: A Benchmark from Density-Calibrated Computed Tomography
publication.authors: Matthias Walle, Bryn E. Matheson, Steven K. Boyd

dataset.provenance: The dataset consists of 160 clinical computed tomography (CT) scans from 141 patients, originally sourced from the publicly available VerSe 2019 dataset. It includes vertebrae from C1 to L6, totaling 1,725 individual vertebrae used for training. While the imaging data was not altered, new ground truth segmentation labels were generated for each vertebra, distinguishing the vertebral body and vertebral processes. Segmentation labels were created using an active learning approach: five vertebrae were manually segmented to initialize the model, and predictions on the remaining vertebrae were refined through manual correction as needed.
dataset.splits: 80% of the data was used for training and 20% for testing. A separate validation set was not used. Distributions of vertebral levels (C1 to L6), scanner types, and imaging protocols were not explicitly plotted, but care was taken to ensure a representative mix across training and test sets.
dataset.redundancy: Each CT scan and its associated vertebrae were assigned to only one of the two sets to avoid data leakage.
dataset.availability: The trained nnU-Net model is publicly available on Zenodo (https://zenodo.org/records/15238176).

model.interpretability: The model is considered a black box, no feature map visualizations or attention maps were generated.
model.output: The output is a multi-class semantic segmentation.
model.duration: We did not formally benchmark inference time, but based on typical nnU-Net performance and our system configuration, a single representative prediction (segmentation of one CT scan) requires approximately 2 minutes on a standard high-performance computing node with a modern GPU (e.g., NVIDIA A100 or equivalent). This includes preprocessing, model inference, and postprocessing.
model.availability: nnU-Net is available by the original creators on github: github.com/MIC-DKFZ/nnUNet

It has been extensively benchmarked and consistently outperforms custom pipelines across various biomedical segmentation challenges. We selected nnU-Net because of its strong, reproducible performance in medical image segmentation tasks, its widespread community acceptance, and its robust support for handling anisotropic 3D medical imaging data such as spine CT.
optimization.meta: No, the model does not use data from other machine learning algorithms as input.
optimization.config: All models are available on Zenodo:

optimization.features: The network learns a total of f = 320 feature maps at its deepest layer, starting from a base of 32 features at the first layer. The number of features doubles at each encoder stage up to a cap of 320, as configured by the nnU-Net framework. These feature maps represent internal representations learned by the convolutional layers during training. Feature selection was not performed in the traditional sense. All convolutional features are learned end-to-end from the training data as part of the model optimization process, without manual filtering or pruning.
optimization.fitting: Yes, the number of parameters p (~5.4 million) is considerably larger than the number of training instances (~1,380 vertebrae, i.e., 80% of 1,725), and the number of input features f = 1 (grayscale CT intensity).

The number of parameters was not manually selected; instead, it was determined automatically by the nnU-Net framework, which adapts the network depth and width based on the input patch size, available GPU memory, and the complexity of the segmentation task.
optimization.regularization: Data augmentation: Real-time 3D augmentations—such as rotation, scaling, elastic deformation, noise, and intensity shifts—were applied during training to improve generalization.  Patch-based training: Training on randomly sampled patches increases the diversity of training inputs and mitigates overfitting to specific anatomical structures.

evaluation.method: The method was evaluated using an independent test set comprising 20% of the total dataset (160 CT scans of 1,725 vertebrae). This test set was held out during training to assess generalization performance.

The segmentation model is intended as a tool to enable anatomically detailed labeling for downstream biomechanical analysis, rather than as a benchmark to outperform existing approaches.

However, a training progress plot showing training and test performance over epochs is included in the Zenodo repository. All materials on Zenodo are shared under a CC0 license, ensuring unrestricted public access and reuse.

publication.title: A novel metric for hyperparameter optimization in Hi-C matrix prediction using linear regression
publication.authors: Joachim Wolff, Florian H. Heidel

dataset.provenance:
Predicted Hi-C matrices by the author in the process of hyperparameter optimization for Hi-cGAN.  The predicted matrices and their scores are in the center of the regression. We used 356 matrices and have therefore 356 datapoints per scoring function. For the regression we combine up to four scoring functions to predict the rating of matrices by a human expert. 

The data was new created by us and was not used by other papers or is recognized by the community.

The prediction of the matrices is based on GM12878 Hi-C matrix from Rao et al. 2014, GSE63525. The ChIP-seq data for the prediction is from the ENCODE Project Consortium: CTCF (GSM733752), H3K27ac (GSM733771), H3K27me3 (GSM733758), H3K36me3 (GSM733679), H3K4me1 (GSM733772), H3K4me2 (GSM733769), H3K4me3 (GSM733708), H3K79me2 (GSM733736), H3K9ac (GSM733677), H3K9me3 (GSM733664), H4K20me1 (GSM733642), Rad21 (GSM935332), Smc3 (GSM935376); DNaseI (GSM816665). Hi-C data for testing of the functions with biological replicates: Drosophila melanogaster nervous system cells (GSE214707); mouse embryonic stem cells (GSE234292); human myoblast and myotube cells (GSE283236).
dataset.splits:
We have 356 datapoints leading with a 80 / 20 split to 284 for training and 71 for a test set. We used additionally a 5-fold cross validation on the test set.

Are the distributions of data types in the training and test sets different? No.
Are the distributions of data types in both training and test sets plotted? No.
dataset.redundancy: The data was split by 80:20 by random selection.

model.interpretability: A linear regression is interpretable given the literature.
model.duration: Desktop-PC: < 0.01 Seconds
model.availability: https://github.com/joachimwolff/hyperparameterScoringHiC

optimization.algorithm: We used a linear regression, but tested also  TabPFN, CatBoost, gradient boosting, random forest, and XGBoost.
optimization.config: We did not apply hyperparameter optimization.
optimization.encoding: Predicted Hi-C matrices were scored by five different scoring functions. The scores were merged into a pandas data frame together with the human rating.
optimization.features: This depends on the scoring funtions. We tested 2 to 5 features. The accuracy of the selection is deeply evaluated in the paper.
optimization.fitting: No.
optimization.parameters: Linear regression with different degrees of freedom between 1 - 6 was tested. The one with the lowest MSE on the 5 fold cross validation was selected.
optimization.regularization: No.

evaluation.method:
Evaluation on Hi-C data with biological replicates: Drosophila melanogaster nervous system cells (GSE214707); mouse embryonic stem cells (GSE234292); human myoblast and myotube cells (GSE283236). 

Additionally, prediction on different resolutions (50kb, 100kb), and comparison of the ranking of the scoring functions, the original five scoring functions and the human expert ranking.
evaluation.measure: We use mean squared error, and specific measures like the comparison of the medians between all scores vs the scores of biological replicates.
evaluation.comparison: Yes. HiCRep and TAD scores.
evaluation.confidence: No. The results are evaluated on the scoring ability of bad Hi-C predicted matrices in comparison to traditional methods and the human expert ranking.

publication.title: CellBinDB: A Large-Scale Multimodal Annotated Dataset for Cell Segmentation with Benchmarking of Universal Models
publication.authors: Can Shi, Jinghong Fan, Zhonghan Deng, Huanlin Liu, Qiang Kang, Yumei Li, Jing Guo, Jingwen Wang, Jinjiang Gong, Sha Liao, Ao Chen, Ying Zhang, Mei Li

dataset.provenance:
The data used in this project comes from the dataset CellBinDB published in this article, as well as two public datasets IEEE_TMI_2019 and Lizard.
CellBinDB contains 1044 images, IEEE_TMI_2019 contains 50 images, and Lizard contains 238 images.
All the datasets mentioned above are publicly accessible. The 2 public datasets have been utilized in prior research and are well-recognized within the scientific community.
dataset.splits:
For our model fine-tuning process:
Training Set: We used the CellBinDB dataset, which contains 1,044 images.
Test Sets: Two separate datasets were used for testing:
IEEE_TMI_2019: Contains 50 images.
Lizard: Contains 238 images.

No separate validation set was used during the fine-tuning of both models (Cellpose and MEDIAR).

Regarding the distribution of data types:
The training set includes images from four different staining types (DAPI, H&E, ssDNA, and mIF), while both test sets only contain images stained with H&E. This difference in staining types between the training and test sets allows us to evaluate the generalization capability of our models on unseen staining types.
In our paper, we have included T-SNE plots that visualize the feature distributions of the datasets. These plots demonstrate that the features in CellBinDB are broadly distributed and cover characteristics from most publicly available datasets. This broad coverage explains why fine-tuning models on CellBinDB improves their performance on third-party datasets they have not seen before, thereby validating the utility and comprehensiveness of our dataset.
dataset.redundancy:
The training set consists of the CellBinDB dataset, and the test sets consist of two separate datasets: IEEE_TMI_2019 and Lizard.
The training set and the test sets are completely independent. There is no overlap between these datasets in terms of image content or source, ensuring that the models are evaluated on entirely unseen data during testing.
dataset.availability:
1. CellBinDB
   - Accession: https://zenodo.org/records/15110639
   - License: CC BY-NC-SA 4.0
2. IEEE_TMI_2019
   - Accession: https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.1174342
   - License: CC-BY-4.0
3. Lizard
   - Accession: https://www.kaggle.com/datasets/aadimator/lizard-dataset
   - License: CC BY-NC-SA 4.0

model.interpretability: The model is interpretable, but interpretation goes beyond the scope of this work. Our work focuses on fine-tuning existing models and observing whether performance improves.
model.output: The models used (Cellpose and MEDIAR) are for instance segmentation, not classification or regression. They are designed to identify and segment individual objects (such as cells) within images.
model.duration: Each image takes a few seconds on a consumer laptop.
model.availability: CellBinDB: https://github.com/STOmics/cs-benchmark (MIT license); Cellpose: https://github.com/MouseLand/cellpose (BSD-3-Clause license); MEDIAR: https://github.com/Lee-Gihun/MEDIAR (MIT license)

optimization.algorithm:
The models used in this study are Cellpose and MEDIAR. Both models are designed for image segmentation tasks, specifically tailored for biomedical image analysis.
Neither Cellpose nor MEDIAR is a new algorithm; both have been previously published and are well-established in the field.
optimization.meta: The input to the models consists of the original images from the datasets without any intermediate processing or outputs from other ML algorithms.
optimization.config: The default configuration of the original study was used. Cellpose: https://github.com/MouseLand/cellpose (BSD-3-Clause license); MEDIAR: https://github.com/Lee-Gihun/MEDIAR (MIT license)
optimization.encoding: The raw images were used directly without additional encoding. Both models are designed to process raw image data.
optimization.features: We use microscope images as input. Instead of using feature selection, we use a deep learning framework for abstract feature extraction.
optimization.fitting: By comparing train and test accuracies.
optimization.parameters: Default hyperparameters from the scikit-learn implementations, as in the original study.
optimization.regularization: No. Manually select training epochs based on experience.

evaluation.method: The method was evaluated on independent test sets (IEEE_TMI_2019 and Lizard). The primary focus was on comparing the improvement in F1 scores between the models fine-tuned on CellBinDB and those not fine-tuned.
evaluation.measure: The F1 score is reported as the primary performance metric. This metric is widely used in segmentation tasks and is representative of commonly used metrics in the literature, especially for evaluating precision and recall balance.
evaluation.comparison: The comparison was made between the model's performance before and after fine-tuning on our dataset (CellBinDB). Specifically, we evaluated the improvement in F1 scores post fine-tuning. No direct comparison with publicly available methods or simpler baselines was performed.
evaluation.confidence: No.

publication.title: Group-specific discriminant analysis enhances detection of sex differences in brain functional network lateralization
publication.authors: Shuo Zhou, Junhao Luo, Yaya Jiang, Haolin Wang, Haiping Lu, Gaolang Gong

dataset.provenance: We used two datasets, HCP and GSP, from public databases. HCP Npos 960 and Nneg 960, GSP Npos 1570 and Nneg 1570. The datasets have been used in previous published papers.
dataset.splits: For each dataset, 50% data points used for training and 50% data points used for testing.
dataset.redundancy: Each subject contribute two hemispheres. We divided our subjects into two groups: for 50% of the subjects, we used their left hemispheres for training, and for the remaining 50%, we used their right hemispheres. The hemispheres not selected for training were then used for testing.
dataset.availability: The original data sets are publicly available at https://www.humanconnectome.org/ for HCP and https://www.neuroinfo.org/gsp/ for GSP, which can be accessed via data use agreements. The preprocessed data sets are available at https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.10050233 for HCP and https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.10050234 for GSP.

model.interpretability: Our models are linear and interpretable. The coefficients of a first-order model represent the strength of lateralization for the corresponding brain network connections.
model.duration: Around 30 seconds on a standard CPU machine for fitting one model.
model.availability: The source code is available at: https://github.com/shuo-zhou/GSDA-Lateralization under MIT license.

optimization.algorithm: Group-specific discriminant analysis. This algorithm is new. It focuses on capturing group-specific patterns, while the patterns learned by standard classifiers
optimization.meta: In our second-order classification, the models obtained from the first-order classification (left vs. right) are used as input data.
optimization.config: Yes. Sample configurations are availabe on the GitHub repo: https://github.com/shuo-zhou/GSDA-Lateralization. Sample model files are available on Hugging Face Model Hub: https://huggingface.co/shuo-zhou/brain_network_lateralization. Both are provided under the MIT license.
optimization.encoding: Left brain hemispheres are labeled as 0, and right brain hemispheres are labeled as 1. For GSDA-Logit, sex is utilized as the grouping factor in the experiments, encoding males as 0 and females as 1
optimization.features: 7503 features. No feature selection.
optimization.fitting: In our experiments, the ratio of p/(Npos + Nneg) is between 5 and 8. We repeat the train-test split 1,000 times to demonstrate that the models are not overfitting.
optimization.parameters: Our model is linear, the number of parameters is the same as the number of features: 7503
optimization.regularization: We use L2 regularization to prevent overfitting.

evaluation.method: Repeated training-test split.
evaluation.measure: Classification accuracy and group specificity index derived from accuracy.
evaluation.comparison: We compared our method with standard logistic regression and univarite t-test.
evaluation.confidence: Accuracy and group specificity index are reported with confidence intervals. Our new method obtained the desired results, whereas the baseline methods did not.
evaluation.availability: The code for baselines and generated figures are available at: https://github.com/shuo-zhou/GSDA-Lateralization. Sample baseline model files are available on Hugging Face Model Hub: https://huggingface.co/shuo-zhou/brain_network_lateralization. Both are provided under the MIT license.

publication.title: Revealing the hidden sequence distribution of epitope-specific TCR repertoires and its influence on machine learning model performance
publication.authors: Sofie Gielis, Maria Chernigovskaya, Milena Pavlovic, Vincent Van Deuren, Romi Vandoren, Sebastiaan Valkiers, Kris Laukens, Victor Greiff, Pieter Meysman

dataset.provenance:
TCRex model training data was used. This includes:
(1) positive training data: a combined data set from several public databases, including VDJdb, McPAS-TCR and the ImmuneCODETM database and published papers. 
(2) negative training data: randomly collected TCR sequences derived from different healthy individuals from Dean, J., Emerson, R.O., Vignali, M. et al. Annotation of pseudogenic gene segments by massively parallel sequencing of rearranged lymphocyte receptor loci. Genome Med 7, 123 (2015). https://doi.org/10.1186/s13073-015-0238-z
dataset.splits:
For every epitope one model was trained. The size of the training data depends on the number of epitope-specific TCRs that could be found in the scientific literature/databases:
- The number of positive TCRs per model is given in Table S2.1 in the Supplemental Materials
- In general, 10 times more negative TCRs are used than epitope-specific TCRs when training prediction models. However, if negative TCRs share the same CDR3 β sequence and V/J genes as an epitope-specific TCR, they are excluded from the training data set. 

TCRex evaluates model performance using a stratified 5-fold cross-validation.
dataset.redundancy: TCRex evaluates model performance using a stratified 5-fold cross-validation.
dataset.availability: The training data is provided through the GigaDB dropbox. This includes a file with all positive and negative TCRs per prediction model.

model.interpretability: The model is interpretable. TCRex provides an overview of the feature importances on its statistics page.
model.output: Classification. TCRex predicts for every TCR whether it binds a specific epitope or not.
model.duration: Predicting the binding between one TCR and one epitope takes less than a second on a standard PC. Most of the time, researchers will upload various TCRs and make predictions against various epitopes with TCRex. A standard analysis on TCRex for 100 epitopes and max 50 000 TCRs requires a few minutes.
model.availability: TCRex is a webtool: https://tcrex.biodatamining.be/

optimization.algorithm: TCRex trains one random forest classifier per epitope.
optimization.config: No
optimization.encoding: We made use of our previously published TCRex framework for model training and evaluation. All information to understand data preprocessing is explained in Gielis, S., Moris, P., Bittremieux, W., De Neuter, N., Ogunjimi, B., Laukens, K., & Meysman, P. (2019). Detection of Enriched T Cell Epitope Specificity in Full T Cell Receptor Sequence Repertoires. Frontiers in immunology, 10, 2820. https://doi.org/10.3389/fimmu.2019.02820
optimization.features: Detailed information on the used features is present in: Gielis, S., Moris, P., Bittremieux, W., De Neuter, N., Ogunjimi, B., Laukens, K., & Meysman, P. (2019). Detection of Enriched T Cell Epitope Specificity in Full T Cell Receptor Sequence Repertoires. Frontiers in immunology, 10, 2820. https://doi.org/10.3389/fimmu.2019.02820
optimization.fitting: Overfitting is taken into account by making use of random forests instead of simple decision trees.
optimization.parameters: Every random forest is a collection of 100 decision trees.
optimization.regularization: Overfitting is taken into account by making use of random forests instead of simple decision trees.

evaluation.method: 5-fold cross-validation
evaluation.measure: Balanced accuracy, Area under the ROC curve and average precision
evaluation.comparison: Since this paper does not introduce a new tool, but uses a state-of-the-art tool to study the relationship between epitope-specific TCR repertoires and model performance, no comparison was made.
evaluation.confidence: We did not do any comparison with other tools since the goal was not to develop a new method.

dataset.provenance:

dataset.splits: frac_train=0.8, frac_valid=0.1, frac_test=0.1

dataset.availability: The names of the datasets are shared, including the citations. There is no information on the data splits.
