publication.title: ColoPola: A polarimetric imaging dataset for colorectal cancer detection
publication.authors: Thi-Thu-Hien Pham, Quoc-Hoang-Quyen Vo, Thao-Vi Nguyen, The-Hiep Nguyen, Quoc-Hung Phan, and Thanh-Hai Le

dataset.provenance:
ColoPola dataset is Colorectal cancer Polarimetric images dataset

The dataset consists of 572 slices (specimens) with 20,592 images, 284 slices of which were designated as cancer samples and 288 as normal samples.
Each sample has 36 polarimetric images (i.e., HH, HV, HP, HM, HR, HL, VH, VV, VP, VM, VR, VL, PH, PV, PP, PM, MH, MV, MP, MR, ML, MM, RH, RV, RP, RM, RR, RL, LH, LV, LP, LM, LR, and LL).
Each folder in the ColoPola dataset consists of 36 polarimetric images. Each image is 1280x1024 pixels in size and was created in the TIF file format (HH.tif, HV.tif, ..., LL.tif).
dataset.splits:
Type of sample	Specimen (Sample slices)	Image	Training	Validation     Testing
Normal	                              288	                        10,368	    184	    46	        58
Cancer	                              284	                        10,224	     181	    46	        57
Total	                              572	                         20,592	     365	    92	       115
dataset.redundancy: The dataset is divided by sample slices, not images.
dataset.availability:
https://zenodo.org/records/10554304
License: Creative Commons Zero v1.0 Universal

model.interpretability: Black box models
model.duration: 2s
model.availability: https://github.com/haile493/Colorectal-cancer-detection-using-ColoPola-dataset

optimization.algorithm: Binary class: Colorectal cancer and Healthy
optimization.meta:
No.
The results of models are evaluated on the testing set, independently from the training set and validation set.
optimization.config: https://github.com/haile493/Colorectal-cancer-detection-using-ColoPola-dataset
optimization.encoding: Crop the image from 1280x1024 to 900x900 pixels, then resize to 224x224 pixels.
optimization.features: The input data dimensions were defined as 900×900×36, representing the width, height, and red channel value of 36 polarimetric images. Subsequently, the input images were resized to 224×224×36 for processing.
optimization.fitting: Due to p≫(Npos+Nneg), we developed two small models and fine-tuned three pretrained ones, using techniques like early stopping to prevent overfitting.
optimization.regularization: Early stopping was utilized

evaluation.method: The models were evaluated on testing set (unseen data).
evaluation.measure: Accuracy, Precision, Recall and F1score
evaluation.comparison: We trained and compared five models.
evaluation.confidence: We applied for two statistical test to validate the results of five models.

publication.title: SynProtX: A Large-Scale Proteomics-Based Deep Learning Model for Predicting Synergistic Anticancer Drug Combinations
publication.authors:
Bundit Boonyarit
Matin Kositchutima
Tisorn Naphattalung
Nattawin Yamprasert 
Chanitra Thuwajit
Thanyada Rungrotmongkol 
Sarana Nutanong

dataset.provenance: Multiomics features (gene expression, gene mutation, DNA methylation, copy number variation) were obtained from renowned source Cancer Cell Line Encyclopedia (CCLE). Protein expression profiling is also concerned, aggregating 949 cancer cell lines covering 8,498 proteins across over 40 cancer types. It was taken from ProCan-DepMapSanger. For the dataset for drug combination, we sourced from the DrugComb database version 1.5. The parameter of interest is a continuous value from original, but later splitted into classes using threshold value for classification evaluation. Studies such as FRIEDMAN-Skin and ALMANAC were used to compile the dataset for anticancer drug combination data. These are conventional datasets particularly in AI of computational pharmaceutics.
dataset.splits:
The processed data for anticancer drug combinations across various datasets, including FRIEDMAN-Skin, ALMANAC-Breast, ALMANAC-Lung, ALMANAC-Ovary, and ALMANAC-Skin. For the FRIEDMAN-Skin dataset, 30,594 drug combinations involving 92 unique drugs were evaluated across 8 cancer cell lines. The ALMANAC-Breast dataset analyzed 13,266 drug combinations with 81 unique drugs across 4 cancer cell lines. Similarly, the ALMANAC-Lung dataset included 22,812 drug combinations involving 81 unique drugs tested on 7 cancer cell lines. The ALMANAC-Ovary dataset featured 13,188 drug combinations with 81 unique drugs across 4 cancer cell lines. Lastly, the ALMANAC-Skin dataset evaluated 12,084 drug combinations using 81 unique drugs on 4 cancer cell lines.

For the FRIEDMAN-Skin dataset, the distribution shows a total of 19,350 combinations with negative scores and 11,244 combinations with positive scores, resulting in a ratio of 0.632. In the ALMANAC-Breast dataset, there are 10,247 negative scores and 3,019 positive scores, with a higher ratio of 0.772. The ALMANAC-Lung dataset includes 17,643 negative scores and 5,172 positive scores, yielding a ratio of 0.773. The ALMANAC-Ovary dataset shows 10,546 negative scores and 2,642 positive scores, with a ratio of 0.800. Lastly, the ALMANAC-Skin dataset presents 9,695 negative scores and 2,390 positive scores, achieving the highest ratio of 0.802 among the datasets.
dataset.redundancy: During model training, we randomly partitioned the dataset into training and test sets using an 80:20 ratio with the random splitting method. Furthermore, we performed 5-fold cross-validation. We also separated the data with leave-drug-combinations-out to predict unseen drug combinations.
dataset.availability: Datasets and features for SynProtX can be retrieved from https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.13285494. All data contained under the CC0 license.

model.interpretability: The SynProtX model leveraging gradient-based and attention-weight strategies provide insights into relevant cancer-associated proteins and important chemical substructures that contribute to the model’s predictions, thus supporting its interpretability.
model.output: The SynProtX is a deep learning model, providing predictive performance based on classification and regression tasks.
model.duration: The SynProtX experiments were conducted on a high-performance computing cluster with a single NVIDIA Tesla V100 GPU. The hyperparameter tuning and model evaluation processes were efficiently optimized, executing time did not exceed three days for each experimental setting. The model evaluation was completed within a single day.
model.availability: The repository containing Python files to run SynProtX experiment and Jupyter notebooks that preprocess corresponding data can be retrieved from https://github.com/manbaritone/SynProtX. This project is licensed under the MIT license.

optimization.algorithm: SynProtX integrates gene and protein expression data with deep neural networks (DNNs) and molecular structure of drugs with graph neural networks (GNNs). We employed graph convolutional networks (GCN). graph attention networks (GAT), Attentive FP, and graph attention networks combined with molecular fingerprint (GATFP) to compare the learning processes of the molecular structure of drugs. We compared SOTA deep learning models including, DeepSynergy, DeepDDS, and AttenSyn, and also XGBoost to SynProtX.
optimization.meta: No, the SynProtX employed the raw experimental data from DrugComb, DepMap (CCLE), and ProCan-DepMapSanger.
optimization.config: Datasets, features, hyperparameters, and model checkpoints for SynProtX can be retrieved from https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.13285494. All data contained under the CC0 license. Furthermore, the settings of hyperparameters appear in the supporting information of the manuscript.
optimization.encoding: Our algorithm propagates data from two main input group: multi-omics and chemical representations. The multi-omics features are as originally is. Chemical representations are, in fact, generated from SMILES using RDKit helper tools.
optimization.features: The chemical structure of drugs was transformed into molecular fingerprints. The Extended Connectivity Fingerprint 6 (ECFP6), a 2048-bit fingerprint generated by processing the Morgan fingerprint with a radius of 3, was used. Feature selection was not conducted in this experiment.
optimization.fitting: In deep learning, it is common to have the number of parameters larger than the number of training points or the feature dimension. This phenomenon has probably led to overfitting. To prevent this, we applied dropout to the deep learning layers and improved generalization. We implemented an early stopping mechanism to prevent overfitting. We used a 5-fold cross-validation technique to ensure model robustness. In addition, we performed batch normalization to stabilize the training process, helping to prevent overfitting.
optimization.parameters: Number of parameters of our model are controlled by attributing hyperparameters such as number of layers, layer size, and number of attention heads, which were tuned using Bayesian optimization bundled in Python package Optuna. The number of parameters in general across models is 15 million.
optimization.regularization: To further improve the training process and prevent overfitting, we implemented an early stopping mechanism. This early stopping mechanism monitors the validation loss and stops the training process if the performance does not improve for a specified number of epochs.

evaluation.method: To ensure robustness and reliable model evaluation, we performed triplicated 5-fold cross-validation for model generation with different seed numbers independently. We also experimented with leave-drug-combinations-out validation to rigorously assess the generalizability of the SynProtX model in predicting unseen drug combinations.
evaluation.measure: For the classification, we used the Area Under the Receiver Operating Characteristic Curve (AUROC), Area Under the Precision-Recall Curve (AUCPR), Accuracy (ACC), Balanced Accuracy (BACC), F1 score (F1), and Cohen’s Kappa Coefficient (KAPPA). For the regression, we used the Root Mean Square Error (RMSE), Mean Absolute Error (MAE), Pearson Correlation Coefficient (PCC), Spearman’s Rank Correlation Coefficient (SCC), and Coefficient of Determination (R2).
evaluation.comparison: The study employed three advanced SOTA deep learning models including, DeepSynergy, DeepDDS, and AttenSyn to SynProtX with various experimental settings. In addition to these advanced models, we compared our models with classical algorithms such as XGBoost to establish a baseline.
evaluation.confidence: We calculated the mean and confidence interval (α = 0.05) of all results of model predictive performance.
evaluation.availability: The results of model predictive performance for all comparison models are available at GigaDB.

publication.title: Open RGB Imaging Workflow for Morphological and Morphometric Analysis of Fruits using AI: A Case Study on Almonds
publication.authors:
Jorge Mas-Gómez [0000-0002-3663-6743]
Manuel Rubio [0000-0003-4605-8227]
Federico Dicenta [0000-0002-7647-5235]
Pedro José Martínez-García* [0000-0002-7647-5235]

dataset.provenance:
The data were obtained through a direct experiment involving the acquisition of high-resolution photographs of almonds in two conditions: with shell and without shell. Each condition constitutes a separate dataset, and independent YOLO segmentation models were fine-tuned for each case, starting from pre-trained weights.

To increase the number of samples and improve the performance of the models, a slicing strategy was applied to the original images, generating smaller tiles (sub-images) with their corresponding object annotations.

This is not a classification or regression problem, but a segmentation/detection task with custom datasets. The number of annotated sliced images per dataset is:

Almonds with shell 2022: N = 1500
Almonds with shell 2023: N = 750

Almonds without shell 2022: N = 1080
Almonds without shell 2023: N = 501

These datasets were created specifically for this study and have not been previously used in any publication.
dataset.splits:
For all datasets, the data were split into training, validation, and external test sets. The standard split was:

60% for training

20% for validation

20% for external test

An exception was made for the “almonds with shell – 2022” dataset, which was split as follows:

75% training

12.5% validation

12.5% external test
dataset.redundancy: The datasets were split randomly at the image level. For each dataset studied (almonds with shell and without shell, across 2022 and 2023), individual images were randomly assigned to the training, validation, and test sets following the proportions previously described.
dataset.availability: No

model.interpretability: The YOLO segmentation model is considered a black-box, as its internal decision processes are not transparent. While it outputs interpretable masks, the underlying reasoning is not directly explainable.
model.output: The model is a segmentation model, which can be considered a pixel-wise classification task. Each pixel is classified into a category (e.g., object vs. background).
model.duration:
On a standard machine (Amazon EC2 P4d instance), a single prediction using the YOLO11s-seg model takes approximately:

117.6 ms on CPU (ONNX format)

2.9 ms on GPU (TensorRT with FP10)

These measurements are averaged over COCO validation images using batch size 1. https://docs.ultralytics.com/es/tasks/segment/#models
model.availability: Yes, the source code and the method to run the algorithm are publicly available. The workflow, including training and inference scripts, is released on GitHub. You can access it at https://github.com/jorgemasgomez/almondcv2/tree/main

optimization.algorithm:
The models used belong to the convolutional neural network (CNN) family, specifically designed for object detection and segmentation tasks. The chosen algorithm is YOLO (You Only Look Once), a well-established and widely used deep learning architecture for real-time object detection.

YOLO is not a new algorithm, but a mature and actively developed framework (e.g., YOLOv5, YOLOv8), known for its balance between speed and accuracy, especially when dealing with high-throughput image datasets such as those used in this study.
optimization.meta: No, the model does not use outputs of other ML algorithms as input. The model is fine-tuned starting from a pre-trained YOLO network, but training and inference are performed on a single unified model. No meta-predictors or ensemble inputs are involved.
optimization.config: Yes, the hyperparameter configurations, optimization schedule, model files, and optimization parameters are reported in the training configuration YAML file used for the YOLO11s-seg model. This includes details such as learning rate, batch size, epochs, weight decay, optimizer settings, data paths, augmentation parameters, and more. https://github.com/jorgemasgomez/almondcv2/tree/main/DOME
optimization.encoding: The input data consisted of high-resolution images of almonds, which were first sliced into smaller tiles, Depending on the dataset, the tiles were cut at either 320x320 pixels or 640x640 pixels, with an overlap of 20% (0.2) between adjacent tiles  Annotations were provided encoded in the YOLO segmentation format (normalized center coordinates and width/height relative to image dimensions) using CVAT labeling tool.
optimization.features:
The input features correspond to the raw pixel values of the image patches used for training. Depending on the dataset, the images were cut into patches of either 320×320 or 640×640 pixels with 20% overlap. Each pixel has 3 color channels (RGB), so the total number of input features per patch is:

For 320×320 images: 

320×320×3=307,200 features

For 640×640 images: 
640×640×3=1,228,800 features
optimization.fitting: In our case, the number of trainable parameters ppp (~10 million) is relatively large compared to the number of training images, and the input feature dimension fff (number of pixels per image patch × 3 channels) is also very high (over 300,000 for 320×320 patches).  To mitigate overfitting, we employed the following strategies: •	Use of pretrained YOLO11s-seg model with fine-tuning: Starting from a pretrained model helps leverage learned general features and reduces the risk of overfitting on the new dataset. •	Data splitting into training, validation, and test sets: This allows monitoring of model performance on unseen data to detect overfitting. •	Data augmentation and overlap in patch extraction: Applying augmentations and overlapping patches increases the effective dataset size and variability.
optimization.parameters:
The model used is YOLO11s-seg, a lightweight segmentation architecture from the YOLO family. The total number of trainable parameters is Total parameters (trainable + frozen): 10,082,675, as calculated from the fine-tuned models. 

This parameter count is inherent to the architecture and was not manually selected. The YOLO11s-seg model was chosen for its balance between computational efficiency and segmentation accuracy, suitable for the almond segmentation task.
optimization.regularization: Yes, several overfitting prevention techniques were applied during model training:  A validation set was used (val: true and split: val) to monitor performance and avoid overfitting. Weight decay (0.0005) was used as regularization to prevent overfitting.  Early stopping was enabled with a patience of 100 epochs (patience: 100), meaning training would stop if no improvement is seen for 100 epochs.  Data augmentation techniques were applied, including RandAugment (auto_augment: randaugment) and random erasing (erasing: 0.4), which increase data variability to help prevent overfitting.

evaluation.method: The method was evaluated by splitting the dataset into training, validation and external subsets,
evaluation.measure:
The reported performance metrics include:

Epoch number

Training losses: box loss, segmentation loss, classification loss, distribution focal loss (dfl loss)

Validation losses: box loss, segmentation loss, classification loss, distribution focal loss

Learning rates for different parameter groups (pg0, pg1, pg2)

Metrics on bounding boxes (B): precision, recall, mAP@50, mAP@50-95

Metrics on masks (M): precision, recall, mAP@50, mAP@50-95

Training time per epoch

This set of metrics is comprehensive and representative, as it includes both loss and detection/segmentation quality metrics commonly used in the literature for evaluating object detection and segmentation models. The use of mAP at multiple IoU thresholds (50 and 50-95) is a standard evaluation approach aligned with benchmarks like COCO.
evaluation.comparison: No, a direct comparison to publicly available methods on benchmark datasets was not performed. Likewise, comparisons to simpler baseline models were not conducted. The evaluation focused on assessing the model’s performance on the specific dataset split for this project.
evaluation.confidence: No, the reported performance metrics do not include confidence intervals.
evaluation.availability: Yes, performance metrics are here in supplementary material https://doi.org/10.1101/2025.05.05.652179

publication.title: PanGIA: A universal framework for identifying association between ncRNAs and diseases
publication.authors: Xiaoyuan Liu,1,† Xiye L¨u,1,† Qiuhao Chen,2 Tianyi Zhao 1,2,∗ and Yan Zhu3

dataset.provenance:
The raw data were collected from publicly available and well-established biological databases. miRNA–disease associations were obtained from HMDD v4.0, with sequence data from miRBase. lncRNA and circRNA associations were sourced from LncRNADisease v3.0, with circRNA sequences from circBase and lncRNA sequences from GENCODE and NONCODE. piRNA–disease associations were collected from piRDisease v1.0, and piRNA sequences from piRBase and piRNAdb. Disease terms were standardized using Disease Ontology (DOID) identifiers.

The dataset is structured as a binary classification task, where positive samples are known RNA–disease associations and negative samples are constructed using the spy technique. The total number of positive samples is in the tens of thousands, and negative samples are generated in equal size per fold during cross-validation. These databases are widely used and recognized in the ncRNA research community, although the exact combination and integration presented in this study is novel.
dataset.splits: Each fold of the dataset contains approximately 10,000 positive samples for training, along with an equal number of reliable negative samples selected using the spy technique. The test set in each fold includes around 3,000 positive samples and an equal number of randomly sampled negatives, resulting in roughly 6,000 test samples per fold. No separate validation set was used; all evaluation was performed using 5-fold cross-validation. The distributions of data types (RNA categories and disease classes) were kept consistent across folds through random stratified splitting. While data distribution plots were not included, care was taken to ensure balanced representation in both training and test sets.
dataset.redundancy: The dataset was randomly split using 5-fold cross-validation. For each fold, training and test sets were strictly separated with no overlapping RNA–disease pairs. This independence was enforced using binary mask matrices that explicitly define which entries are used for training or testing. No additional redundancy reduction (e.g., sequence similarity filtering) was performed. The distribution of positive and negative samples is consistent with previous studies in the ncRNA–disease association domain, and no significant imbalance or bias was observed.
dataset.availability: Yes. All datasets used in this study, including RNA and disease information, known associations, and the 5-fold cross-validation splits, are publicly available. The data will be archived and assigned a DOI in GigaDB upon publication. In addition, key data files and preprocessing scripts are available in the GitHub repository. All data will be shared under an open data license to ensure reusability and transparency.

model.interpretability: The model incorporates both black-box and interpretable components. While deep neural networks like HAN and MMoE are generally considered black-box models, our architecture allows for some interpretability. Specifically, the gating mechanisms in the Multi-gate Mixture-of-Experts (MMoE) reveal which expert networks are activated for each RNA type, offering insights into task-specific patterns. In addition, the cross-task attention weights highlight how different RNA types influence each other. These components provide interpretable signals that can be visualized and analyzed to better understand the learned biological relationships.
model.output: The model performs binary classification. For each RNA–disease pair, it predicts the probability of association, which is then thresholded to classify the pair as associated or not. The output is a score between 0 and 1 for each pair.
model.duration: A single forward pass to generate predictions for all RNA–disease pairs takes approximately 1 second on an NVIDIA A100 GPU. On a CPU, the same operation may take 15–30 seconds depending on matrix size. During training, each epoch takes around 8–12 seconds on A100. Generating predictions and saving ranked results for one fold takes less than 1 minute in total.
model.availability: Yes, the full source code is publicly available. It includes training, evaluation, and prediction scripts for the PanGIA model. However, no executable, web server, virtual machine, or container instance is currently provided. The source code is hosted on GitHub at https://github.com/qiankunzizairen/PanGIA and will also be archived in GigaDB upon publication. It is released under an OSI-compliant open-source license (e.g., MIT).

optimization.algorithm:
The algorithm belongs to the class of graph neural networks (GNNs) and multi-task learning architectures. Specifically, we use a Multi-gate Mixture-of-Experts (MMoE) framework combined with a Heterogeneous Graph Attention Network (HAN), designed to learn shared and task-specific representations across multiple RNA types (lncRNA, circRNA, miRNA, piRNA). While MMoE and HAN are existing models, this combination is novel in the context of heterogeneous ncRNA–disease association prediction.

We chose this architecture because it allows information sharing across related tasks while maintaining specialization through expert selection. Compared to single-task or flat GNN baselines (e.g., GCN, GAT), this structure improved performance and interpretability across all RNA types.
optimization.meta: No, the model does not use the outputs of other machine learning algorithms as input. All predictions are directly generated from the original input features (node attributes and edge structure) within a unified end-to-end architecture. There is no meta-predictor stage, and no stacking or ensembling of separate models was performed. The 5-fold cross-validation ensures strict separation between training and test data.
optimization.config: Yes. All hyperparameter configurations, optimization settings, and model files (including trained weights and training scripts) are publicly available in the GitHub repository and will be archived in GigaDB upon acceptance. The GitHub repository includes the training script with command-line arguments for hyperparameters, and configuration values are documented in the README. Trained model files (.pt) and cross-validation scores are included in the `scores/` directory. The code is released under an OSI-compliant open-source license (e.g., MIT or Apache 2.0).
optimization.encoding: The ncRNA–disease data were represented as a heterogeneous graph with multiple relation types (miRNA–disease, lncRNA–disease, circRNA–disease, piRNA–disease). Each node type (RNA, disease) was assigned initial feature vectors. For RNAs, one-hot encodings of sequence types or statistical features (e.g., k-mer counts) were used where applicable; for diseases, semantic embeddings derived from the DOID ontology were used. All features were normalized. The adjacency matrix was binarized (1 for known association, 0 otherwise), and reliable negative samples were generated using the spy technique. Masks were used to define training and test regions in the matrix.
optimization.features: Each RNA and disease node is represented by a fixed-length feature vector. For RNAs, the input feature dimension is typically 64 or 128 depending on configuration; for diseases, features were projected to the same dimension using a linear layer. In total, the feature dimension per node is f = 128. No explicit feature selection was performed. All features were retained and used as input. The input features were derived from domain knowledge (e.g., sequence encodings, ontology embeddings) and not learned from the training set alone.
optimization.fitting: Yes, the number of trainable parameters (p ≈ 1–2 million) is larger than the number of training points in each fold, and the feature dimension (f ≈ 128) is also relatively high. To reduce overfitting risk, we applied multiple strategies: dropout layers were used throughout the model (including attention and expert modules), early layers were regularized, and 5-fold cross-validation was used for evaluation. Additionally, no test data was used during training, and performance was monitored across folds to ensure consistency. The model showed stable generalization across folds, indicating overfitting was effectively controlled.
optimization.parameters: The model has approximately 1.2 to 2.0 million trainable parameters, depending on the chosen hidden dimensions, number of experts, and expert layer size. The total parameter count includes the HAN encoder, expert networks, gating layers, and attention modules. The values of hyperparameters (e.g., hidden_dim, expert_dim, num_experts, num_heads) were manually selected based on validation performance using 5-fold cross-validation. No exhaustive grid search was conducted; instead, we evaluated a small set of reasonable configurations based on prior work and model capacity considerations.
optimization.regularization: Yes, multiple regularization techniques were applied to prevent overfitting. Dropout layers were used in both the expert networks and attention modules. L2 regularization was applied implicitly via the optimizer. Additionally, the model’s multi-task structure (MMoE) encourages parameter sharing and reduces the risk of overfitting to any single RNA type. While early stopping was not explicitly applied, 5-fold cross-validation was used to evaluate generalization, and no test data was used during training.

evaluation.method: The method was evaluated using 5-fold cross-validation. Known RNA–disease associations were randomly partitioned into five folds, and in each run, one fold was used for testing while the remaining four were used for training. Reliable negative samples were constructed separately for each fold using the spy technique. No associations from the test set were used during training, ensuring strict separation. Evaluation metrics were averaged across all folds to assess generalization performance.
evaluation.measure: We report AUC (Area Under the ROC Curve), AUPR (Area Under the Precision-Recall Curve), and Ranking Index (RI) as performance metrics. These metrics are widely used in ncRNA–disease association prediction tasks and are well-suited for imbalanced binary classification problems. AUC and AUPR measure the classifier’s ability to distinguish positive and negative associations, while RI evaluates the ranking quality of predicted associations. This set of metrics is representative and consistent with standard practices in recent biomedical machine learning literature.
evaluation.comparison: Yes. The proposed method was compared against both publicly available methods and simpler baseline models using the same dataset and evaluation protocol. The comparisons were conducted using 5-fold cross-validation to ensure fairness and reproducibility. The results demonstrated that our model achieved superior performance across multiple metrics, confirming its effectiveness over existing alternatives.
evaluation.confidence: Performance metrics were averaged over 5-fold cross-validation, and standard deviations were reported to indicate variability. While formal confidence intervals were not computed, the observed performance improvements over baselines were consistent across all folds. This consistency suggests that the model's superiority is statistically meaningful, although no formal statistical significance tests (e.g., p-values) were conducted.
evaluation.availability: Yes. The raw evaluation outputs, including prediction scores, evaluation scripts, and fold-wise performance logs, are available in the GitHub repository and will be archived in GigaDB upon publication. The evaluation code includes metrics computation, result aggregation, and visualization tools. All resources are released under an OSI-compliant open-source license (e.g., MIT).

The evaluation code includes metrics computation, result aggregation, and visualization tools. All resources are released under an OSI-compliant open-source license (e.g., MIT).

publication.title: SEHI-PPI: An End-to-End Sampling-Enhanced Human-Influenza Protein-Protein Interaction Prediction Framework with Double-View Learning
publication.authors: Qiang Yang, Xiao Fan, Haiqing Zhao, Zhe Ma, Megan Stanifer, Jiang Bian, Marco Salemi, and Rui Yin

dataset.provenance:
1. The data is collected from publicly resources, containing human-influenza protein-protein interaction pairs experimentally validated.
2. The data is used for classification task where positive data and negative data are both 15,889.
3. The used data is recognized by the community, including BioGRID, EBI-GOA-nonIntAct, HCVpro, HPIDB, HVIDB, IntAct, VirusMINT, PHISTO, Viruses.STRING, VirHostNet, and VirusMentha.
dataset.splits: The data is randomly splitted into training, test, and validation set with the ratio of 7:2:1 to ensure the same distributions.
dataset.redundancy: There is no redundancy between data splits.
dataset.availability: The used dataset is accessible by the Github repository https://github.com/UF-HOBI-Yin-Lab/SEHI-PPI with the CC0 license.

model.interpretability: The model is black box.
model.duration: The average running time for one epoch is approximate 71.64s on a A100 GPU node.
model.availability: The source is release in https://github.com/UF-HOBI-Yin-Lab/SEHI-PPI/tree/main/Codes.

optimization.algorithm:
1. We proposed a novel deep learning model which combines the double-viewed of protein sequence data, i.e., local-view and global view features.
2. The compared methods are competitive.
optimization.meta: Our model SEHI-PPI used the pretrained language model ProtBERT to get the initial embeddings of k-mers. It is clear that there is no prediction task for ProtBERT in our task.
optimization.config: All hyperparameter configurations, optimization schedule, model files and optimization parameters are reported in the https://github.com/UF-HOBI-Yin-Lab/SEHI-PPI/blob/main/Codes/utils/config_single.py.
optimization.encoding: Protein sequences then segmented into K-mers and encoded using pre-trained protein language models (ProtBERT) to create sequential and graph-based representations.
optimization.features: The dimension of features is 1024, coming from ProtBERT.
optimization.fitting: We use the early stop strategy to avoid the overfitting problem. If the F1 score in validation set does not improve more than 20 epochs, we will stop the training.
optimization.parameters: The total number of parameters in our model are 8,732,066. They come from the neural networks including Graph Neural Network and Long Short-Term Memory netwokr.
optimization.regularization: Early stopping using a validation set and weight decay.

evaluation.method: The method is evaluated with five-fold cross-validation.
evaluation.measure: We used six metrics, accuracy, F1-score, sensitivity, specificity, AUROC, and Matthew’s correlation coefficient, which are widely used in the task.
evaluation.comparison: We compare our model with publicly available methods performed on our collected dataset, including CNNLSTM, HGCN, DSSGNN, HIGH, ect. We also perform the simpler baselines, i.e., traditional machine learning methods, like SVM, Decision Tree, XGBoost, etc.
evaluation.confidence: We reported the results with mean values and standard deviation .

publication.title: An Interpretable Graph-Regularized Optimal Transport Framework for Diagonal Single-Cell Integrative Analysis
publication.authors: Zexuan Wang, Qipeng Zhan, Shu Yang, Zhuoping Zhou, Mengyuan Kan,Tianhuan Zhai and Li Shen

dataset.provenance:
We evaluated our method on four widely used, gold-standard multi-omics benchmarks:

scGEM – Jointly profiles gene expression and DNA methylation, covering 177 cells × 34 gene-expression features and 177 cells × 27 methylation features.

SNARE-seq – Links chromatin accessibility to gene expression, producing an ATAC matrix of 1,047 cells × 19 peaks and an RNA matrix of 1,047 cells × 10 genes.

PBMC 10X (Dataset 1) – Human peripheral blood mononuclear cells, comprising 9,378 cells with 130,417 scATAC peaks and 15,417 scRNA genes.

PBMC 10X (Dataset 2) – A complementary PBMC set with 11,259 cells, 28,307 scATAC peaks, and 11,942 scRNA genes.

We also evaluated our method on four Simulated benchmarks:

Simulation 1 – Branch manifold
2-D branching structure embedded into 1,000-Dimension with 300 points.

Simulation 2 – Swiss-roll manifold
3-D Swiss roll embedded into 2,000-Dimension with 300 points.

Simulation 3 – Circular frustum manifold
3-D frustum embedded into 1,000-Dimension with 300 points.

Simulation 4 – Splatter RNA-seq
Synthetic scRNA-seq counts (5,000 cells; 50 or 500 genes).
dataset.splits:
Consistent with prior literature, we evaluate the entire dataset without creating separate train/test splits. GROTIA is assessed in two modes:

Semi-supervised – hyper-parameters are tuned with the aid of cell-type labels.

Fully unsupervised – hyper-parameters are tuned solely by minimizing the model’s loss function, with no label information used.
dataset.redundancy:
Consistent with prior literature, we evaluate the entire dataset without creating separate train/test splits. GROTIA is assessed in two modes:

Semi-supervised – hyper-parameters are tuned with the aid of cell-type labels.

Fully unsupervised – hyper-parameters are tuned solely by minimizing the model’s loss function, with no label information used.
dataset.availability:
Yes, all the datasets are publicly available. 

Simulation 1 – https://rsinghlab.github.io/SCOT/data/
Simulation 2 – https://rsinghlab.github.io/SCOT/data/
Simulation 3 – https://rsinghlab.github.io/SCOT/data/
Simulation 4 – https://rsinghlab.github.io/SCOT/data/
SNAREseq – https://rsinghlab.github.io/SCOT/data/
scGEM – https://rsinghlab.github.io/SCOT/data/
PBMC 1 – https://figshare.com/s/ff75c0bfecd89468dc8d?file=44698216
PBMC 2 – https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/1AH1h2zDnuowdV3gSm2RjDgmPfHgmsk7I

model.interpretability: Yes, it is interpretable. We compute partial derivatives of the RBF kernel embeddings with respect to each gene’s expression and then weight these by the projection matrix to obtain a contribution score for every gene–dimension pair. Ranking these scores identifies dimension-specific “signature genes”—those whose expression changes most strongly reposition cells in the low-dimensional space.
model.duration: It is 15 minutes for a 10k points dataset.
model.availability: Yes, it is publicly available (https://github.com/PennShenLab/GROTIA).

optimization.algorithm: Yes, GROTIA is a novel algorithm. It performs global alignment with optimal transport while preserving local structure through graph regularization, delivering superior accuracy with high computational efficiency.
optimization.config: Yes, it is in the github under MIT license
optimization.encoding: All datasets were pre-processed following the protocols detailed in their original publications.
optimization.features: The PCA (dimension 50) result of the pre-processed data has been used as input. No feature selection is performed.
optimization.fitting: No, it is not.
optimization.parameters:
Our model has just three hyper-parameters:

Latent dimension d – we use 5 or 8 and find GROTIA is robust to either choice.

Nearest neighbours k – fixed at 5 to build the graph Laplacian that preserves local structure.

Loss weights p and q –

p balances the two modalities (searched over {1, 0.1, 0.01, 0.001}).

q strengthens local-geometry preservation (searched over {1 × 10⁻³, 10⁻⁴, 10⁻⁵, 10⁻⁶}).

We keep p > q so that local structure is maintained while still achieving good cross-modal alignment.
optimization.regularization: Training employs early stopping: if the loss fails to improve for 50 consecutive epochs, optimization terminates.

evaluation.method: The method was assessed in two distinct evaluation modes, each paired with two quantitative metrics across eight datasets.
evaluation.measure: We report FOSCTTM and label-transfer accuracy (LTA) because together they capture the two complementary aspects of multimodal alignment emphasized in recent literature. FOSCTTM is a pairwise metric: it asks whether each individual cell’s true counterpart in the other modality is indeed its nearest neighbour in the joint space, providing a fine-grained measure of geometric alignment that is sensitive to global distortions. LTA, in contrast, is a group-level metric: it checks how well discrete biological labels propagate across modalities, reflecting the preservation of local neighbourhood structure that underlies downstream analyses such as clustering or trajectory inference. hese two metrics are standard in state-of-the-art studies on single-cell alignment (e.g. SCOT, UNIPORT) and are widely regarded as jointly representative of alignment quality.
evaluation.comparison: The method is compared to six advanced methods.
evaluation.confidence: No, they don't.

publication.title: PanGIA: A universal framework for identifying association between ncRNAs and diseases
publication.authors: Xiaoyuan Liu,1,† Xiye L¨u,1,† Qiuhao Chen,2 Tianyi Zhao 1,2,∗ and Yan Zhu3

dataset.provenance:
The raw data were collected from publicly available and well-established biological databases. miRNA–disease associations were obtained from HMDD v4.0, with sequence data from miRBase. lncRNA and circRNA associations were sourced from LncRNADisease v3.0, with circRNA sequences from circBase and lncRNA sequences from GENCODE and NONCODE. piRNA–disease associations were collected from piRDisease v1.0, and piRNA sequences from piRBase and piRNAdb. Disease terms were standardized using Disease Ontology (DOID) identifiers.

The dataset is structured as a binary classification task, where positive samples are known RNA–disease associations and negative samples are constructed using the spy technique. The total number of positive samples is in the tens of thousands, and negative samples are generated in equal size per fold during cross-validation. These databases are widely used and recognized in the ncRNA research community, although the exact combination and integration presented in this study is novel.
dataset.splits: Each fold of the dataset contains approximately 10,000 positive samples for training, along with an equal number of reliable negative samples selected using the spy technique. The test set in each fold includes around 3,000 positive samples and an equal number of randomly sampled negatives, resulting in roughly 6,000 test samples per fold. No separate validation set was used; all evaluation was performed using 5-fold cross-validation. The distributions of data types (RNA categories and disease classes) were kept consistent across folds through random stratified splitting. While data distribution plots were not included, care was taken to ensure balanced representation in both training and test sets.
dataset.redundancy: The dataset was randomly split using 5-fold cross-validation. For each fold, training and test sets were strictly separated with no overlapping RNA–disease pairs. This independence was enforced using binary mask matrices that explicitly define which entries are used for training or testing. No additional redundancy reduction (e.g., sequence similarity filtering) was performed. The distribution of positive and negative samples is consistent with previous studies in the ncRNA–disease association domain, and no significant imbalance or bias was observed.
dataset.availability: Yes. All datasets used in this study, including RNA and disease information, known associations, and the 5-fold cross-validation splits, are publicly available. The data will be archived and assigned a DOI in GigaDB upon publication. In addition, key data files and preprocessing scripts are available in the GitHub repository. All data will be shared under an open data license to ensure reusability and transparency.

model.interpretability: The model incorporates both black-box and interpretable components. While deep neural networks like HAN and MMoE are generally considered black-box models, our architecture allows for some interpretability. Specifically, the gating mechanisms in the Multi-gate Mixture-of-Experts (MMoE) reveal which expert networks are activated for each RNA type, offering insights into task-specific patterns. In addition, the cross-task attention weights highlight how different RNA types influence each other. These components provide interpretable signals that can be visualized and analyzed to better understand the learned biological relationships.
model.output: The model performs binary classification. For each RNA–disease pair, it predicts the probability of association, which is then thresholded to classify the pair as associated or not. The output is a score between 0 and 1 for each pair.
model.duration: A single forward pass to generate predictions for all RNA–disease pairs takes approximately 1 second on an NVIDIA A100 GPU. On a CPU, the same operation may take 15–30 seconds depending on matrix size. During training, each epoch takes around 8–12 seconds on A100. Generating predictions and saving ranked results for one fold takes less than 1 minute in total.
model.availability: Yes, the full source code is publicly available. It includes training, evaluation, and prediction scripts for the PanGIA model. However, no executable, web server, virtual machine, or container instance is currently provided. The source code is hosted on GitHub at https://github.com/qiankunzizairen/PanGIA and will also be archived in GigaDB upon publication. It is released under an OSI-compliant open-source license (e.g., MIT).

optimization.algorithm:
The algorithm belongs to the class of graph neural networks (GNNs) and multi-task learning architectures. Specifically, we use a Multi-gate Mixture-of-Experts (MMoE) framework combined with a Heterogeneous Graph Attention Network (HAN), designed to learn shared and task-specific representations across multiple RNA types (lncRNA, circRNA, miRNA, piRNA). While MMoE and HAN are existing models, this combination is novel in the context of heterogeneous ncRNA–disease association prediction.

We chose this architecture because it allows information sharing across related tasks while maintaining specialization through expert selection. Compared to single-task or flat GNN baselines (e.g., GCN, GAT), this structure improved performance and interpretability across all RNA types.
optimization.meta: No, the model does not use the outputs of other machine learning algorithms as input. All predictions are directly generated from the original input features (node attributes and edge structure) within a unified end-to-end architecture. There is no meta-predictor stage, and no stacking or ensembling of separate models was performed. The 5-fold cross-validation ensures strict separation between training and test data.
optimization.config: Yes. All hyperparameter configurations, optimization settings, and model files (including trained weights and training scripts) are publicly available in the GitHub repository and will be archived in GigaDB upon acceptance. The GitHub repository includes the training script with command-line arguments for hyperparameters, and configuration values are documented in the README. Trained model files (.pt) and cross-validation scores are included in the `scores/` directory. The code is released under an OSI-compliant open-source license (e.g., MIT or Apache 2.0).
optimization.encoding: The ncRNA–disease data were represented as a heterogeneous graph with multiple relation types (miRNA–disease, lncRNA–disease, circRNA–disease, piRNA–disease). Each node type (RNA, disease) was assigned initial feature vectors. For RNAs, one-hot encodings of sequence types or statistical features (e.g., k-mer counts) were used where applicable; for diseases, semantic embeddings derived from the DOID ontology were used. All features were normalized. The adjacency matrix was binarized (1 for known association, 0 otherwise), and reliable negative samples were generated using the spy technique. Masks were used to define training and test regions in the matrix.
optimization.features: Each RNA and disease node is represented by a fixed-length feature vector. For RNAs, the input feature dimension is typically 64 or 128 depending on configuration; for diseases, features were projected to the same dimension using a linear layer. In total, the feature dimension per node is f = 128. No explicit feature selection was performed. All features were retained and used as input. The input features were derived from domain knowledge (e.g., sequence encodings, ontology embeddings) and not learned from the training set alone.
optimization.fitting: Yes, the number of trainable parameters (p ≈ 1–2 million) is larger than the number of training points in each fold, and the feature dimension (f ≈ 128) is also relatively high. To reduce overfitting risk, we applied multiple strategies: dropout layers were used throughout the model (including attention and expert modules), early layers were regularized, and 5-fold cross-validation was used for evaluation. Additionally, no test data was used during training, and performance was monitored across folds to ensure consistency. The model showed stable generalization across folds, indicating overfitting was effectively controlled.
optimization.parameters: The model has approximately 1.2 to 2.0 million trainable parameters, depending on the chosen hidden dimensions, number of experts, and expert layer size. The total parameter count includes the HAN encoder, expert networks, gating layers, and attention modules. The values of hyperparameters (e.g., hidden_dim, expert_dim, num_experts, num_heads) were manually selected based on validation performance using 5-fold cross-validation. No exhaustive grid search was conducted; instead, we evaluated a small set of reasonable configurations based on prior work and model capacity considerations.
optimization.regularization: Yes, multiple regularization techniques were applied to prevent overfitting. Dropout layers were used in both the expert networks and attention modules. L2 regularization was applied implicitly via the optimizer. Additionally, the model’s multi-task structure (MMoE) encourages parameter sharing and reduces the risk of overfitting to any single RNA type. While early stopping was not explicitly applied, 5-fold cross-validation was used to evaluate generalization, and no test data was used during training.

evaluation.method: The method was evaluated using 5-fold cross-validation. Known RNA–disease associations were randomly partitioned into five folds, and in each run, one fold was used for testing while the remaining four were used for training. Reliable negative samples were constructed separately for each fold using the spy technique. No associations from the test set were used during training, ensuring strict separation. Evaluation metrics were averaged across all folds to assess generalization performance.
evaluation.measure: We report AUC (Area Under the ROC Curve), AUPR (Area Under the Precision-Recall Curve), and Ranking Index (RI) as performance metrics. These metrics are widely used in ncRNA–disease association prediction tasks and are well-suited for imbalanced binary classification problems. AUC and AUPR measure the classifier’s ability to distinguish positive and negative associations, while RI evaluates the ranking quality of predicted associations. This set of metrics is representative and consistent with standard practices in recent biomedical machine learning literature.
evaluation.comparison: Yes. The proposed method was compared against both publicly available methods and simpler baseline models using the same dataset and evaluation protocol. The comparisons were conducted using 5-fold cross-validation to ensure fairness and reproducibility. The results demonstrated that our model achieved superior performance across multiple metrics, confirming its effectiveness over existing alternatives.
evaluation.confidence: Performance metrics were averaged over 5-fold cross-validation, and standard deviations were reported to indicate variability. While formal confidence intervals were not computed, the observed performance improvements over baselines were consistent across all folds. This consistency suggests that the model's superiority is statistically meaningful, although no formal statistical significance tests (e.g., p-values) were conducted.
evaluation.availability: Yes. The raw evaluation outputs, including prediction scores, evaluation scripts, and fold-wise performance logs, are available in the GitHub repository and will be archived in GigaDB upon publication. The evaluation code includes metrics computation, result aggregation, and visualization tools. All resources are released under an OSI-compliant open-source license (e.g., MIT).

publication.title: High-precision machine learning identifies a reproducible functional connectivity signature of autism spectrum diagnosis in a subset of individuals
publication.authors: Natasha Clarke, Sebastian Urchs, Hien Duy Nguyen, Clara Moreau, Christian Dansereau, Angela Tam, Alan C. Evans, Lune Bellec

dataset.provenance:
The data were sourced from the ABIDE I and ABIDE II publicly available datasets, which aggregate resting-state fMRI and phenotypic data from individuals with autism spectrum diagnosis (ASD) and neurotypical controls (NTC) across multiple international sites. These datasets are widely recognized and have been used extensively in the neuroimaging and ML communities.

After preprocessing and quality control, the final discovery (training) dataset included 452 males (226 ASD, 226 NTC) from 10 imaging sites. The independent validation dataset included 424 males (212 ASD, 212 NTC) from 16 sites. All individuals were matched on age and head motion using propensity score matching.
dataset.splits:
The training set (discovery sample) consisted of 452 individuals (226 ASD, 226 NTC), and the independent validation set included 424 individuals (212 ASD, 212 NTC). These sets are completely non-overlapping and drawn from different ABIDE dataset releases (ABIDE I for training; ABIDE II for validation).

Key confounds (age and motion) were matched using propensity score matching within each site to ensure comparable groups. Summary statistics and cohort characteristics are presented in the manuscript (e.g., flowcharts in Figure 5 and 6), though full distributions are not plotted. In figure 3 we show that the model's predictions are not significantly correlated with key confounds.
dataset.redundancy: The training (ABIDE I) and validation (ABIDE II) sets are fully independent, with no participant overlap. Independence was ensured by using separate dataset releases. Bootstrapping was confined to the training set for model development, while the validation set remained strictly held out. This design improves upon common ABIDE ML practices that risk leakage via random splits of a single dataset.
dataset.availability: All data used in the study are released on Zenodo (https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.15706115), including the training (ABIDE 1) and validation (ABIDE II) data splits found in Data.zip. License: Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International (CC BY-NC-SA 4.0)

model.interpretability: The model is interpretable. The conformal prediction framework provides a confidence score for each prediction (i.e., how “unusual” an individual is with respect to ASD and NTC reference groups), which allows users to understand not just the classification, but how certain the model is in making that prediction. Furthermore, we report the FC signature derived from the model that is associated with identification of the ASD group, providing a neurobiologically meaningful basis for the predictions.
model.duration: A single prediction takes seconds on a standard machine. However, the full analysis involves extensive bootstrap resampling (100 iterations × 18 networks) and per-subject conformal predictions, which substantially increases total runtime. These procedures required parallel execution on a high-performance computing cluster and span several weeks to months depending on resource allocation.
model.availability: All source code used in the analysis is publicly available at https://github.com/SIMEXP/autism-signature under the MIT license. Apptainer and Docker images for full reproducibility are also archived on Zenodo (https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.15706115).

optimization.algorithm: We used transductive conformal prediction (TCP) combined with logistic regression as the ML framework. TCP is not a standard inductive learning algorithm but a transductive method that produces confidence measures for individual predictions. This approach was chosen to ensure high-confidence, low false-positive predictions of autism diagnosis, prioritizing specificity over sensitivity. Unlike traditional classifiers, TCP assesses conformity of each test instance to known classes, allowing predictions only when confident. This novelty aligns with the clinical goal of identifying a high-risk autism signature with strong precision.
optimization.meta: The model uses features derived from a hierarchical clustering algorithm performed on the training data to identify FC subtypes. These subtype similarity scores serve as input features for the logistic regression classifier within the conformal prediction framework. The clustering is conducted solely on the training data to ensure independence of the test/unclassified individuals. Therefore, the training of initial predictors (clustering + logistic regression) and the classification of test data remain independent, avoiding data leakage.
optimization.config: All configurations, settings, and model generation code are publicly available in the GitHub repository (https://github.com/SIMEXP/autism-signature) under MIT license. Containerized environments (autism-signature.sif and autism-signature.tar.gz) are included in the Zenodo archive (https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.15706115) under the same license and ensure full reproducibility of the pipeline.
optimization.encoding: Functional connectivity (FC) was computed using a seed-to-voxel approach. For each of the 18 MIST atlas networks (excluding cerebellar networks due to coverage limitations), the average time series was extracted and Pearson’s correlation coefficients were calculated between this time series and the time series of all non-cerebellar voxels in the brain. To mitigate confounding effects we performed ordinary least squares regression to remove variance associated with age and head motion parameters from the FC maps, retaining the residuals for analysis. For dimensionality reduction, we applied hierarchical agglomerative clustering to FC maps across the discovery cohort, identifying five FC subtypes. The final input features consisted of each subject's spatial similarity to the five subtype centroids (per network).
optimization.features: The five subtype centroids defined via hierarchical clustering were used as input features. Feature selection was performed separately for each of the 18 networks, resulting in a 5-dimensional feature space per network, and conducted on the discovery data only (ABIDE 1).
optimization.fitting: Both p and f are small compared to the number of training samples, mitigating the risk of overfitting. Overfitting was further controlled by bootstrap resampling to assess model stability, and use of the transductive approach, which reduces overfitting to the training set since there's no global model to overfit. Both over- and underfitting were further addressed by validating performance on an independent dataset.
optimization.parameters: The logistic regression within the conformal prediction framework involved two key parameters: (1) the ASD class weight (w = 10^16), which heavily penalizes false positives to prioritize specificity, and (2) the conformal rejection threshold (5%), which selects only high-confidence predictions. These were empirically chosen to align with the clinical goal of reliable ASD identification. Standard binomial logistic regression without additional regularization was used (no L1/L2 penalties or C parameter), as the focus was on conformal prediction scoring rather than optimizing inductive model parameters.
optimization.regularization: No explicit regularization techniques or early stopping was applied.

evaluation.method: The method was evaluated using bootstrap resampling (100 iterations) on the discovery dataset (ABIDE 1), and independently validated on an unseen dataset (ABIDE 2).
evaluation.measure: The study reports six key metrics: sensitivity (recall), specificity, positive predictive value (PPV), risk ratio (RR), odds ratio (OR), and the Sørensen-Dice coefficient. This set is representative of neuroimaging-based diagnostic literature, but by focusing on the PPV goes beyond standard accuracy which, even when high, translates to low PPVs in the general population.
evaluation.comparison: While a direct benchmarking comparison on the same dataset with other publicly available methods was not performed, our model’s performance was compared against published results from similar datasets in the literature. These comparisons demonstrate that our FC signature achieves a substantially higher positive predictive value (PPV) and risk increase for ASD than existing neuroimaging models, and outperforms the current state-of-the-art in ensemble methods.
evaluation.confidence: While formal confidence intervals are not reported, performance metrics are derived from the conformal prediction framework, which inherently provides confidence in predictions and uses statistical significance in its classification decisions. However, statistical superiority over other methods and baselines was not tested.
evaluation.availability: All raw evaluation files are available in Results.zip, archived on Zenodo (https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.15706115) under CC-BY-NC-SA license.

publication.title: HeteroMRI: Robust white matter abnormality classification across multi-scanner MRI data
publication.authors: Masoud Abedi, Navid Shekarchizadeh, Pierre-Louis Bazin, Nico Scherf, Julia Lier, Christa-Caroline Bergner, Wolfgang Köhler, and Toralf Kirsten

dataset.provenance:
The input data are MRI images. The MRI images are obtained from published datasets which are publicly available or are accessible on request to the respective dataset providers.
In total, Npos= 232 and Nneg=132. However, in different experimental settings, the model is always trained with balanced data.
dataset.splits: The project includes different experimental settings. In each setting, the number of data points (MRI images) is different. For example in setting A of the paper, 174 (87 pos+87 neg) MRI images are used for training, 26 (13 pos+13 neg) images for validation, and 44 (22 pos+22 neg) images are used for testing the model. In every data shuffle, the data was split randomly, ensuring random distribution of data in the training, validation, and test sets.
dataset.redundancy: In every data shuffle, the necessary number of data for training, validation, and test was selected randomly from the available data. The training, validation, and test sets are completely independent. Also, we have a hold-out test set.
dataset.availability: All the MRI images used in this study are either publicly available or are accessible upon request to the respective dataset providers. The number of images used from each dataset in the training, validation, and test sets is reported in the supplementary material of the paper. The list of MRI image IDs from used from each dataset is reported in the GitHub repository of HeteroMRI (https://github.com/ul-mds/HeteroMRI)

model.interpretability: The model is a convolutional neural network and it is black box.
model.duration: On a normal laptop with at least 8 GB of RAM, the preprocessing of an MRI image takes 20 to 35 mins (depending on the size of the image and the laptop hardware configuration) and the prediction by the model takes around 6 seconds.
model.availability: Yes, the source code and the docker file is publicly available under https://github.com/ul-mds/HeteroMRI with GPL-3.0 license.  The user should install and implement the method on his own machine or HPC resources.

optimization.algorithm: The ML algorithm within HeteroMRI method is a 3D convolutional neural network (CNN). The model architecture is not completely new. It is taken from another research paper and adapted it to our clinical MRI data. Later, in our paper, the model is trained and evaluated only with public MRI data. The Adam optimizer is used in the model.
optimization.config: The complete source code (including all the hyperparameter parameters and optimization parameters used) for implementing our method is published under https://github.com/ul-mds/HeteroMRI. The trained model files are not published due to their significant number and total size.
optimization.encoding: The MRI images were preprocessed using the FlexiMRIprep pipeline (https://github.com/ul-mds/FlexiMRIprep). The applied preprocessing steps are: Bias field correction, 3-times nonlinear registration to MNI template,  extracting the white-matter of the brain, and clustering the white-matter into 3 intensity clusters. Only one intensity cluster of the white matter per MRI is thresholded and used for the model.
optimization.features: While the input data is image, the features are automatically extracted by the convolutional neural network in each layer. There are five 3D Convolution layers in the model with 64, 64, 128, 128, and 256 filters (number of feature maps) respectively.
optimization.fitting: Yes, p is much larger than the number of training points. To address the risk of overfitting, we applied several measures: We performed training and evaluation over 50 independent random splits of the data and reported the average results. This robust resampling strategy reduces the likelihood of overfitting to a specific subset and demonstrates model stability and generalizability. In addition, the overfitting prevention techniques mentioned in the next question are employed.
optimization.parameters: The convolutional neural network has 1,795,905 parameters. The architecture of the model is taken from another research paper and we adapted and redesigned it to our clinical MRI data to achieve an acceptable performance of the model. Later, in our paper, the model is trained and evaluated only with public MRI data.
optimization.regularization: In the convolutional neural network, a dropout layer with a 30% rate is used to prevent overfitting. Moreover, an Early Stopping feature (patience=40) is employed in the model in order to monitor the validation loss in each epoch.

evaluation.method: In each experiment, an independent part of the dataset was used for evaluating the method. We performed training and evaluation over 50 independent random splits of the data and reported the average results. Moreover, the method was evaluated on a hold-out dataset.
evaluation.measure:
Accuracy, sensitivity, specificity, F1 score, precision, AUROC, and MLcps are reported. Moreover, permutation test results are reported.
The metrics are the common metrics used for evaluating classification models.
evaluation.comparison: We found no other model in the literature that directly performs the similar task of HeteroMRI. However, we compared the results with publicly available lesion segmentation models by binerizing their output.
evaluation.confidence: The confidence interval of the performance metrics are reported as standard deviation values of every average value. In addition, the metrics are reported by means of box plots which show the distribution of metrics values over different data shuffles and runs.  For statistical significance, permutation tests are performed and results are reported as jittered points in the accuracy box plots.
evaluation.availability: The high number of experimental settings, data splits, repeated runs of each split, and the number of permutations result in thousands of raw evaluation excel sheets in which the results of each trained model and the IDs of the used data are reported. Therefore, only the overall results are reported in the paper but not the raw files. The list of subject IDs of the MRI data used from the public datasets is published in the GitHub repository under https://github.com/ul-mds/HeteroMRI

publication.title: CryoDataBot: a pipeline to curate cryoEM datasets for AI-driven structural biology
publication.authors:
Z. Hong Zhou
Qibo Xu
Leon Wu
Michael Rebelo
Shi Feng
Xinye Yu
Harhana Harheen
Daisuke Kihara

dataset.provenance:
The dataset used by CryoDataBot was compiled from publicly accessible cryo-electron microscopy databases, including the Electron Microscopy Data Bank (EMDB) and Protein Data Bank (PDB), supplemented by atomic models from peer-reviewed publications.

Total for the point in each class:
        Label-0: 13650927191
        Label-1: 264684349
        Label-2: 105272253
        Label-3: 260789461
        Label-4: 537589210
        Total: 14819262464
dataset.splits:
We use 42,060*64*64*64 data points for training and a separate 10,516*64*64*64 data points for validation.

A total of 20 cryoEM maps were used as the independent test set. Each map was subdivided into 3D subvolumes of size 64×64×64, enabling voxel-level evaluation.
dataset.availability: Yes. The metadate of each dataset are uploaded to GigaScience private User DropBox area, which will be release after the publication of the paper. And the raw data can be downloaded from publicly accessible cryo-electron microscopy databases EMDB with the metadate.

model.interpretability: The 19-layer 3D U-Net model used in CryoDataBot is partially interpretable. While deep learning models like U-Net are inherently complex, the outputs and intermediate activations offer useful insights:  Segmentation Masks: The model generates 3D segmentation maps of biomolecular structures which can be directly visualized and overlaid on cryoEM density maps, making predictions interpretable for structural biologists.  Voxel-level Confidence Scores: Output channels provide probability values for each voxel, allowing users to assess prediction certainty.  Feature Map Analysis: Intermediate convolutional layers can be visualized to understand which regions and patterns the model focuses on.  Comparative Validation: Predicted structures can be compared with ground truth atomic models using RMSD and FSC scores, supporting model interpretability through quantitative metrics.  These examples demonstrate that while the model’s internal logic may be non-transparent, its behavior and predictions can be meaningfully interpreted and evaluated in practical applications.
model.duration:
The time varies among different input size of cryoEM map.

Using NVIDIA RTX 4090, the whole process for an input of a large size cryoEM map with 440A*440A*440A is ~50s.
The prediction part will cost 15s and the rest time is spent on data normalization, output data generation, and so on.
model.availability: Yes and yes. The source code of CryoDataBot is available at https://github.com/t00shadow/CryoDataBot under the MIT license.

optimization.algorithm:
In the testing of CryoDataBot-generated dataset, we utilizes supervised deep learning algorithms, primarily based on convolutional neural networks (CNNs). Specifically, it integrates U-Net architectures.

The U-Net is not new but tailored for 3D cryoEM map segmentation and feature recognition.
optimization.config: Yes. The hyperparameter configurations, optimization schedule are in method part of the submitted paper. The model files have been uploaded to GigaScience private User DropBox area, which will be release after the publication of the paper.
optimization.encoding: Map Normalization: Cryo-EM density maps were normalized to a consistent voxel intensity range to eliminate dataset-dependent variance and facilitate model convergence.  Resampling & Voxel Size Standardization: All maps were resampled to a fixed voxel size (e.g., 1 Å/voxel) to ensure spatial consistency across inputs.  Segmentation & Label Encoding: Atomic models were converted into labeled volumetric masks. Each atom type or residue class was encoded using categorical encoding schemes suitable for the supervised learning tasks.  Input Format Transformation: CryoEM maps were formatted as 3D tensors (e.g., N × 64 × 64 × 64) compatible with deep learning frameworks such as PyTorch.
optimization.features: One. No.
optimization.fitting: We have used two groups of training set (control and experimental), including multi voxel files of size 64*64*64 (~260,000). Experimental training dataset contains ~50,000 voxel files, including 1e10 training points, which is much larger than the number of ps. We verified that the model did not underfit by ensuring convergence in training and strong performance on held-out validation data.
optimization.parameters: We used a 19-layer 3D U-Net models, including a total number of params as 90,298,821.
optimization.regularization: Batch normalization and early stopping using a validation set

evaluation.method: Independent dataset
evaluation.measure: F1 score, precision and recall. Yes.
evaluation.comparison: The U-Net model is for testing the dataset.
evaluation.confidence: No.
evaluation.availability: Evaluation files are not currently available, but they will be released upon publication under an open-source license (MIT or Apache 2.0) via GitHub.

publication.title: Using synthetic RNA to benchmark poly(A) length inference from direct RNA sequencing
publication.authors: Jessie J-Y Chang, Xuan Yang, Haotian Teng,  Jianshu Zhang, Benjamin Reames, Shuxin Zhang, Vincent Corbin, Lachlan Coin

dataset.provenance:
Training data for BoostNano  consists of nanopore signal data as well as hand annotated  segmentation, which we generated by direct experiment.
reported in this  paper https://doi.org/10.1093/gigascience/giaa002 .  This is reported in this BioProject: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/bioproject/PRJNA307517.      
The segmentation of a subset of these reads is available here https://github.com/haotianteng/BoostNano/tree/master/training_data.  
2186 reads were used as training data.  A further , 1165 reads were used as test data.

Validation data:
The validation dataset used for all 4 algorithms  is also a direct experiment. This dataset has been used in another publication (DOI: 10.1016/j.celrep.2021.109108).  It is reported in a different bioproject  (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/bioproject/PRJNA675370).  There is no overlap between the two projects.
dataset.splits:
2186 reads used as training data. 1165 used as internal test data from one experiment 

A completely different experiment , utilising synthetic RNA was used for validation of BoostNano as well as three other algorithms. This validation dataset  had
dataset.redundancy: The validation dataset was completely independent from any dataset used to train the various algorithm we tested.  This consisted of 57827 reads.
dataset.availability:
Training data set https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/bioproject/PRJNA307517  and https://github.com/haotianteng/BoostNano  (annotation)
Validation data set https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/bioproject/PRJNA675370

The annotation for training set is Mozilla Public license v2.0.  The sequence data is public domain (NCBI)

Scripts available here : https://doi.org/10.26188/c.7767503.v1

model.interpretability: Black box
model.duration: BoostNano requires 122 milliseconds to process each sequencing read.
model.availability: https://github.com/haotianteng/BoostNano

optimization.algorithm: For BoostNano we used deep learning CNN+RNN+CTC neural network structure. This is a well known structure and has been used previously for modelling nanopore signal data.
optimization.config: No
optimization.encoding: fast5 and pod5
optimization.features: The neural network does not use features. Rather it is an end-to-end model for the raw electrical nanopore signal data.
optimization.fitting: The parameter size is certainly much larger than the number of samples used for training.   A test set (as described) was used to assess level of overfitting.
optimization.parameters: BoostNano is a neural network and has 13 layers.
optimization.regularization: To avoid over-fitting the model was trained in multiple epochs.

evaluation.method: Independent dataset from novel experiments. Validation dataset was experimentally created after the training was completed
evaluation.measure: Distribution of PolyA tail length compared to the designed experiment and time efficiency between the various algorithm.
evaluation.comparison:
The manuscript is about comparing several methods, including BoostNano, TailfindR(https://github.com/adnaniazi/tailfindr ) , Dorado( https://github.com/nanoporetech/dorado ,) 
 Nanopolish (https://github.com/jts/nanopolish).   Tailfindr has been widely used and is the de-facto method for this analysis.
evaluation.confidence: We are using distribution of PolyA tails between multiple methods. The full distribution of results are shown.  We don't claim a method is clearly superior than others regarding polyA tails estimation. For time efficiency, the result is clear.
evaluation.availability: Yes, distribution of polyA tails for all methods are have been uploaded to GigaScience server (user282@files.gigadb.org

publication.title: DRIP: Dimensionality reduction informs polygenic risk scoring
publication.authors:
Hadasa Kaufman
Yarden Hochenberg
Michal Linial
Nadav Rappoport
publication.doi:
GIGA-D-25-00270
 DRIP: Dimensionality reduction informs polygenic risk scoring

dataset.provenance: UK biobank
dataset.splits:
Over all, we had 487,409 samples and 93,095,623 imputed SNPs from the imputation data analyzed and provided by the UKB. 
After filtering we had 341,985 samples and 467,429 SNPs.
For the 5 repetitions, we randomly separate the data into an 85% training set and a 25% test set 5 times. 1000 samples from the training set were taken out for the validation set. 289,688 samples for the training set, 51,297 for the test set, and 1,000 for the validation set. 
We didn't plot the distributions of the validation and the test sets for each phenotype and repetition, but for the common phenotypes, we can see high consistency between the repetitions, and we can assume that there is no bias between the training and the test distrebutions.
dataset.redundancy:
The split was random, and the training, test, and validation sets are independent. 
We removed family-related samples.
All the pre-processing analysis was done by accepted protocols for using the UKB.
dataset.availability:
No. Due to privecy.
The original data can be found in the UKB : https://www.ukbiobank.ac.uk/

model.interpretability: We are not tring to interpert the model. We compare our model performence to alternative models.
model.output: We did both classification and regression analysis for binary and continuous phenotypes, respectively.
model.duration: The running times for DNN were the longest and could take 5 days on a GPU. For linear/logistic regression, the running times were around 5 hours. The running times of the complete recommended method (PCA+LR) are reported in the paper.
model.availability: The code is avilable on GitHub: https://github.com/nadavlab/DRIP

optimization.algorithm:
We tried XGBoost, linear/logistic regression, and a Deep neural network.
We chose this because we want to examine whether non-linear learning improves the performances.
optimization.meta:
At the first stage of the analysis (after pre-processing), we used principal component analysis (PCA) and an autoencoder.
The meta-predictor and the predictor based on dimensionality reduction (PCA/autoencoder)were independent
optimization.config: All the hyperparameters are reported at the manuscript and the codes are avilable at the github: https://github.com/nadavlab/DRIP.
optimization.encoding: Pre-processing Quality control was implemented on participants and SNPs using the PLINK2 tool[18].
