SNP quality control was performed by eliminating variants with duplicate IDs, those with missing values (geno = 0, keeping only genotyped SNPs with a dosage of 0, 1, or 2), variants that deviated from Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium (HWE) by p-value <1e-6, and variants with minor allele frequency (MAF) <0.001. SNP quality control operations were carried out in the default PLINK2 order. Family-related subjects were eliminated using the in-house protocol[35]. In addition, we used subjects of European ancestry to minimize the effects of population structure, which can fade some of the phenotype-related genetic signal[36]. Note that approximately 6% from the UKB population are of a non‑European ethnicity. The age covariate was min-max normalized to range between zero and one. SNPs were coded as 0, 1, 2 for homozygous for the alternative allele, hetero-, and homozygous for the reference allele, respectively, assuming additive allele effects. To create 5 repetitions, the samples were randomly split into an 85% training set and a 15% test set. For each repetition, 1,000 random samples were taken from the training set to serve as the validation set. Overall, the DRIP method is based on dimensionality reduction (DR) of genomic data and the subsequent use of a learning prediction model algorithm. Reducing the number of features For the first stage of DRIP method, we examine two unsupervised approaches for DR, Principal Component Analysis (PCA) and Autoencoder. Principal component analysis (PCA). We trained PCA on the SNP data using the Scikit-learn Python package[37]. Due to existing resource limits, we trained separate dimensionality reduction models on the training data for each of the 22 chromosomes for all the SNPs (for the five repetitions, using autosomal chromosomes) for the dimensionality reduction process. Such a large dataset in high dimensions could not be loaded into memory at once. Therefore, we split the data into 1,000 samples each. We used iterative algorithms, meaning the model was updated based on a batch of 1,000 samples in each iteration. The first 10% of the principal components were the features used in DRIP’s second stage. Autoencoder. As an additional, non-linear methods for unsupervised DR, we used a deep-autoencoder. We trained a fully connected autoencoder model with the TensorFlow Python package[38]. The autoencoder was trained for each chromosome separately. The network was designed as an encoder with two hidden layers, with the second layer being the feature compression layer (bottleneck) and a decoder with one hidden layer. We chose to add dropout layers to prevent overfitting. This technique is known for its ability to efficiently combine different neural network architectures[39]. Each hidden layer had a dropout layer with a rate of 0.1, except for the bottleneck. The number of neurons in each hidden layer was 20%, 10%, and 20% of the input SNP number, respectively. We performed hyperparameter tuning using the validation set for the activation functions and for the learning rate, where the best configuration was chosen according to the root mean square error (RMSE) metric that measures the average magnitude of prediction errors. As hyperparameter tuning is a resource-intensive task, which takes long run times, we performed the tuning on chromosome 22 and used optimal hyperparameters for the other chromosomes. We trained our model using the Adam Optimizer[40] and the mean squared error (MSE) loss function with a batch size of 250 over 500 epochs. The chosen activation functions were PReLU[41] for the hidden layers and linear for the output layer, and the best learning rate was 1e-5.  The model training was performed using a single RTX6000 GPU and 58 GB of RAM. The evaluation of conserved information of DR was performed as mentioned above. The bottleneck, which contained 10% neurons relative to the original number of SNPs, was used as features to the learning models. In addition, we compare the unsupervised DR to GWAS based supervised SNP selection. Supervised SNP selection. Based on the GWAS results, we calculated for each phenotype a threshold for the 10% lowest p-values. The thresholds were 0.096< p <0.0173 for all phenotypes. SNPs with lower p-values than the thresholds were used as features for the prediction models.
optimization.features:
We used for each of the models: %10 of the features of the original number of SNPs as a rule of thumb for the comparison, which we found in PCA that saved 70% of the explained variance. 46,743 SNPs. In addition, we added 170 standard covariates: sex, age, assessment_centre, genotype_measurement_batch, and 40 PCs.
The 10% features for all the compared methods (PCA, autoencoder, and GWAS-based SNP selection) were chosen based on the training set only.
optimization.fitting: No
optimization.parameters:
In the regression models, we had 46,914 parameters. 
In the DNN and XGB, we didn't evaluate the number of parameters, but the XGB and network structure are detailed in the manuscript.
optimization.regularization: To get a fair comparison, we did not use an early stop mechanism.

evaluation.method: We used a validation test to evaluate all the methods. For each method, we randomly separate the data into training, test, and validation 5 times, and the standard deviation was calculated.
evaluation.measure: Yes. We compare our method to a variety of poligenic risk score methods.
evaluation.comparison: No, 'e do not have access to a parallel database.
evaluation.confidence: The standard deviation is calculated and the significance of the results is discussed.
evaluation.availability: The files are not avilable due to privecy but results can be reproduced using the UKB dataset.

publication.title: Nanopore- and AI-empowered microbial viability inference
publication.authors: Harika Ürel, Sabrina Benassou, Hanna Marti, Tim Reska, Ela Sauerborn, Yuri Pinheiro Alves De Souza, Albert Perlas, Enrique Rayo, Michael Biggel, Stefan Kesselheim, Nicole Borel, Edward J. Martin, Constanza B. Venegas,  Michael Schloter, Kathrin Schröder, Jana Mittelstrass, Simone Prospero, James M. Ferguson,  Lara Urban

dataset.provenance:
We generated raw nanopore signal data to create 'dead' and 'alive' classes for each of the following conditions: UV-treated Escherichia coli, UV-treated Chlamydia suis, antibiotic-treated E. coli alone (no mock community), and an antibiotic-treated quasi-mock community containing E. coli and Klebsiella oxytoca.
We cultured E. coli K12 in 200 mL Luria-Bertani (LB) medium for 24 hours at 37°C to reach the log phase of the growth curve. The culture was then used to inoculate four 200 mL LB media in 1L Erlenmeyer flasks, which were again incubated for 24 hours to reach the growth log phase. One of the media was used as viable control, i.e. DNA was extracted from 750 uL of the living culture using the spin-column based QIAGEN PowerSoil Pro Kit (QIAGEN, 2018, Hilden, Germany), following the manufacturers’ instructions. The remaining three cultures were killed by one of the following stressors: UV irradiation at 254 nm for 15 min, heat shock at 120°C for 5 min, or bead beating for 30 min. To then separate extracellular DNA from cell debris and intact bacterial cells, we centrifuged the media for 10 min at 4,000 x g and filtered the supernatant through 0.2 µm filters. The resulting extracellular DNA was subsequently kept at room temperature for 5 days to simulate the natural accumulation of DNA degradation. DNA from dead bacteria was extracted from these samples using the same extraction approach following the QIAGEN PowerSoil Pro Kit protocol, but the first lysis buffer step was omitted since cell lysis had already happened. 
We then used Oxford Nanopore Technologies’ Rapid Barcoding library preparation kit (RBK114-24 V14), R10.4.1 MinION flow cells, and MinKNOW software v23.04.5 for shotgun nanopore sequencing of the “viable” and “dead” DNA. We used four barcodes for each sample, resulting in DNA input of 800 ng and 218 ng for the preparation of the “viable” and “dead” library, respectively. We ran each library for 24 h, using two different flow cells to avoid any cross contamination, and filtered the resulting nanopore data at a minimum read length of 20 b. Raw nanopore data was created using the standard translocation speed of 400 b/s, and a sampling frequency of 5 kHz.
We applied Dorado v4.2.0 (https://github.com/nanoporetech/dorado) SUP-basecalling (dna_r10.4.1_e8.2_400bps_sup@v4.2.0) and 6mA-aware SUP-basecalling (6mA@v1) to all nanopore reads that had passed internal data quality thresholds to obtain E. coli DNA sequence data. We subsequently removed sequencing adapters and barcodes using Porechop v0.2.3 (https://github.com/rrwick/Porechop). The Chlamydia suis strain S45 (kindly provided by J. Storz, Baton Rouge, LA, USA) was cultured as described by Leonard et al. [55]. Briefly, chlamydiae were grown in the epithelial rhesus monkey kidney cell line LLM-MK2 (provided by IZSLER, Brescia, Italy) and prepared as semi-purified stock by scraping infected cells into the supernatant and removal of cellular debris by centrifugation at 500 g for 10 min. Chlamydiae were then pelleted (10’000 x g, 45 min) and resuspended in sucrose phosphate glutamate buffer (SPG). To determine the viability of this stock, one aliquot was thawed on ice and separated into two tubes of which one was UV-inactivated using a Hoefer UVC 500 Ultraviolet Crosslinker (Hoefer Inc., Bridgewater MA 02324, United States): Briefly, samples were kept on ice and exposed to 8 watts of UV light at 12.5 cm for 30 min, similar to previously described protocols [56]. All samples were prepared in biological duplicates. UV-inactivated chlamydia were then further incubated at room temperature for 48 h prior to further processing, while viable chlamydiae were immediately processed. The resulting four samples were divided into subsamples and used for cultivation, vPCR, and nanopore sequencing. 
For viability determination by culture, subsamples (approximately 1e7 IFU) were used to infect four glass coverslips (13 mm in diameter, ThermoScientific, Waltham, MA, USA) in 24-well plates (TPP Techno Plastic Product AG, Trasadingen, Switzerland) seeded to confluence with LLC-MK2 cells [57]. For the “viable” subsamples, a 1:1000 dilution was performed prior to inoculation. The infection was then enhanced by centrifugation for 1 h at 25°C (1000 x g). After 48 h of incubation at 37°C (5% CO₂), cultures were fixed for 10 min in ice-cold methanol. If cultures were free of chlamydiae, one well was scraped and transferred to fresh monolayers up to three times to confirm negativity as described [58]. Coverslips were then processed using a well-established immunofluorescence assay [59]. Briefly, DNA was stained with 1 μg/mL 4', 6-diamidino-2’-phenylindole dihydrochloride (DAPI, Molecular Probes, Eugene, OR, USA). In parallel, inclusions were labeled with a Chlamydiaceae-specific primary antibody (Chlamydiaceae LPS, Clone ACI-P; Progen, Germany), which was diluted 1:200  in blocking solution consisting of 1% bovine serum albumin (BSA, St. Louis, MO, USA) in phosphate-buffered saline (PBS, GIBCO, Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA, USA). Inclusions were visualized with Alexa Fluor 488 goat anti-mouse (Molecular Probes) diluted 1:500 in blocking solution. As a final step, coverslips were washed with PBS, mounted with FluoreGuard (Hard Set; ScyTek Laboratories Inc., Logan, UT, USA) on glass slides, and inclusions determined using a Leica DMLB fluorescence microscope (Leica Microsystems, Wetzlar, Germany) and a 10X ocular objective (Leica L-Plan 10x/ 25 M, Leica Microsystems). In parallel, a three-fold dilution series of the sample was performed in 96-well plates (TPP) and processed as above. The number of IFU/ml for the whole samples was then calculated based on the number of inclusions detected using the Nikon Ti Eclipse epifluorescence microscope (Nikon, Tokyo, Japan) at a 20X magnification [57].
For vPCR, subsamples (approximately 2e7 IFU) were taken and mixed with 200 µl SPG and 100 µl PMA enhancer for Gram Negative Bacteria (5X, Biotium, Fremont, CA, USA). PMAxx (Biotium) at a final concentration of 50 µM was added (“PMA-treated”) or not (“untreated”) to the subsamples. Samples were then exposed to a 650-W light source using a PMA-Lite LED Photolysis Device (Biotium) for 5 min, followed by 2 min on ice and additional light exposure for 5 min [48]. For vPCR as well as nanopore sequencing (subsamples with approximately 5e8 IFU), DNA was extracted using the DNeasy® Blood and Tissue Kit (QIAGEN, Hilden, Germany) according to the manufacturer’s instructions. The amount of chlamydial DNA was quantified with a sensitive C. suis qPCR [60], based on a standard curve with recombinant plasmid containing the amplicon target and calculated for the whole sample. For subsequent nanopore sequencing of the DNA extracts (viable: 13–16 ng/μL; dead: 1.9–2.8 ng/μL), we followed the same approach as described for E. coli above. Each viable sample was sequenced using one barcode (input volume of 10 μL) and each dead sample using three barcodes (input volume of 30 μL). Sequencing reads were processed following the same steps used for the E. coli dataset. Chimeric reads were identified using the 'pi' tag added by Dorado and removed with the pysam Python package. Adapter and barcode trimming was performed using Porechop, and taxonomic classification was conducted with Kraken2 v2.1.4, retaining only reads classified as Chlamydia. 
To generate data from a simple mock community, a carbenicillin-susceptible E. coli strain and an ESBL-producing Klebsiella oxytoca strain (ATCC 700324) were cultured on Müller-Hinton (MH) agar at 37 °C for 20 hours in two biological replicates. Susceptibility to penicillin as an approximation of carbenicillin resistance was confirmed by VITEK2 and growth curve analysis at 100 and 200 ng/μL. Species identity was confirmed by MALDI-TOF MS and MLST. Cultures were inoculated at OD600 = 0.01 in 10 mL MH broth and incubated for 5 hours. Carbenicillin (200 ng/μL) was added during logarithmic growth, followed by 20 hours of further incubation. DNA was extracted directly from 250 μL of uncentrifuged culture using the same DNA extraction approach as described for UV-exposed E. coli. 
To generate clean training data for an antibiotic exposure-specific model, two biological replicates of the same E. coli strain were used. For the viable samples,  DNA was extracted from centrifuged pellets (4000 × g, 10 min) before antibiotic treatment, respectively. For the dead samples, DNA was extracted from the filtered supernatant (0.2 μm) 20 hours after carbenicillin exposure using the same DNA extraction approach as described for UV-exposed E. coli. Nanopore sequencing and data processing were done as described for E. coli above.
To train ResNet model with UV-treated Escherichia coli, raw nanopore signals were segmented into chunks of 10,000 data points to create balanced 'dead' and 'alive' datasets, resulting in 1,940,000 chunks per class. These were split into training (1,164,000 chunks per class), validation (388,000), and test (388,000) sets, following a 60%-20%-20% ratio.
For read-level inference analysis, we used the original reads corresponding to the test set chunks. After excluding chimeric reads and those not mapped to the Escherichia genus by Kraken2, the final test set included 59,171 'alive' reads and 72,207 'dead' reads. An independent read-level dataset was also prepared from UV-treated Chlamydia suis to evaluate the UV-E. coli model, using the same preprocessing steps (exclusion of chimeric reads and reads unmapped to the genus level). This dataset included two barcodes per class, totaling 54,853 'alive' reads and 23,073 'dead' reads. The UV-E. coli model was further evaluated on two biological replicates (BR1 and BR2) of a quasi-mock community comprising carbenicillin-susceptible Escherichia coli and carbenicillin-resistant Klebsiella oxytoca. After preprocessing, the dataset included 479,494 'dead' E. coli reads and 1,945,621 'alive' K. oxytoca reads.
To train a ResNet model on antibiotic-treated, filtered Escherichia coli (non-mock community), raw nanopore signals were segmented into chunks of 5,000 data points to create balanced 'dead' and 'alive' datasets, yielding 275,000 chunks per class. The data were split into training (165,000 chunks per class), validation (55,000 per class), and test (55,000 per class) sets, following a 60%-20%-20% ratio. For read-level inference, the antibiotic-treated E. coli model was tested using the full reads that contributed to test set chunks. After mapping the chunks back to their originating reads, the test set comprised 5,218 'alive' reads and 44,563 'dead' reads. Additionally, the model was evaluated on a held-out, biological replicate of E. coli (non-mock community), yielding 273,896 'dead' reads and 1,639,456 'alive' reads. Finally, the model was also evaluated on the antibiotic-treated quasi-mock community that was mentioned before.
This data has not been previously used by any other research.
dataset.splits: To train ResNet model with UV-treated Escherichia coli, raw nanopore signals were segmented into chunks of 10,000 data points to create balanced 'dead' and 'alive' datasets, resulting in 1,940,000 chunks per class. These were split into training (1,164,000 chunks per class), validation (388,000), and test (388,000) sets, following a 60%-20%-20% ratio. To train a ResNet model on antibiotic-treated, filtered Escherichia coli (non-mock community), raw nanopore signals were segmented into chunks of 5,000 data points to create balanced 'dead' and 'alive' datasets, yielding 275,000 chunks per class. The data were split into training (165,000 chunks per class), validation (55,000 per class), and test (55,000 per class) sets, following a 60%-20%-20% ratio.
dataset.redundancy:
Raw nanopore sequencing data were segmented into fixed-length signal chunks—10,000 data points for the ResNet model trained on UV-treated Escherichia coli and 5,000 for the model trained on antibiotic-treated E. coli. To avoid information leakage, training, validation, and test set splits were performed along read boundaries, ensuring that chunks from the same read did not appear in multiple sets. For the UV-treated E. coli model, 1,940,000 chunks per class ('dead' and 'alive') were generated and split into training (1,164,000), validation (388,000), and test (388,000) sets following a 60%-20%-20% ratio. For the antibiotic-treated, filtered E. coli dataset (non-mock community), 275,000 chunks per class were produced using the same methodology and split into training (165,000), validation (55,000), and test (55,000) sets, again using a 60%-20%-20% ratio.
We did not use redundancy reduction measures based on pairwise identity.
dataset.availability: The complete dataset, including all raw nanopore signal data, has been made publicly available via Squidbase under accession number SQB000009 and ENA (study accession number: PRJEB76420). Data preprocessing, dataset splitting, model training and evaluation can be replicated using publicly available scripts available at: https://github.com/harikaurel/Squiggle4Viability.

model.interpretability: The model is interpretable due to the use of Class Activation Maps (CAMs) as an Explainable AI (XAI) method. CAMs were implemented to highlight the most important regions in the nanopore signal data that inform the model's binary classifications. By visualizing these regions, it was observed that certain "dead" signal chunks exhibited discrete areas with high CAM values. This indicates the presence of patterns that the model relies on for making predictions. When consecutive masking was applied to these regions with the highest CAM values, we confirmed that the prediction probability decreased. Additionally, a simplified XAI rule based on the presence of sudden drops in the signal was developed, which maintained a good overall performance, albeit with a reduction in recall compared to the full model (Fig. 2).
model.duration: A single representative prediction using our model takes approximately 0.04 seconds on a standard machine.
model.availability: All computational code is available here: https://github.com/Genomics4OneHealth/Squiggle4Viability.git.

optimization.algorithm: We used a 1D-ResNet-based binary classifier for this study due to its effectiveness in capturing both short-term and long-term dependencies in 1-dimensional time series data, which is crucial for analyzing nanopore signals.
optimization.meta: No, the model does not use data from other ML algorithms as input. It solely relies on raw nanopore signal data and does not involve any meta-prediction processes. Before training begins, the model's weights are initialized randomly, and it is then trained from scratch using our signals. The test data is only used during the evaluation phase to assess the performance of the model’s performance.
optimization.config: The hyperparameter configurations, optimization schedule, and other relevant parameters are reported in the supplementary material of the paper. Detailed information on the learning rates, model architectures, and performance metrics across various configurations is provided. For example, learning rates of 1e-3, 1e-4, and 1e-5 were tested for different model architectures, as shown in the loss plots (Fig. S1). The complete set of performance metrics, including accuracy, F1 score, sensitivity, and specificity for each configuration, is shown in Table S1. The code and model configurations are publicly available on the GitHub repository (https://github.com/Genomics4OneHealth/Squiggle4Viability.git). The repository includes scripts for data processing, model training, and evaluation.
optimization.encoding: The raw nanopore signals were preprocessed using median absolute deviation (MAD) normalization to handle outliers effectively: Each sequencing read was cut into chunks of 10,000 signals, which were then normalized by subtracting the median and dividing by the MAD. The resulting values were then scaled by the MAD factor of 1.4826. Outliers exceeding 3.5 times the scaled MAD were replaced by the mean of their two neighboring values.
optimization.features: To standardize input length for model training, raw nanopore signals were segmented into fixed size chunks (10,000 data points for the UV model and 5,000 data points for the antibiotic model), which served as the input features. No additional feature selection was performed.For inference, however, the full signal from each read was used without chunking.
optimization.fitting: No. The number of model parameters (p = 66,916) is substantially smaller than the number of training samples in both models. For the UV model, 1,164,000 signal chunks per class were used for training, and for the antibiotic model, 165,000 chunks per class.
optimization.parameters: Model selection was guided by monitoring training and validation loss curves. The optimal set of parameters was chosen at the point where validation loss was minimized and accuracy maximized, while the training loss was still getting smaller.
optimization.regularization: Batch normalization was used after each convolutional layer to stabilize learning and reduce internal covariate shifts, which can have an indirect regularizing effect by introducing slight noise to the batch inputs. Additionally, we monitored the training and validation loss throughout the process to ensure the model was not overfitting.

evaluation.method:
We first trained a model on UV-killed Escherichia coli and evaluated its generalizability on an independent dataset of UV-treated Chlamydia suis, where it achieved strong performance. We also tested the same model on an antibiotic-treated quasi-mock community containing carbenicillin-susceptible E. coli and resistant Klebsiella oxytoca, but performance dropped significantly.

To address this, we trained a second model on antibiotic-treated E. coli, with 'dead' DNA extracted from filtered supernatants and 'alive' DNA from centrifuged pellets. This model was evaluated on a held-out biological replicate processed identically, confirming its reliability. We further tested it on the same quasi-mock community as above (unfiltered in this case), and the model still performed well.
evaluation.measure: We report accuracy, F1 score, precision, sensitivity, specificity, AUROC (Area Under the Receiver Operating Characteristic Curve), and AUPR (Area Under the Precision-Recall Curve). These performance measures are standard in machine learning literature.
evaluation.comparison: At present, no publicly available method exists for direct comparison with our approach. However, we evaluated the performance of our model against several alternative deep learning architectures, including different ResNet and Transformer architectures, as well as baseline models such as logistic regression using read length and translocation speed as input features.
evaluation.confidence: While, we do not provide confidence intervals of performance metrics at this point due to computational restraints, but we are happy to run (nested) cross-validation or similar if needed. There is no established method that we can compare our approach to. We use the Standard Error of the Mean (SEM) to calculate the 95% confidence interval during CAM masking experiments for interpretability analysis. This was done to evaluate the effect of masking highly activated CAM on prediction probabilities.
evaluation.availability: Our Github repository (https://github.com/Genomics4OneHealth/Squiggle4Viability.git) contains code for calculating performance metrics, and generating confusion matrices.

publication.title: PrediLnc: A Platform for disseminating lncRNA-disease associations
publication.authors: Udit, Shruti Kaushal, Dhvani S. Vora, Shashank Yadav, Jaspreet Kaur Dhanjal

dataset.provenance:
The dataset used in GARNET was constructed from several reputable and publicly available biomedical sources. Experimentally verified lncRNA–disease associations were obtained from LncRNADisease v3.0, while lncRNA sequence data were sourced from the NCBI nucleotide repository. Disease semantic information was extracted using ontology identifiers from the European Bioinformatics Institute (EBI), with semantic similarity scores calculated using the doSIM function in R. lncRNA–target associations were integrated from NPInter v4.0, and disease–gene associations were derived from the DISEASES database.

After comprehensive filtering and mapping, the curated dataset consisted of 4365 lncRNAs, 467 diseases, and 13,335 gene-derived entities (including protein, miRNA, and mRNA targets). A total of 4579 positive lncRNA–disease associations were included. An equal number of negative samples were constructed by randomly pairing lncRNAs and diseases with no known evidence of association, resulting in a balanced binary classification dataset of 9398 data points. These datasets are widely recognized in the biomedical community and have been employed in several prior studies on lncRNA–disease association prediction.
dataset.splits:
To evaluate the performance of the proposed model, we employed stratified 5-fold cross-validation on the complete dataset of 9398 samples. This approach ensured an even distribution of positive (known lncRNA–disease associations) and negative (randomly generated, non-associated) samples in each fold. In every iteration, 80% of the data was used for training and 20% for testing. Stratification was explicitly applied to maintain class balance across all folds, reflecting the overall distribution in both training and test subsets.

A separate static validation set was not used outside the cross-validation framework. Instead, model selection, hyperparameter tuning, and evaluation were all performed within the cross-validation loop, a standard practice when working with balanced but limited datasets.

While we did not perform formal statistical tests on feature distribution across splits, we carried out extensive exploratory data analysis using similarity matrices and visualizations. Heatmaps of k-mer frequencies, Levenshtein distances, disease semantic similarity, gene–gene interaction profiles, and other associations were examined to confirm the diversity and consistency of features across subsets. These visual checks helped ensure that data distributions were well-represented and structurally preserved within each fold.
dataset.redundancy:
The dataset was partitioned using stratified 5-fold cross-validation, and each fold was independently constructed to prevent data leakage between training and test sets. Specifically, no known lncRNA–disease association used for training was allowed to appear in the test set of the same fold. This ensured that test predictions were based solely on unseen examples.

Although we did not apply explicit sequence-level redundancy reduction such as limiting pairwise identity between lncRNAs or between diseases, careful curation was conducted to exclude duplicate entries and entities lacking key information (such as sequences or ontology identifiers). Furthermore, sequence similarity-based features (k-mer, Levenshtein) and ontology-based measures (semantic similarity) were included in the feature space to help the model learn nuanced relationships while preserving representation diversity.

The distribution of data and association types in our dataset is comparable to other published LDA (lncRNA–disease association) machine learning datasets. However, unlike many earlier studies, our model integrates multiple layers of biological information and incorporates both sequence-level and semantic data, which enhances the richness and reliability of the training and evaluation pipeline.
dataset.availability:
Yes, the complete dataset used in this study—including the constructed lncRNA–disease associations, lncRNA sequences, disease ontology annotations, and all data splits used during cross-validation—will be made publicly available via a dedicated GitHub repository upon acceptance of the manuscript. The repository will be hosted under an open-source MIT License, allowing unrestricted reuse and extension by the research community.

In addition to the raw and processed data, the repository will include detailed instructions for replicating our preprocessing steps, model training, and evaluation procedures. Furthermore, our web server PrediLnc, which implements the GARNET architecture, provides real-time access to model predictions and supports user-uploaded queries for novel lncRNA or disease inputs. This ensures that both the dataset and the model remain transparent and accessible for future use and validation.

model.interpretability: GARNET is primarily a black-box model due to its use of graph neural networks, attention layers, and ensemble learning. However, partial interpretability is achieved through the attention mechanism, which assigns weights to node interactions, revealing which neighbors (e.g., lncRNAs or diseases) most influence a given prediction. Additionally, feature importance from the Random Forest meta-classifier offers insight into which base model outputs most affect the final decision.
model.output: The model performs binary classification, predicting whether a given lncRNA–disease pair is likely to be associated or not. Each prediction outputs a probability score, which is then thresholded to assign a class label (positive or negative association).
model.duration: A single representative prediction using GARNET requires under 30 seconds on a standard desktop machine with GPU support (e.g., NVIDIA RTX 3060). The lightweight structure of the trained model and optimized inference pipeline ensures fast response times, as also demonstrated in the PrediLnc web server.
model.availability: Yes, the full source code, trained model, and data preprocessing scripts will be made publicly available on GitHub under the MIT License. Additionally, GARNET is deployed as part of the PrediLnc web server, enabling real-time prediction of top lncRNA–disease associations.

optimization.algorithm: GARNET (Graph convolution Attention RNA Network using stack ensemble to predict LncRNA-disease associations) is a hybrid model that integrates graph convolutional networks (GCNs), self-attention mechanisms, and a stack ensemble classifier. While GCNs and attention layers are established techniques, their combination with biological graph structures and ensemble-based prediction is novel in the lncRNA–disease prediction domain. This architecture was chosen to leverage both topological and semantic signals while addressing bias from uneven data distributions.
optimization.meta: Yes, GARNET uses a two-stage architecture. The outputs from five base classifiers—Logistic Regression, SVM, Random Forest, Gradient Boosting, and MLP—are used as inputs to a Random Forest meta-model. Stratified 5-fold cross-validation ensures that training and testing data are separated for both base learners and the meta-model, preserving data independence throughout the pipeline.
optimization.config: Yes, the full model configuration—including the GCN architecture, autoencoder setup, training loop, optimization parameters, and hyperparameter settings—will be released on GitHub upon publication. The repository will be openly licensed (MIT License) and include all scripts, datasets, and usage instructions for full reproducibility.
optimization.encoding: Data encoding includes k-mer frequency and Levenshtein distance for sequence features, disease semantic similarity from ontology graphs, and multiple biological associations. These features were concatenated into a high-dimensional matrix, reduced to 512-dimensional vectors using autoencoders. The resulting node features were embedded into a graph, passed through a GCN with two convolutional layers and a global self-attention layer, enabling rich, context-aware embeddings for downstream classification.
optimization.features: Initially, each sample included over 13,000 features derived from sequence similarity, semantic similarity, and association matrices. Autoencoders reduced these to 512 features per entity (lncRNA or disease). No manual feature selection was applied post-reduction; the encoder learned compressed representations solely from the training data.
optimization.fitting: The feature count (f = 512) and number of parameters were controlled using autoencoders and careful network design. With 9398 labeled samples and moderate model complexity, the architecture avoids overfitting. Regularization techniques, dropout, batch normalization, and 5-fold cross-validation further reduce overfitting risks. Underfitting was also ruled out by maintaining sufficient model capacity and consistently high classification performance across folds.
optimization.parameters: The model includes parameters from the autoencoder, two GCN layers, a self-attention layer, five base classifiers, and a Random Forest meta-classifier. While the total parameter count is architecture-dependent, dimensionality was fixed at 512 neurons for hidden layers. Parameter selection was guided through empirical testing and performance evaluation via cross-validation.
optimization.regularization: Yes, regularization techniques included dropout (in autoencoders and MLP), batch normalization in GCN layers, and L2 weight decay during optimization. Reconstruction loss was minimized using mean squared error, and stratified cross-validation ensured performance generalization across subsets.

evaluation.method: GARNET was evaluated using stratified 5-fold cross-validation, ensuring class balance across training and test subsets. Each fold involved an independent test split, and no overlap occurred between training and testing samples. Additionally, performance was qualitatively assessed through case studies and literature-based validation using PubMed evidence.
evaluation.measure: The evaluation metrics reported include AUC (Area Under the ROC Curve), AUPR (Area Under the Precision-Recall Curve), Accuracy, Precision, Recall, F1-score, and Matthews Correlation Coefficient (MCC). These are standard and widely accepted metrics in biomedical machine learning and are consistent with those used in prior LDA prediction literature.
evaluation.comparison: Yes, GARNET was compared against several state-of-the-art methods, including VGAELDA, DMFLDA, and IPCARF. All models were evaluated using the same dataset, and GARNET consistently outperformed them across all the above mentioned metrics. This demonstrates its competitiveness and improvement over both deep learning and simpler baseline methods.
evaluation.confidence: While specific confidence intervals are not reported, model stability was observed across all folds of cross-validation, and performance metrics showed low variance. The superior results compared to baselines are consistent and robust, but formal statistical significance testing (e.g., p-values) was not performed.
evaluation.availability: Yes, all evaluation results—including predictions, metric scores, confusion matrices, and PubMed-supported validations—will be made available in the GitHub repository under the MIT License. This includes cross-validation scripts, base and meta-model outputs, and the code used to generate figures and tables in the manuscript.

publication.title: EssSubgraph improves performance and generalizability of mammalian essential gene prediction with large networks
publication.authors: Haimei Wen, Susan Carpenter, Karen McGinnis, Andrew Nelson, Keriayn Smith, Tian Hong

dataset.provenance: The protein-protein interaction (PPI) network was obtained from publicly available databases such as STRING (source of string_net.txt), which is widely recognized and used in bioinformatics research. Node features were generated by performing PCA on a processed TCGA gene expression dataset (cancer_full_expression_pc50.csv) that was compiled and curated by previous studies from the TCGA public resource. Class labels indicating essential (positive) and non-essential (negative) genes were obtained from a summary file from DepMap, a widely used database. The dataset includes 2,299 essential genes (Npos) and 10,723 non-essential genes (Nneg). It is designed for classification tasks and does not contain real-valued outputs for regression. While the cancer_full_expression_pc50.csv feature file was generated in this study, it is from direct transformation of TCGA expression matrix, which is widely used in the cancer research community.
dataset.splits:
We employed a stratified 5-fold cross-validation strategy to evaluate model performance. 80% of the data were allocated for training and 20% for testing. Within the training subset, 90% was used for final training and 10% for validation, which was utilized for model tuning and early stopping. Although the original label data consist of 2,299 essential genes (Npos) and 10,723 non-essential genes (Nneg), the actual number of genes involved in training varies depending on the protein-protein interaction (PPI) network, as not all genes are present in every network. For instance, in the STRING network, only a subset of genes is retained after filtering based on network inclusion.

Given that non-essential genes outnumber essential genes by more than fourfold, and that the number of available genes varies across networks, direct training would suffer from a class imbalance problem, potentially resulting in poor predictive performance on the minority (essential) class. To mitigate this, we adopted a resampling strategy whereby, for each training, validation, and test split, all essential genes were included alongside randomly selected non-essential genes at a 1:4 ratio. Using the STRING network as an example, this procedure yielded 6,048 genes in the training set, 972 in the validation set, and 1,680 in the test set. Because the splits were dynamically generated in each fold, we did not plot the distributions explicitly, but the stratification process guarantees that the class balance is consistent across training, validation, and test sets.
dataset.redundancy: The dataset was split using stratified 5-fold cross-validation to ensure independence between training and test sets in each fold. Specifically, genes were partitioned so that no gene appeared in both training and test sets within the same fold, thus maintaining non-overlapping sets. Similar to our approach, other gene classification methods such as EMOGI and MTGCN (both used as benchmark methods in this study) also employ cross-validation strategies to split data into training and test sets. Cross-validation provides a robust framework for performance evaluation by ensuring that each sample is tested while maintaining independence between training and testing data within each fold. This approach is widely used in the community for gene-level prediction tasks, especially when datasets are limited in size or exhibit class imbalance. Therefore, our use of stratified cross-validation aligns with established practices in similar studies.
dataset.availability: Yes, the datasets used in this study have been made publicly available for reproducibility and further research. They are hosted on GitHub at https://github.com/wenmm/EssSubgraph/tree/main/data. The data are shared under the GPL v3 license.

model.interpretability: The graph neural network (GNN) models used in this study are not inherently interpretable and require additional methods to enhance their interpretability.
model.output: The model is a classification model. It is designed to predict whether a given gene is essential or non-essential, which is a binary classification task.
model.duration: Each epoch takes approximately 1–2 seconds to complete.  Experiments were run on a workstation with an AMD Ryzen Threadripper 3960X 24-core CPU, an NVIDIA GeForce RTX 2080 Ti GPU, and 256 GB of RAM.
model.availability: Yes, the source code was released in github (https://github.com/wenmm/EssSubgraph/tree/main), we provide methods to run the algorithm using both Docker containers and Conda environments. The Docker image and Conda environment files are available in our GitHub repository, released under the GPL v3 license.

optimization.algorithm: The machine learning approach used in this study falls within the class of graph neural networks (GNNs). While graph neural networks themselves are not new, they possess previously unexplored advantages for node classification tasks, especially when integrating multi-omics data and protein-protein interaction networks. This makes GNNs particularly well-suited for essential gene prediction, as they effectively capture both network topology and complex biological features that other methods struggle to model.
optimization.meta: Our model does not use predictions from other machine learning algorithms as input.
optimization.config: Yes, the parameters are reported in the script (https://github.com/wenmm/EssSubgraph/blob/main/EssSubgraph.py). The code is released under the GPL v3 license.
optimization.encoding: The protein-protein interaction (PPI) network was represented as a graph where nodes correspond to genes and edges represent interactions. Node features were derived from gene expression data, which were first processed by principal component analysis (PCA) performed on TCGA gene expression (gene-sample) matrix curated by previous studies. After PCA, we applied min-max scaling to normalize node feature values to a [0, 1] range. For each gene, its expression-based feature vector was combined with its topology in the PPI network to provide the input for the graph neural network. Label data (essential vs. non-essential) were encoded as binary classes (1 for essential, 0 for non-essential). Prior to training, data splits were performed using stratified cross-validation, ensuring balanced representation of classes.
optimization.features: We evaluated the test set PRAUC across different PCA dimensions and selected 𝑓= 50 features as it achieved the best performance. Given that benchmark methods EMOGI and MTGCN both use 64 features and the performance difference between 50 and 64 features is minimal, we chose 50 from a model performance analysis perspective to provide a clear rationale for our selection.
optimization.fitting: In our study, the number of trainable parameters p is moderately higher than the number of training samples. For example, under the STRING network setting, the training set contains around 6,000 genes. We only use 50 node features so our model does not fall into the regime where f > 100. To prevent overfitting, we applied several strategies, including stratified cross-validation, early stopping based on validation performance, dropout, and L2 regularization. These techniques help the model generalize effectively. Conversely, to avoid underfitting, we tuned the model’s complexity (e.g., number of layers and hidden channels). The consistent results across validation folds suggest that the model's capacity is appropriate for the task.
optimization.parameters: There are 95,361 trainable parameters in the model. They are trained with gradient descent and a loss function defined by the deviation from experimental data. The model also includes a set of commonly used hyperparameters such as the number of layers, hidden dimensions, dropout rate, learning rate, L2 regularization weight, and whether to use batch normalization. These settings were kept consistent with previous related studies to ensure fair comparison, and were not extensively tuned for performance optimization.
optimization.regularization: Yes, we used stratified cross-validation, early stopping based on validation set, dropout, and L2 regularization.

evaluation.method: The method was evaluated using stratified 5-fold cross-validation to ensure robust assessment of model performance.
evaluation.measure: We report commonly used classification performance metrics, including Area Under the Receiver Operating Characteristic Curve (AUROC) and Precision-Recall Area Under the Curve (PRAUC). These metrics are widely accepted in the literature for evaluating binary classification tasks. Our reported metrics are consistent with those used in comparable studies such as EMOGI and MTGCN (both used as benchmark methods in this study), facilitating direct comparison and demonstrating the competitiveness of our approach.
evaluation.comparison: We did not evaluate our method on publicly available benchmark datasets, as existing essential gene prediction methods such as XGEP and DeepHE typically use their own specific datasets. However, we applied our method to the dataset used by XGEP and achieved superior performance compared to their results. Additionally, we included comparisons to simpler baseline models to demonstrate the improvements brought by our approach. Although we did not use publicly available benchmark datasets, we performed comparisons on the same dataset with several graph-based models including GCN, GAT, EMOGI, and MTGCN. Additionally, we compared our method against traditional approaches such as DeepWalk and SVM. These comparisons demonstrate the superior performance of our method across multiple baselines.
evaluation.confidence: We used 5-fold cross-validation and conducted 10 rounds, obtaining 50 sets of data. The average performance was shown as a heatmap, and for the data with perturbations, we created a line plot with error bars. The data underlying the line plot with error bars showed statistical significance of the superior performance.
evaluation.availability: Yes, the raw evaluation files—including assignments for comparison and baselines, statistical code, and data—are available. They can be found at https://github.com/wenmm/EssSubgraph/tree/main/baseline. We have provided a README file there with instructions on how to run these baseline methods.

publication.title: Prediction of Drug-Target Interactions Based on Dual-Channel Heterogeneous Graph Neural Networks
publication.authors: Haoyang Tang, Chenyang Fan, Bo Qin, Xu Zhu}

dataset.provenance:
Data Source:
The data originates from a published literature source. Specifically, it is derived from a dataset that has been previously utilized in other research papers, indicating its recognition within the scientific community.
Data Points in Each Class:
Positive Class (Npos): There are 1,363 positive data points.
Negative Class (Nneg): There are 588,594 negative data points.
Dataset Usage:
This dataset has been previously used by other papers, which attests to its relevance and recognition within the community.
dataset.splits:
Number of Data Points:
Training Set: Contains 471965 data points.
Validation Set: Contains 58996 data points.
Test Set: Contains 58996 data points.
Use of a Separate Validation Set:
No.
Differences in Data Type Distributions:
The distributions of data types in the training and test sets are similar. We ensured that the data distribution in each subset remained consistent with that of the original dataset during the splitting process. Specifically, we calculated the proportion of each data type in both the training and test sets and ensured that these proportions were similar across the two subsets.
Visualization of Data Type Distributions:
No.
dataset.redundancy:
Data Splitting Method:
Our dataset was divided into training, validation, and test sets, with proportions of 80%, 10%, and 10%, respectively. The splitting process was conducted using a random sampling method to ensure that the data distribution in each subset remained consistent with that of the original dataset.
Independence of Training and Test Sets:
To ensure the independence of the training and test sets, we adopted a strict splitting strategy. During the splitting process, we ensured that there was no overlap between the samples in the training and test sets, meaning that each sample belonged to only one subset.
We further ensured independence through the following methods:
Pairwise Similarity Check: We calculated the pairwise similarity between all samples in the training and test sets and ensured that the similarity was below 30%. This step was implemented by calculating the Jaccard similarity between samples.
Data Source Verification: We verified the sources of the data to ensure that the samples in the training and test sets came from different experiments or data sources, thereby reducing potential biases.
Redundancy Reduction:
To reduce redundancy in the data, we performed the following operations during the data preprocessing stage:
De-duplication: We removed completely identical samples from the dataset to avoid the impact of duplicate data on model training.
Comparison of Data Distribution:
We compared our data distribution with that of previously published machine learning datasets. Specifically, we calculated key statistical indicators of our dataset (such as the number of samples, the number of features, and class distribution) and compared them with those of published datasets.
Through these analyses, we found that our dataset was similar to published datasets in terms of sample size and feature distribution, but differed in certain aspects (such as class distribution). These differences reflect the specific needs of our research and the characteristics of our data sources.
dataset.availability:
Yes.
Luo dataset: https://github.com/luoyunan/DTINet
Zheng dataset:https://github.com/ahu-bioinf-lab/AMGDTI

model.interpretability: The model is black box.
model.duration:
Our experiments were conducted on a standard desktop computer with the following specifications:
Hardware Configuration:
CPU: AMD Ryzen 7 7730U with Radeon Graphics
Memory: 32GB
GPU: AMD Radeon (TM) Graphics
Software Environment:
Operating System: Windows 10
Python Version: Python 3.8
Main Libraries: Python 3.8.20, Biopython 1.83, PyTorch 2.4.1, Torch Geometric 2.6.1, Pandas 2.0.3, NumPy 1.24.4, XGBoost 2.1.2
Under the above hardware configuration, the prediction time for a single representative instance was 0.00036 seconds.
model.availability: The source code has been released.  A method for running the algorithm has been published. Specifically, a detailed README.md file has been provided, which includes the steps and instructions needed to run the algorithm.  Links and License:  URL: The source code and running guide can be accessed via the following link:  https://github.com/2045977925/DCHG-DTI.git  Running Method: The README.md file provides detailed steps, including environment setup, data preprocessing, model training, and prediction. The source code is released under the GPL-3.0 license.

optimization.algorithm:
This study employs Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) and the XGBoost algorithm. Specifically, we have constructed a framework based on a Dual-Channel Heterogeneous Graph Neural Network (DCHG-DTI), where a Relation-Aware Graph Convolutional Network (R-GCN) is used for feature extraction, and a Multi-Head Bilinear Attention mechanism (MHBA) is used for feature fusion. Finally, XGBoost is employed for predicting drug-target interactions (DTI).
While Graph Neural Networks and XGBoost are not new algorithms in themselves, we have integrated them into a novel dual-channel heterogeneous graph neural network framework for predicting drug-target interactions. This combination approach is innovative.
The reason for selecting this combination is that it leverages multi-modal features of drugs and targets (such as SMILES sequences, protein sequences, molecular graphs, and residue contact maps) and integrates cross-modal information through heterogeneous graph neural networks. This approach not only enhances the predictive capability of the model but also improves its generalization ability, enabling it to handle complex biomedical data effectively.
optimization.meta:
In this study, we did not utilize a meta-prediction model. All input data were directly sourced from the original dataset, and we did not use predictions from other machine learning algorithms as inputs.
Since we did not employ a meta-prediction model, there is no issue of training data independence between initial predictive variables and meta-predictive variables.
optimization.config: We provide a detailed report on the hyperparameter configuration and optimization plan in the "MATERIALS AND METHODS" section of the paper.  Model Files and Optimization Parameters: The model files and optimization parameters have been uploaded to the GitHub repository and can be accessed via the following link:  GitHub Repository Link: https://github.com/2045977925/DCHG-DTI.git. All code and data are released under the GPL-3.0 license.
optimization.encoding: Data Encoding: 1.Drug SMILES Sequences: Convert SMILES to numerical embeddings using a 3-gram method, assign unique indices, and construct a 3-gram dictionary for feature extraction. 2.Protein Sequences: Convert protein sequences to numerical embeddings using the same 3-gram method, assigning unique indices for feature extraction. 3.Drug Molecular Graphs: Use RDKit to convert SMILES into molecular graphs, extracting atomic and edge features. 4.Protein Residue Contact Maps: Parse PDB files to obtain 3D structural information and calculate residue contact relationships to generate contact maps. Data Preprocessing:  1.Sequence Padding and Truncation: Fix SMILES sequences to a maximum length of 100 and protein sequences to 1000. Longer sequences are truncated, and shorter ones are padded with zeros. 2.Feature Extraction: Use Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN) and GraphSAGE to extract features from embeddings. 3.Normalization: Normalize extracted features to ensure they are on the same scale. 4.Data Augmentation: Upsample positive samples and downsample negative samples to balance the dataset.
optimization.features:
The input features include drug SMILES sequence features, protein sequence features, drug molecular graph features, and protein residue contact map features, all of which have a dimensionality of 64.
In the feature extraction phase, we extracted key features using CNN and GraphSAGE, and further fused these features using a Multi-Head Bilinear Attention mechanism (MHBA) to reduce redundant information. These steps can be considered part of the feature selection process.
The feature selection and fusion processes were conducted using only the training set to ensure the model's generalization capability.
optimization.fitting: To prevent overfitting, we employed the following techniques: 1.Dropout: We used dropout techniques in CNN and GraphSAGE, randomly dropping a portion of neurons to reduce the risk of overfitting.  2.Regularization: L1 and L2 regularization were applied in XGBoost to control model complexity.  3.Cross-Validation: We utilized 5-fold cross-validation to evaluate model performance, ensuring stability across different subsets. To prevent underfitting, we ensured that the model had sufficient complexity to capture the intricate relationships within the data and optimized model performance by adjusting hyperparameters.
optimization.parameters:
The number of parameters used in the model includes the weight matrices and bias vectors of the CNN and GraphSAGE, as well as the parameters in the XGBoost model. The specific number depends on the structure and depth of the models.
Parameter Selection: The selection of parameters is determined through cross-validation and hyperparameter optimization. We used grid search and random search methods to choose the optimal combination of hyperparameters, ensuring that the model performs best on the validation set.
optimization.regularization: We used the following techniques to prevent overfitting:  1.Early Stopping: During the training process, we monitored model performance using a validation set and stopped training early when the performance on the validation set no longer improved.  2.Dropout: We implemented dropout techniques in CNN and GraphSAGE, randomly dropping a portion of neurons to reduce the risk of overfitting.  3.Regularization: L1 and L2 regularization were employed in XGBoost to control model complexity.

evaluation.method:
Cross-Validation: This study employed 5-fold cross-validation to assess the performance of the DCHG-DTI model. To address the issue of class imbalance in the dataset, oversampling was applied to the positive samples, and undersampling was applied to the negative samples to balance the dataset. In each cross-validation iteration, 80% of the positive samples and 80% of the negative samples were randomly selected to train the model, while 10% of the positive samples and 10% of the negative samples were used as a validation set for parameter adjustment. The remaining 10% of the positive and negative samples were selected as the test set.
Independent Dataset: In addition to evaluation on the Luo benchmark dataset, tests were also conducted on the Zheng dataset to verify the model's generalization capability.
Novel Experiments: To further validate the practical application value of the model, predictions were made on anti-aging drug-target interactions, and experiments were conducted on drug-target pairs related to anti-aging.
evaluation.measure: Accuracy, Precision, Recall, F1 Score, AUC, AUPRC. These metrics are widely used in the fields of machine learning and drug-target interaction prediction, and they are representative.
evaluation.comparison: Benchmark Dataset Comparison: Yes, this study compared the DCHG-DTI model with four state-of-the-art drug-target interaction prediction models on the Luo benchmark dataset, including GraphDTA, BG-DTI, MultiDTI, and DeepConv-DTI. DCHG-DTI outperformed these methods across all evaluation metrics.  Baseline Comparison: Yes, this study also compared the model with simpler baseline methods, such as single-channel models that use only Channel A or Channel B, as well as fusion strategies that employ simple feature concatenation. DCHG-DTI also demonstrated significant performance improvements in these comparisons.
evaluation.confidence: Confidence Interval: This paper does not report the confidence intervals for the performance metrics. Future experiments will consider using bootstrap methods or other statistical approaches to calculate the confidence intervals.  Statistical Significance:While the results of statistical tests are not directly reported, DCHG-DTI significantly outperformed other methods and baseline models across all evaluation metrics, indicating its superior performance. To further enhance the statistical significance of the results, future work will consider conducting paired t-tests or other appropriate statistical tests.

publication.title: Accurate proteome-wide prediction of enzymes and catalytic sites using graph deep learning and protein language model
publication.authors: Yui-Lun Ng, Xiaomei Wang, Yingqi Li, Junzhe Huang, Hei Ming Lai, Jason Ying-Kuen Chan, Billy Wai-Lung Ng, Ho Ko, Ka-Wai Kwok

dataset.provenance:
The data source used are Protein Data Bank, UniProt Knowledgebase, Mechanism and Catalytic Site Atlas, and AlphaFold2 Database. 

The labels in this work are multi-label classification, where the class distribution are as follow
Main class (1st digit): 7 classes
Subclass (2nd digit): 59 classes 
Sub-subclass (3rd digit): 159 classes 
Sub-sub-subclass (4th digit): 348 classes
dataset.splits:
Temporal holdout method were used to split the training and test set. 
The Training Set are derived from UniProtKB release 2022_01. After clustering to reduce redundancy (95% identity), the training set contained 16,263 protein structures. The Test Set (Newly Annotated Structures) contained 3,378 unique structures that were newly annotated with EC numbers between UniProtKB releases 2022_01 and 2025_02. The Test Set (Newly Annotated Sequences) consisted of 297 sequence records with newly identified EC functions.
During model training, 5 fold cross validation were employed to split the training set into 5 fold.
dataset.redundancy: A sequence similiarity method CD-HIT were used to check the similarity between training set and test set. Proteins with sequence similarity of 95% identity or below are considered distinct.
dataset.availability: The protein data can be downloaded from Protein Data Bank. The index of data split were included in the GitHub repository (https://github.com/ngyuilun/EC-LMGraph). MIT License were used.

model.interpretability: The model is interpretable with Captum explainabale packages.
model.duration: With NVIDIA GeForce RTX 3090 GPUs used, the framework can predict 100 proteins within 50 seconds.
model.availability: The code was uploaded to GitHub (https://github.com/ngyuilun/EC-LMGraph/) with MIT license.

optimization.algorithm: The proposed work investiaged the graph convolutional layer, graph attention, hypergraph attention, a graph clustering algorithm, and local extremum convolution, in combination with the protein language model, could achieve superior score over other methods.
optimization.config: N/A
optimization.encoding: The protein data were pre-processed into an adjacency matrix and a feature matrix to obtain a protein graph format. The adjacency matrix encodes the pairwise Euclidean distances between the alpha carbon of amino acid residues, whereas the feature matrix encodes the amino acid identity.
optimization.features: Features were collected from protein data and pre-processed into an adjacency matrix and a feature matrix. The twenty standard amino acid residues were encoded using one-hot encoding method. Inter-residue separation of residues (in Å) constructed as a contact map for each protein. No feature selection were performed.
optimization.fitting: Deep learning model were evalauted on validation set and test set to ensure overfiting and underfitting does not ruled out.
optimization.parameters: The EC-LMGraph model contains 20,820,854 parameters. This was depends on the number of layer implemented.
optimization.regularization: Early stopping criterion was set when training loss, validation loss and mean F1 score could not be further improved by 30 successive epochs

evaluation.method: Temporal holdout validation were employed to identify newly annotated protein structures in the UniProtKB database between two releases, 2022_01 (Feb 2022) and 2025_02 (Apr 2025).
evaluation.measure: The models are evaluated on precision, recall, accuracy, specificity, F1 score, and Matthews Correlation Coefficient (MCC). These metrics are representative  and commonly used.
evaluation.comparison: A comparison was made with existing works, including CLEAN, ProteInfer, ECPred, DeepEC, DeepFRI and COFACTOR and the baseline method is BLASTp.
evaluation.confidence: No

publication.title: HVRLocator: A Computationally Efficient Tool for Identifying Hypervariable Regions in Large 16S rRNA Datasets
publication.authors: Clara Arboleda-Baena, Felipe Borim Correa, Joao Pedro Saraiva, Santiago Castillo-Rivadeneira, Jonas Coelho Kasmanas, Antonis Chatzinotas, Stephanie D. Jurburg

dataset.provenance: Sequence data can be obtained from the databases: the European Nucleotide Archive (ENA) at the European Bioinformatics Institute, the Sequence Read Archive (SRA) at the National Center for Biotechnology Information, and the DNA Databank of Japan (DDBJ) Sequence Read Archives at the National Institute of Genetics. HVRLocator also accepts resolved amplicons (e.g., Amplicon Sequence Variants (ASV)) or raw sequencing data in .FASTA or .FASTQ file formats.
dataset.splits: For the Random Forest model generation, a curated collection of SRA runs known to possess (882 RUNS) or not sequencing primers (8940 RUNS) was downloaded from the Sequence Read Archive (SRA) hosted by the National Center for Biotechnology and Information (NCBI).
dataset.redundancy: The model was trained using scikit-learn’s RandomForestClassifier (v1.2.1) with 100 estimators and a fixed random seed (random_state=42), using an 80/20 stratified train-test split.
dataset.availability: Supplementary Tables S1 and S2 of the manuscript contain the Accsession numbers for each dataset. The python script used to generate the model is available at https://github.com/fbcorrea/hvrlocator/blob/main/rf_model_hvrlocator.py. The model and supporting files are available at https://github.com/fbcorrea/hvrlocator/. The full workflow is licensed under CC0 1.0.

model.interpretability: Black-box, but explainable post hoc. A random forest is not intrinsically interpretable like a linear model or a single decision tree. However, we provide global explanations via impurity-based and permutation feature importance, and local explanations via SHAP values/decision-path traces. In practice, features summarizing positions 1–5 (e.g., mean and lower quantile of Phred scores) tend to contribute most to “primer” predictions, consistent with primer-associated early-read quality patterns.
model.output: Binary classification. The model outputs one of two classes: {primer, no-primer}, along with the predicted probability (forest vote proportion) for the positive class.
model.duration: Prediction is sub-millisecond; end-to-end is dominated by I/O. On a standard laptop/desktop CPU (4–8 cores, ~2.5–3.5 GHz), scikit-learn RF inference for a single 16-feature sample takes well under 1 ms. When including feature computation from the first 1,000 reads, wall-clock time is typically ≪1 s per run, primarily constrained by reading/decompressing FASTQ rather than the model itself.
model.availability: Yes. Both the python script necessary to generate the Random Forest model as well as the model itself are available at https://github.com/fbcorrea/hvrlocator/ under the license CC0 1.0 Universal.

optimization.algorithm: Random Forest
optimization.config: Yes. All files are available at https://github.com/fbcorrea/hvrlocator/ under the license CC0 1.0 Universal.
optimization.encoding: We encoded each SRA run as fixed-length numeric features derived from early-read Phred quality scores. From the first 1,000 reads per run, we computed summary statistics over two base-position segments (1–5 and 6–10). For each segment we calculated: count, mean, median, standard deviation, minimum, maximum, 25th percentile, and 75th percentile—yielding 16 numeric features per run. No scaling/normalization was applied (tree-based model); no missing values were present. The 25th/75th percentiles were included as robust proxies for distribution shape.
optimization.features: The model uses f = 16 features per run (two quality segments × eight statistics). No feature selection or dimensionality reduction was performed; all features were computed from the predefined schema and used as input. Feature selection not applicable.
optimization.fitting: This is a small-f, large-N setting: f = 16 and N = 9,822 runs (≈80/20 stratified split for training/test). Thus  (Npos+Nneg)≫f (N pos+N neg)≫f and p is not fixed (nonparametric). Underfitting was ruled out by strong performance on the held-out test set (per-class precision: 99.96% no-primer, 100% primer; recall: 100% no-primer, 99.55% primer). Overfitting risk is mitigated by bagging and feature subsampling inherent to random forests and by evaluation on a stratified hold-out set.
optimization.parameters: Random forests are nonparametric; the number of learned split thresholds and leaf values grows with data and is not a fixed “p.” We therefore report hyperparameters instead: n_estimators=100, random_state=42, and otherwise scikit-learn v1.2.1 defaults (e.g., criterion="gini", max_features="sqrt", bootstrap=True, max_depth=None). No hyperparameter tuning was performed.
optimization.regularization: No explicit early stopping or penalty-based regularization was used. Overfitting prevention comes from the RF’s built-in mechanisms—bootstrap aggregation, random feature subsampling at each split, and ensembling across 100 trees—plus validation on a held-out stratified test set.

evaluation.method: Stratified 80/20 hold-out: the model was trained on 80% of runs and evaluated once on the held-out 20% test set, preserving the class distribution (primer vs. no-primer). No cross-validation or test-set peeking was performed.
evaluation.measure: We report per-class precision and recall on the held-out test set (primer / no-primer), along with the confusion matrix and overall accuracy. This set emphasizes class-wise behavior under imbalance and is standard/representative for binary classification.
evaluation.comparison: No direct benchmarking against external/public tools was performed. As internal baselines, a majority-class predictor (always “no-primer”) and a single decision tree on the same 16 features were considered; the random forest substantially outperformed these baselines, especially on primer recall (the majority baseline has zero primer recall by definition).
evaluation.confidence: Formal confidence intervals and statistical tests vs. alternatives were not computed. Given the near-perfect test performance and large test set, binomial 95% Wilson intervals for class-wise precision/recall would be narrow. We do not claim statistical superiority over other methods.
evaluation.availability: Yes. All files, statistical code and confusion matrices are located at https://github.com/fbcorrea/hvrlocator/

publication.title: Generalizable machine learning models for rapid antimicrobial resistance prediction in unseen healthcare settings
publication.authors: Diane Duroux, Paul P. Meyer, Giovanni Visonà, Niko Beerenwinkel

dataset.provenance:
The publicly available DRIAMS dataset [1] consists of MALDI-TOF mass spectrometry data collected from patients in the Swiss healthcare system. This dataset includes data from four distinct diagnostic laboratories, collected from 2015 to 2018: University Hospital Basel (designated as DRIAMS-A), Cantonal Hospital Basel-Land (DRIAMS-B), Cantonal Hospital Aarau (DRIAMS-C), and the Viollier laboratory service provider (DRIAMS-D). The MALDI-TOF mass spectra used in this project were originally published as part of the study by Weis et al. [2]. This dataset is widely recognized within the microbiology community and has been utilized in several subsequent studies.

[1] Weis, C., et al. "DRIAMS: database of resistance information on antimicrobials and MALDI-TOF mass spectra." Dryad, dataset (2021).
[2] Weis et al., "Direct antimicrobial resistance prediction from clinical MALDI-TOF mass spectra using machine learning" (Nature Medicine, 28(1), 2022, pp. 164–174)
dataset.splits:
In total, 631,167 observations were leveraged: 11,610 in A2015; 138,132 in A2016; 179,334 in A2017; 123,558 in A2018; 32,377 in B2018, 47,586 in C2018; and 98,570 in D2018. 
Two main data splits were created: 
1. Hospital zero-shot split: Select data from the DRIAMS dataset collected in 2018. Let i, j ∈ {A, B, C, D} represent the hospitals in the dataset. Train the model on data from hospital i. Test the model on data from hospital j, where j!= i.
2. Year zero-shot split: Select data from the DRIAMS A. Let i, j ∈ {2015, 2016, 2017, 2018} represent the year of data collection. Train the model on data from year i. Test the model on data from year j, where j!= i.
dataset.redundancy: To prevent data leakage, each data split was designed so that no pathogen appeared in both the training and test sets. In each split, the test set was drawn under a different condition: a different hospital in the hospital zero-shot setting, and a different year in the year zero-shot setting.
dataset.availability: The MALDI-TOF spectra used in this project can be obtained by downloading the DRIAMS dataset from https://doi.org/10.5061/dryad.bzkh1899q. The accompanying metadata includes information on the hospital and year of data collection, necessary to reproduce the splits.

model.interpretability: The model is black box.
model.duration: Inference for a single spectrum-antimicrobial combination takes less than 1 second to run on a desktop PC.
model.availability: The source code used to train the models and generate the results presented in this study is publicly available at https://github.com/DianeDuroux/ZeroShotAMR. The project is released under the GNU General Public License v3.0 (GPL-3.0).

optimization.algorithm:
In Visona et al. [1], three primary models are explored: (1) encodings derived by applying principal component analysis to mass spectra and chemical fingerprints, which are concatenated and used as input for a logistic regression model; (2) joint representations generated by Siamese networks, subsequently utilized as input for logistic regression to predict resistance; and (3) a classification Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP) with Residual Skip-Connections. Building on the findings of Visona et al. [1], which identified the MLP with Residual Skip-Connections [2] as achieving the highest performance, we trained this network to predict the probability of resistance for antimicrobial-spectrum pairs.

[1] Visonà, Giovanni, et al. "Multimodal learning in clinical proteomics: enhancing antimicrobial resistance prediction models with chemical information." Bioinformatics 39.12 (2023): btad717.
[2] Szegedy, Christian, et al. "Inception-v4, inception-resnet and the impact of residual connections on learning." Proceedings of the AAAI conference on artificial intelligence. Vol. 31. No. 1. 2017.
optimization.meta:
We compare two pathogen representations: binned MALDI-TOF mass spectra and encodings generated by masked autoencoders (MAEs). 

We compare three types of antimicrobial representations: traditional molecular fingerprints, encodings generated by Molformer transformer-based model for molecular representation learning [1], and SELF-referencing embedded strings (Selfies) [2].

[1] Ross, Jerret, et al. "Large-scale chemical language representations capture molecular structure and properties." Nature Machine Intelligence 4.12 (2022): 1256-1264.
[2] Krenn, Mario, et al. "Self-referencing embedded strings (SELFIES): A 100% robust molecular string representation." Machine Learning: Science and Technology 1.4 (2020): 045024.
optimization.config: The code used to train the models (including the hyperparameter configurations) and generate the results presented in this study is publicly available at https://github.com/DianeDuroux/ZeroShotAMR. Pretrained model weights can be accessed via the GigaDB repository. The project is released under the GNU General Public License v3.0 (GPL-3.0).
optimization.encoding: Data bias exists within DRIAMS-A due to one particular workstation (HospitalHygene), where samples were captured using a different medium and skewed heavily toward resistant samples. Following Weis et al. [1], we excluded data from this workstation to mitigate potential biases. The spectra were binned using a bin size of 3 m/z units. The encodings defined in the section above were used. [1] Weis et al., "Direct antimicrobial resistance prediction from clinical MALDI-TOF mass spectra using machine learning" (Nature Medicine, 28(1), 2022, pp. 164–174)
optimization.features: Different encoding strategies are evaluated (as described above), each resulting in a different number of input features. None of the encoding techniques leverage the resistance/susceptibility outcome during feature construction. The total number of features varies from 1,280 (MAE embeddings of dimension 512 combined with Molformer embeddings of dimension 768) to 30,160 (6000-dimensional spectra combined with 24,160-dimensional SELFIES encodings).
optimization.fitting: The number of parameters is larger than the number of training points. Overfitting was addressed through early stopping, dropout, weight decay, and validation monitoring (see below)
optimization.parameters: The input projections encodes the MALDI TOF spectra and the antimicrobials encodings into 512-dimensional vectors, which are then concatenated. The model consists of 5 residual blocks, including ReLU activation, a linear layer of dimensionality 1024, a dropout layer with probability 0.2, and a BatchNorm layer. The ResMLP is trained with early stopping with a patience parameter of 10 epochs using an Adam optimiser with a learning rate of 3∗10−4 and a weight decay of 10−5. With the 6000-dimensional binned MALDI-TOF mass spectra and Morgan molecular fingerprints, the ResMLP model has 218M trainable parameters.
optimization.regularization: Early stopping was employed to halt training if the validation loss did not improve in consecutive epochs, preventing the model from over-optimizing on the training set. Additional regularization was introduced via dropout within residual blocks (with a probability of 0.2) and weight decay (L2 regularization with a factor of 1e-5) to discourage overly complex models. The best model was selected based on validation performance, ensuring generalizability.

evaluation.method: The method was evaluated under two zero-shot settings: hospital zero-shot and year zero-shot, using four data splits for each scenario.
evaluation.measure: We report three standard classification metrics for imbalanced data: area under the precision-recall curve (AUPRC), balanced accuracy, and Matthews Correlation Coefficient (MCC).
evaluation.comparison:
We use as baseline, the best model of Visona et al.  [1], which utilizes a 6000-dimensional binned MALDI-TOF mass spectra vector representation for pathogens and Morgan fingerprints for antimicrobial representations.

[1] Visonà, Giovanni, et al. "Multimodal learning in clinical proteomics: enhancing antimicrobial resistance prediction models with chemical information." Bioinformatics 39.12 (2023): btad717.
evaluation.confidence: We provide error bars representing standard deviation across training sets.
evaluation.availability: The raw evaluation files are not available.
