publication.title: Cell type transcriptomics reveal shared genetic mechanisms in Alzheimer’s and Parkinson’s disease
publication.authors: Anwesha Bhattacharya, Edward A. Fon, Alain Dagher, Yasser Iturria-Medina, Jo Anne Stratton, Chloe Savignac, Jack Stanley, Liam Hodgson, Badr Ait Hammou, David A Bennett, Danilo Bzdok

dataset.provenance:
Re-used Data availability

ROSMAP Alzheimer’s dataset https://www.radc.rush.edu/docs/var/standardDatasetVariables.htm
Parkinson’s disease, Kamath dataset, GEO accession number GSE178265
Seattle Alzheimer’s dataset https://cellxgene.cziscience.com/
Parkinson’s disease, Smajić dataset, GEO accession number GSE157783
dataset.splits:
ROSMAP (Alzheimer’s disease): 70,634 nuclei
Kamath (Parkinson’s disease): 340,902 nuclei
SEA-AD (Alzheimer’s disease): 683,260 nuclei
Smajić (Parkinson’s disease): 41,435 nuclei

For selection of the number of PLS components (hyperparameter), a nested cross-validation procedure was performed using an 80–20 train–test split, with 10-fold cross-validation (80–20 train–validation split) within the training set to optimize model performance and stability.
dataset.redundancy: A clustered bootstrap was performed to assess model performance with an 80%-20% train-test split. The clustering was done based on donors, ensuring nuclei from the same donor were not present in both the train and test sets.
dataset.availability: The datasets are publicly available

model.interpretability: Yes, the model is interpretable. PLS-DA is a linear model which gives direct access to feature loadings
model.duration: NA
model.availability: yes. Code is available at https://github.com/dblabs-mcgill-mila/AD-PD-overlap-study

optimization.algorithm:
Partial Least Squares Discriminant Analysis (PLS-DA) was used for this study.

PLS-DA was used to model disease versus control classification. The model was chosen for its ability to handle high-dimensional transcriptomic data with strong inter-gene correlations, and inherent noise while maintaining interpretability through gene-level loadings and latent components.
optimization.config: Yes.
optimization.encoding: cell x gene expression matrices were used. Count matrices were library size normalized followed by log1p transformation.
optimization.features: f = ~16,936 genes. f varied across cell-types based on filtering out genes that were present in <0.1% of all nuclei.
optimization.fitting: In most cases (dependent on cell-type), the model was fit with the scenario of N>>p. For cases where p<N, label shuffle permutation enabled validating the statistical significance of the model predictions.
optimization.parameters:
p_scaler = f (number of genes)+1
p_pca = f*pca_components
p_pls = p_pca*pls_components
optimization.regularization: No

evaluation.method: cross-validation, bootstrap, label shuffle permutation tests
evaluation.measure: roc-auc, p-values
evaluation.comparison: no
evaluation.confidence: yes the performance metrics have confidence intervals

publication.title: Predicting treatment response of tumor spheroids from radiomics analysis of post-treatment dynamics
tags: Radiomics, multicellular tumor spheroids, AI-driven methods,   radiation oncology, preclinical therapy testing, 3D cancer models,   brightfield microscopy

dataset.provenance:
The datasets were generated in-house from 3D tumor spheroid experiments conducted at OncoRay – National Center for Radiation Research in Oncology Dresden. Spheroids were derived from human head and neck squamous cell carcinoma cell lines (FaDu and SAS) and exposed to radiotherapy or hyperthermia. Spheroid morphology was monitored over multiple time and radiomics data were generate at each timepoint using the pyradiomics. 
Each dataset corresponds to a different temporal observation window:
Short range: days [0, 3, 5, 7]
Mid range: days [0, 3, 5, 7, 10, 12]
Long range: days [0, 3, 5, 7, 10, 12, 14, 17]
The data were obtained directly from laboratory experiments and not from public databases.
dataset.splits:
Each (short-, mid-, and long-range) contains one row per spheroid, where each spheroid is described by time-series radiomics features and a binary label (controlled vs relapsed).
Thus, each row corresponds to one data point. 
for training we have = 2484 and for the test we have 2485
dataset.redundancy:
Data were split into training (50 %) and test (50 %) partitions using stratified random sampling implemented via StratifiedKFold and train_test_split to maintain an equal ratio of controlled and relapsed cases in both sets. During model training, 5-fold stratified cross-validation on the training set provided internal validation and performance estimation.
The test set remained completely unseen until the final evaluation phase (evaluate() / evaluate_bootstrap()), ensuring genuine out-of-sample performance assessment.
dataset.availability:
The accompanying source code—including preprocessing, model training,  and visualization scripts—is hosted on GitHub at:
🔗 https://github.com/pejman-shojaee/TumorSpheroids

model.interpretability: The model is partially interpretable. Although some classifiers are non-linear, interpretability is achieved via radiomics features with biological meaning, feature-importance analysis, coefficient inspection, and fully transparent preprocessing and training code.
model.duration: About 5 minutes to calculate 6 different ML models for each time range with a 12th Gen Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-12700H (2.30 GHz), 32.0 GB , and * GB Graphic card.
model.availability: All code is available in the GitHub repository: 🔗 https://github.com/pejman-shojaee/TumorSpheroids

optimization.algorithm: We used well-established and not new ML algorithms in our study.
optimization.meta: No, the models in this study do not use the outputs of other ML algorithms as input.
optimization.config: Yes. All hyperparameter configurations, model training scripts, and optimization schedules are fully documented and publicly available.
optimization.encoding: All datasets consisted of numeric radiomics features extracted from tumor spheroid brightfield microscopy images using the PyRadiomics framework.
optimization.features: We used multiple different of feature selectors. Therefore, it is hard to define exactly how many parameters were taken into account. However, we focused on one of the feature selector and ML models and the number of chosen features are 50.
optimization.fitting: In this study, the number of training data points (Ntrain = 2484) is much larger than the number of model parameters (p ≈ 50) and input features after preprocessing (f ≈ 50). Thus, the model operates in a data-rich, low-parameter regime:
optimization.parameters: it is not specified since we used a collection of featur selectors and ML algorithms.
optimization.regularization: Yes. Several complementary regularization and overfitting-control techniques were employed within the modeling pipeline to ensure stable generalization performance.The ML algorithms themselves are using built in regularization terms that penelize the model complexity.  We applied a variance threshold to remove newar constant features. We used feature selectors to reduce the number of features.  For algorithms supporting iterative learning (e.g., MLPClassifier, XGBoost), early stopping was enabled to terminate training when the validation performance ceased to improve, preventing unnecessary parameter updates.

evaluation.method:
We evaluated the method based on the average accuracy of the test data and how it performs on the whole range of days of relapse. We evaluate the prediction accuracy for relapsed cases across the
corresponding DoR to quantify among others the time gain from an early prediction of treatment response
evaluation.measure: We used AUC-ROC and Accuracy as the performance metrics.
evaluation.comparison: No direct comparison to publicly available benchmark datasets was performed, because this study uses in-house experimental data derived from 3D tumor spheroid assays, which do not have established public benchmark counterparts for relapse prediction under radiotherapy or hyperthermia treatment conditions.
evaluation.confidence: We include them in the code but since it was not in our scope of the research we didnt present them in the manuscript.

publication.title: EssSubgraph improves performance and generalizability of mammalian essential gene prediction with large networks
publication.authors: Haimei Wen, Susan Carpenter, Karen McGinnis, Andrew Nelson, Keriayn Smith, Tian Hong

dataset.provenance: The protein-protein interaction (PPI) network was obtained from publicly available databases such as STRING (source of string_net.txt), which is widely recognized and used in bioinformatics research. Node features were generated by performing PCA on a processed TCGA gene expression dataset (cancer_full_expression_pc50.csv) that was compiled and curated by previous studies from the TCGA public resource. Class labels indicating essential (positive) and non-essential (negative) genes were obtained from a summary file from DepMap, a widely used database. The dataset includes 2,299 essential genes (Npos) and 10,723 non-essential genes (Nneg). It is designed for classification tasks and does not contain real-valued outputs for regression. While the cancer_full_expression_pc50.csv feature file was generated in this study, it is from direct transformation of TCGA expression matrix, which is widely used in the cancer research community.
dataset.splits:
We employed a stratified 5-fold cross-validation strategy to evaluate model performance. 80% of the data were allocated for training and 20% for testing. Within the training subset, 90% was used for final training and 10% for validation, which was utilized for model tuning and early stopping. Although the original label data consist of 2,299 essential genes (Npos) and 10,723 non-essential genes (Nneg), the actual number of genes involved in training varies depending on the protein-protein interaction (PPI) network, as not all genes are present in every network. For instance, in the STRING network, only a subset of genes is retained after filtering based on network inclusion.

Given that non-essential genes outnumber essential genes by more than fourfold, and that the number of available genes varies across networks, direct training would suffer from a class imbalance problem, potentially resulting in poor predictive performance on the minority (essential) class. To mitigate this, we adopted a resampling strategy whereby, for each training, validation, and test split, all essential genes were included alongside randomly selected non-essential genes at a 1:4 ratio. Using the STRING network as an example, this procedure yielded 6,048 genes in the training set, 972 in the validation set, and 1,680 in the test set. Because the splits were dynamically generated in each fold, we did not plot the distributions explicitly, but the stratification process guarantees that the class balance is consistent across training, validation, and test sets.
dataset.redundancy: The dataset was split using stratified 5-fold cross-validation to ensure independence between training and test sets in each fold. Specifically, genes were partitioned so that no gene appeared in both training and test sets within the same fold, thus maintaining non-overlapping sets. Similar to our approach, other gene classification methods such as EMOGI and MTGCN (both used as benchmark methods in this study) also employ cross-validation strategies to split data into training and test sets. Cross-validation provides a robust framework for performance evaluation by ensuring that each sample is tested while maintaining independence between training and testing data within each fold. This approach is widely used in the community for gene-level prediction tasks, especially when datasets are limited in size or exhibit class imbalance. Therefore, our use of stratified cross-validation aligns with established practices in similar studies.
dataset.availability: Yes, the datasets used in this study have been made publicly available for reproducibility and further research. They are hosted on GitHub at https://github.com/wenmm/EssSubgraph/tree/main/data. The data are shared under the GPL v3 license.

model.interpretability: The graph neural network (GNN) models used in this study are not inherently interpretable and require additional methods to enhance their interpretability.
model.output: The model is a classification model. It is designed to predict whether a given gene is essential or non-essential, which is a binary classification task.
model.duration: Each epoch takes approximately 1–2 seconds to complete.  Experiments were run on a workstation with an AMD Ryzen Threadripper 3960X 24-core CPU, an NVIDIA GeForce RTX 2080 Ti GPU, and 256 GB of RAM.
model.availability: Yes, the source code was released in github (https://github.com/wenmm/EssSubgraph/tree/main), we provide methods to run the algorithm using both Docker containers and Conda environments. The Docker image and Conda environment files are available in our GitHub repository, released under the GPL v3 license.

optimization.algorithm: The machine learning approach used in this study falls within the class of graph neural networks (GNNs). While graph neural networks themselves are not new, they possess previously unexplored advantages for node classification tasks, especially when integrating multi-omics data and protein-protein interaction networks. This makes GNNs particularly well-suited for essential gene prediction, as they effectively capture both network topology and complex biological features that other methods struggle to model.
optimization.meta: Our model does not use predictions from other machine learning algorithms as input.
optimization.config: Yes, the parameters are reported in the script (https://github.com/wenmm/EssSubgraph/blob/main/EssSubgraph.py). The code is released under the GPL v3 license.
optimization.encoding: The protein-protein interaction (PPI) network was represented as a graph where nodes correspond to genes and edges represent interactions. Node features were derived from gene expression data, which were first processed by principal component analysis (PCA) performed on TCGA gene expression (gene-sample) matrix curated by previous studies. After PCA, we applied min-max scaling to normalize node feature values to a [0, 1] range. For each gene, its expression-based feature vector was combined with its topology in the PPI network to provide the input for the graph neural network. Label data (essential vs. non-essential) were encoded as binary classes (1 for essential, 0 for non-essential). Prior to training, data splits were performed using stratified cross-validation, ensuring balanced representation of classes.
optimization.features: We evaluated the test set PRAUC across different PCA dimensions and selected 𝑓= 50 features as it achieved the best performance. Given that benchmark methods EMOGI and MTGCN both use 64 features and the performance difference between 50 and 64 features is minimal, we chose 50 from a model performance analysis perspective to provide a clear rationale for our selection.
optimization.fitting: In our study, the number of trainable parameters p is moderately higher than the number of training samples. For example, under the STRING network setting, the training set contains around 6,000 genes. We only use 50 node features so our model does not fall into the regime where f > 100. To prevent overfitting, we applied several strategies, including stratified cross-validation, early stopping based on validation performance, dropout, and L2 regularization. These techniques help the model generalize effectively. Conversely, to avoid underfitting, we tuned the model’s complexity (e.g., number of layers and hidden channels). The consistent results across validation folds suggest that the model's capacity is appropriate for the task.
optimization.parameters: There are 95,361 trainable parameters in the model. They are trained with gradient descent and a loss function defined by the deviation from experimental data. The model also includes a set of commonly used hyperparameters such as the number of layers, hidden dimensions, dropout rate, learning rate, L2 regularization weight, and whether to use batch normalization. These settings were kept consistent with previous related studies to ensure fair comparison, and were not extensively tuned for performance optimization.
optimization.regularization: Yes, we used stratified cross-validation, early stopping based on validation set, dropout, and L2 regularization.

evaluation.method: The method was evaluated using stratified 5-fold cross-validation to ensure robust assessment of model performance.
evaluation.measure: We report commonly used classification performance metrics, including Area Under the Receiver Operating Characteristic Curve (AUROC) and Precision-Recall Area Under the Curve (PRAUC). These metrics are widely accepted in the literature for evaluating binary classification tasks. Our reported metrics are consistent with those used in comparable studies such as EMOGI and MTGCN (both used as benchmark methods in this study), facilitating direct comparison and demonstrating the competitiveness of our approach.
evaluation.comparison: We did not evaluate our method on publicly available benchmark datasets, as existing essential gene prediction methods such as XGEP and DeepHE typically use their own specific datasets. However, we applied our method to the dataset used by XGEP and achieved superior performance compared to their results. Additionally, we included comparisons to simpler baseline models to demonstrate the improvements brought by our approach. Although we did not use publicly available benchmark datasets, we performed comparisons on the same dataset with several graph-based models including GCN, GAT, EMOGI, and MTGCN. Additionally, we compared our method against traditional approaches such as DeepWalk and SVM. These comparisons demonstrate the superior performance of our method across multiple baselines.
evaluation.confidence: We used 5-fold cross-validation and conducted 10 rounds, obtaining 50 sets of data. The average performance was shown as a heatmap, and for the data with perturbations, we created a line plot with error bars. The data underlying the line plot with error bars showed statistical significance of the superior performance.
evaluation.availability: Yes, the raw evaluation files—including assignments for comparison and baselines, statistical code, and data—are available. They can be found at https://github.com/wenmm/EssSubgraph/tree/main/baseline. We have provided a README file there with instructions on how to run these baseline methods.

publication.title: Leveraging Machine Learning and Network Biology to Uncover Blood Biomarkers of Brain Gene Expression
publication.authors: Cigdem Sevim Bayrak, Qi Zeng, Marjan Ilkov, Scott J Russo, Minghui Wang, Bin Zhang

dataset.provenance:
The data were obtained from the Genotype-Tissue Expression (GTEx) Project, an open-access, community-recognized resource that provides multi-tissue RNA-seq expression and genotype data from postmortem human donors. The specific dataset used was the GTEx Analysis V8 release, file GTEx_Analysis_2017-06-05_v8_RNASeQCv1.1.9_gene_reads.gct.gz, available from the GTEx Portal (https://gtexportal.org/home/datasets). The dataset contains bulk RNA-seq read counts measured across multiple human tissues. For the analyses presented here, we used matched expression data from the frontal cortex (brain) and whole blood tissues for 152 individuals. The analysis was performed as a regression problem, where the goal was to predict gene expression in the brain from gene expression in blood. Accordingly, there were 152 real-valued paired data points (one per individual). No class labels were used. 
The GTEx dataset is a widely used and well-recognized public resource in genomics and transcriptomics research. It has been used in numerous peer-reviewed studies including the main GTEx Consortium publication (Science, 2020; DOI: 10.1126/science.aaz1776).
dataset.splits: For each gene analyzed, the dataset was partitioned into five folds using the createFolds() function from the caret R package. Each fold was used once as a test set, while the remaining four folds served as the training set, following a standard 5-fold cross-validation procedure. No separate external validation set was used; instead, performance metrics were averaged across the five cross-validation folds to estimate generalization performance.
dataset.redundancy: The data were split using a 5-fold cross-validation strategy implemented with the createFolds() function from the caret R package. Yes, the training and test sets are mutually exclusive. Each model was evaluated only on samples that were not used for training in that fold. Independence was enforced by partitioning at the individual (sample) level. The GTEx dataset is a well-established and widely used reference for transcriptomic modeling. Its expression distributions reflect biological variability across human tissues and donors rather than artificially balanced classes.  Similar cross-tissue gene expression prediction frameworks using GTEx data have been published by the GTEx Consortium and other studies, confirming its representativeness and suitability for this type of modeling.
dataset.availability: The data used in this study, including the example data splits generated using 5-fold cross-validation (folds.rds), as well as the paired expression data (frontal cortex–blood), pre-trained models, and selected feature sets for each fold, are publicly available in the project repository on GitLab (https://gitlab.com/csbayrak/ips). A permanent snapshot of the repository is also archived on Zenodo (https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.17477449) to ensure long-term accessibility. All data and accompanying files are released under the Creative Commons CC0 (Public Domain Dedication) license, allowing unrestricted use, distribution, and reproduction.

model.interpretability: The models we used are interpretable. For example, in a linear regression model predicting brain gene expression, a positive coefficient for a blood gene indicates higher expression of that blood gene is associated with higher expression of the target brain gene. In elastic net model, non-zero coefficients identify most informative features. Additionally, since we explore multiple feature selection strategies, one can inspect which blood genes, PCs, or network modules are driving the prediction, allowing biological interpretation.
model.duration:
Running prediction using only the best performing pre-trained model takes about 20-45 seconds depending on the system. 
macOS Sonoma 14.8.1, Apple Silicon (aarch64), R 4.4.1: elapsed time ≈ 20 seconds using the best model
Rocky Linux 9.4, x86_64, R 4.4.1: elapsed time ≈ 35 seconds 
Windows 11 10.0.26200, Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-1065G7 CPU @ 1.30GHz, R 4.4.1: elapsed time ≈ 45 seconds
model.availability: Yes, the source code for an illustrative example, along with the input files, is publicly available on GitLab: https://gitlab.com/csbayrak/ips. To facilitate reproducibility, a Docker image containing the full computational environment and all required R packages is provided. This allows users to run the prediction pipeline without manually installing dependencies. The Docker image can be pulled from the GitLab container registry (or built locally from the repository).

optimization.algorithm: The modeling framework is based on supervised regression, using two standard machine learning algorithms: linear regression (lm() R function) and elastic net regression (implemented via the glmnet() R package). Both are well-established, widely used methods.
optimization.config: For the elastic net models, the hyperparameters α (mixing between L1 and L2 penalties) and λ (regularization strength) were optimized using cross-validation within the training set. Specifically, α values were scanned from 0 to 1 in increments of 0.1, and for each α, λ was selected using cv.glmnet() with 10-fold cross-validation. If elastic net failed to converge, α was set to 0 (ridge regression) and λ re-optimized with 20-fold cross-validation. Linear regression models did not have hyperparameters. All trained model objects, along with the selected features and data folds for the example gene and tissue pair (frontal cortex–blood), are available in the GitLab repository (https://gitlab.com/csbayrak/ips) and are archived on Zenodo (https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.17477449).
optimization.encoding: Gene expression data were obtained as raw read counts from the GTEx RNA-seq dataset, transformed to log2(counts per million). Then, a linear model was applied to adjust for the covariates. Subsequently, the data went through the Z-transform algorithm to center it to zero, std=1 and  limit the expression to -4 < expression < 4.
optimization.features:
The input features (f) correspond to blood gene expression variables or their derived representations (e.g., principal components or module eigengenes). Because multiple feature selection strategies were evaluated, f varied across models.
Feature selection was performed independently within each training subset of the 5-fold cross-validation to prevent data leakage. Specifically:  (i) Unsupervised selection: Dimensionality reduction via PCA on the blood, using 40–120 principal components or explained-variance thresholds of 80–95%. (ii) Supervised selection: Filtering by Pearson correlation between blood gene expression and target brain gene expression (|ρ| > 0.2, 0.25, or 0.3). (iii) Network-based selection: Extraction of eigengenes or top PCs from blood co-expression modules (top 2, 5, 10 PCs or those explaining 70–85% variance). The total number of selected features (f) varied depending on the method and thresholds used, typically ranging from a few dozen to several hundred features per model. Feature selection was performed using only the training data within each cross-validation fold; the same selected features were then applied to the corresponding hold-out (test) data.
optimization.fitting: For each gene-specific model, the number of parameters typically ranged from tens to several hundred, while the number of training samples per fold was 80% of the total 152 individuals (~122 samples). Thus, in some models, p was comparable to or slightly smaller than the number of training points. To prevent overfitting, linear regression was only applied when p<1000, elastic net was applied for larger p, automatically shrinking less informative coefficients.
optimization.parameters: Because we applied multiple feature selection strategies, p varied across models, typically ranging from tens to several hundred parameters per gene-specific model.
optimization.regularization: All models were trained using 5-fold cross-validation, feature selection was performed exclusively on the training subset of each fold, elastic net was used for larger number of features, linear regression was applied when the number of features is small.

evaluation.method: The average correlation across the five folds was used as the primary performance metric
evaluation.measure: The primary metric reported is the Pearson correlation coefficient (r) between predicted and observed brain gene expression values.
evaluation.comparison: We compared our method to BrainGENIE, a recently developed approach that predicts brain gene expression from blood using the top 40 principal components of blood transcriptome data. For the same tissue pair, we applied our pipeline using the same dataset and evaluated performance using the 5-fold cross-validation framework. This comparison demonstrates the impact of our multi-strategy feature selection relative to a simpler baseline using only top PCs.
evaluation.confidence: Performance metrics are reported as the average Pearson correlation coefficient across the five cross-validation folds. Although exact confidence intervals were not computed, the distribution of correlations across folds provides an indication of variability and robustness. To assess superiority relative to baselines (e.g., BrainGENIE using top 40 blood PCs), the average correlations across folds were compared, showing consistently higher performance for our method.
evaluation.availability: Data splits (folds.rds), paired input data (frontal cortex-blood), pre-trained models for each fold, selected feature sets for each fold, evaluation outputs such as predicted vs observed values and correlation values are included in the GitLab repo https://gitlab.com/csbayrak/ips  and released under CC0 license.

publication.title: Extending Protein Language Models to a Viral Genomic Scale Using Biologically Induced Sparse Attention
publication.authors: Thibaut Dejean; Barbra D. Ferrell; William Harrigan; Zachary D. Schreiber; Rajan Sawhney; K. Eric Wommack; Shawn W. Polson; Mahdi Belcaid

dataset.provenance:
What is the source of the data (database, publication, direct experiment)?

NCBI Virus database (retrieved June 2024): 14,436 complete viral genomes totaling 683 million amino acids. Metadata labels from (i) NCBI taxonomy (species/family), and (ii) Pfam domain families via HMMER3 against Pfam 35.0. Validation of protein-protein interactions used the STRING database (146 interactions across 5 viral genomes). The list of loci is available in the GitHub repository.

If data are in classes, how many data points are available in each class?

Multiple classification tasks evaluated:
- Species classification (proteins): 5 to 100 species classes using 100,000 proteins from 5,000 genomes
- Species classification (genomes): Variable species classes from genome embeddings
- PPI binary classification: 146 validated interactions from STRING (positive cases) vs. non-interacting pairs (negative cases not explicitly quantified)

If regression, how many real value points are there?

Not applicable. 

Has the dataset been previously used by other papers and/or is it recognized by the community?

The NCBI Virus database is well-established and community-recognized. However, this specific dataset configuration which uses the complete viral genomes as multi-protein sequences with preserved genomic order, deduplicated at 90% identity, and genome-level splitting is novel for protein language modeling.
dataset.splits:
1. "How many data points are in the training and test sets?"

  Training:
  - 14,436 viral genomes (NCBI Virus database, June 2024)
  - Multiple training epochs with different masking patterns

  Test (varies by evaluation task):
  - Language modeling validation: ~1,400-2,800 genomes (10-20% of training set)
  - Fine-tuning validation: 83 genomes (PolA/RNR/HEL)
  - Classification/clustering: 100 genomes
  - PPI prediction: 6,789 genomes analyzed, 146 validated interactions

  2. "Was a separate validation set used, and if yes, how large was it?"

  During Model Training:
  Yes, a validation set was used during fine-tuning (10% of the data) 

For Downstream Evaluation:
Yes, multiple validation/test sets were used:

- 83 viral genomes containing PolA, RNR, and HEL proteins for interaction validation 
- 100,000 proteins from 5,000 genomes for classification tasks after deduplication, evaluated with 10-fold cross-validation
- 146 annotated interactions across 5 viral genomes from the STRING database for PPI validation.

  3. "Are the distributions of data types in the training and test sets different?"

  Yes and No, depending on the task:

  For Language Modeling (No):
  Both training and test sets come from the same source (NCBI Virus database, June 2024), so taxonomic and sequence length distributions are expected
  to be similar. However, genome-wise stratified splits at the species level were used; this  maintained proportional representation of different species across all three sets, which implies the distributions of data types (species, viral families, etc.) should be similar across training, validation, and test sets.

  For Downstream Tasks (Yes, by design):

  1. Fine-tuning Validation (83 genomes):
    - Intentionally different: Selected specifically to contain PolA, RNR, and HEL proteins
    - Bias: Enriched for DNA replication proteins
    - Purpose: Validate attention mechanism on known interacting proteins
  2. Classification/Clustering (100 genomes):
    - Intentionally different: One genome per species (maximizes taxonomic diversity)
    - Bias: Balanced species representation
    - Purpose: Test generalization across diverse viral families
  3. PPI Validation (146 interactions):
    - Intentionally different: Only 5 genomes with known STRING interactions
    - Bias: Limited to well-studied viral species with experimental PPI data
    - Purpose: Benchmark against ground truth

  4. "Are the distributions of data types in both training and test sets plotted?"

  No, distribution plots are not provided in the current manuscript or repository.
dataset.redundancy:
How were the sets split?
Genome-wise stratified splits at the species level: 80% train, 10% validation, 10% test.
Are the training and test sets independent?
Yes, strictly independent. No genome or protein appears in more than one split.
How was this enforced (for example, redundancy reduction to less than X% pairwise identity)?
Enforced through two mechanisms:
Genome-wise splitting (entire genomes assigned to single splits only)
CD-HIT redundancy reduction at 90% identity (primary dataset) and 50% identity (secondary dataset) thresholds

How does the distribution compare to previously published ML datasets?
Unlike existing protein language model datasets (e.g., ESM-2 trained on UniRef50 individual proteins), this dataset preserves complete genomic contexts with proteins in native genomic order. Context length up to 61,000 amino acids covers 98% of all sequenced viral genomes in NCBI virus database, versus typical single-protein models limited to 1,024-2,048 amino acids.
dataset.availability:
Yes.

  Location: https://github.com/Hawaii-Bioinformatics/ViralEmbed
  License: MIT (code), CC0 (data)

  All training data (14,436 genomes), test data (100 genomes), and validation data (83 genomes) are in the paper_data/ directory. Data split logic is 
  in src/classifier/classifier.py with seed=42 for reproducibility.

model.interpretability: Blackbox
model.output: pLM is a masked language model (MLM), it performs token-level classification to predict masked amino acids but objective is learn latent representations (embeddings)
model.duration: ~ Seconds on a A6000 GPU
model.availability: Source code released under MIT License (See: https://github.com/Hawaii-Bioinformatics/ViralEmbed/blob/main/LICENSE.md)

optimization.algorithm:
Transformer-based protein language model with masked language modeling objective.

While the core architecture is a standard transformer, this model introduces a novel biologically-informed sparse attention mechanism. It was chosen over alternatives because:

1. Standard transformers using for protein modeling (e.g., ESM-2) are limited to short contexts (1024 aa) and cannot process multiple proteins simultaneously
2. Context-agnostic sparse attention methods (Longformer, BigBird, LongLoRA) use predetermined patterns that ignore biological relationships between proteins
3. Context-aware methods (Routing Transformer) rely solely on sequence similarity clustering and miss functionally related but structurally distinct protein pairs
4. This approach incorporates computationally inferred protein-protein interactions as sparsity priors, reducing memory from quadratic to manageable levels while maintaining biological relevance

The method enables processing entire viral genomes (up to 61,000 aa) on a single commodity GPU while capturing long-range inter-protein dependencies missed by existing approaches.
optimization.meta:
The model uses output from ESM-2 (a pretrained protein language model) in two ways:
1. Attention scores from a fine-tuned ESM-2 model are used to identify putative protein-protein interactions, which guide the sparse attention patterns during training
2. LV-5B model is initialized with pretrained ESM-2 weights (650M parameters) before training with sparse attention

Is it clear that training data of initial predictors and meta-predictor are independent of test data for the meta-predictor?

Yes. The putative protein-protein interactions are inferred separately for each genome fragment using the same computational method (attention-based scoring). The genome-level train/validation/test split ensures no genome appears in multiple splits, maintaining independence. The interaction inference method is applied uniformly across all splits rather than using precomputed interactions from training data.
optimization.config: Yes. All materials are available at https://github.com/Hawaii-Bioinformatics/ViralEmbed  Available materials include: - Source code for model training and inference - Long-context inference scripts - Pair-ranking utilities - Example input data (test viral proteome FASTA and protein-labels files) - Worked "realistic use case" notebook  Hyperparameters reported in paper: - Learning rates: 3×10^-4 (LV-3C), 3×10^-5 (LV-5B) - Training epochs: 12 - Block size: 32 amino acids - Context lengths: up to 61,000 aa (LV-3C), up to 48,000 aa (LV-5B) - Hardware: NVIDIA A6000 GPU (48GB RAM)  MIT License (OSI-approved)
optimization.encoding: Amino acid sequences tokenized at residue level. Genomes segmented at protein boundaries, then subdivided into 32 amino acid blocks. Potein interactions mapped to block-level pairs to guide attention patterns
optimization.features:
Input vocabulary: 20 standard amino acids plus special tokens (separator, padding, mask, etc.) and 30 tokens total

Embedding dimension: 1280 (standard for ESM-2 650M, which LV-5B inherits and LV-3C likely matches for architectural consistency)

Raw amino acid sequences are used directly without engineered features or feature selection. The model learns representations end-to-end from tokenized sequences.

If yes, was it performed using the training set only?

Not applicable
optimization.fitting: 1. Separate validation set used (10% of data) during training with genome-level stratified splitting  2. Perplexity monitored across multiple sequence lengths (500-20,000 aa)  3. Multiple independent evaluation tasks:    - Clustering quality via silhouette scores    - 10-fold cross-validation for classification tasks    - External validation against STRING database (146 interactions not used in training)     4. Performance evaluated on held-out test genomes (10% split) that share no proteins with training data  5. Consistency across different downstream tasks (taxonomy classification, Pfam domain prediction, PPI validation) suggests learned representations generalize beyond training data  The combination of held-out validation, external database validation, and performance across diverse tasks provides evidence against overfitting despite the large parameter count.
optimization.parameters:
The model (transformer) has 650M parameters (inherited from ESM-2 650M initialization)
The base model was chosen as one of the most widely adopted and effective protein language models. The focus was on achieving computational tractability for whole-viral genome processing on a single GPU.
optimization.regularization: Yes, several techniques were used:  1. Validation set monitoring: 10% validation split with genome-level stratification to prevent data leakage 2. Dropout: Applied during sparse attention computation  3. Data deduplication: CD-HIT at 90% identity threshold reduces training set redundancy and over-representation 4. Fixed training schedule: 12 epochs for both models

evaluation.method:
How was the method evaluated?

1. Cross-validation: 10-fold cross-validation for species classification tasks

2. External validation: 146 experimentally validated protein-protein interactions from STRING database (not used in training)

3. Multiple evaluation metrics:
   - Perplexity (language modeling performance)
   - Silhouette scores (clustering quality)
   - F1-scores and accuracy (classification tasks)
   - ROC-AUC (PPI prediction)

4. Multiple downstream tasks:
   - Taxonomic classification (species/family)
   - Pfam domain prediction
   - PPI validation
   - Genome embedding quality

5. Known biological interactions: Validated attention patterns against well-characterized protein interactions (PolA-RNR-HEL) in 83 viral genomes
evaluation.measure:
Which performance metrics are reported?

Language modeling:
- Perplexity: Lower values indicate better amino acid prediction

Embedding quality:
- Silhouette scores: Measures clustering coherence (higher is better)
- Pairwise Euclidean distances: Distribution analysis of embedding space

Classification:
- F1-score: Harmonic mean of precision and recall
- Accuracy: Overall classification correctness
- ROC-AUC: Area under receiver operating characteristic curve

Attention validation:
- Ranking positions: Relative rank of known protein pairs among all possible interactions
- Percentage of known interactions captured at different thresholds

Is this set representative?

Yes, these metrics are standard in protein language modeling literature.
evaluation.comparison:
Was a comparison to publicly available methods performed on benchmark datasets?

Yes. Comparisons made to:

Publicly available methods:
- ESM-2 (650M, pretrained and fine-tuned variants)
- Protein Set Transformer (PST)
- Context-agnostic sparse attention: Longformer, BigBird, LongLoRA


Was a comparison to simpler baselines performed?

Yes:

- ESM-2 pretrained (no fine-tuning): Simplest baseline using only preexisting knowledge
- ESM-2 with standard context extension
- Context-agnostic sparse attention patterns: Simpler than biology-informed attention
evaluation.confidence: Limited confidence intervals reported:  - ROC-AUC for PPI prediction: 0.66 with bootstrapped 95% CI [0.56, 0.75]  Are the results statistically significant to claim superiority? No formal statistical tests were used.   Evidence for better performance is based on: - Consistent performance differences across multiple metrics and tasks - Cross-validation results - Single confidence interval for PPI prediction shows statistically significant performance (CI does not include 0.5 baseline)
evaluation.availability: - Statistical code: Fully available in GitHub under MIT license - Baseline comparison code: Available throughout repository - Raw evaluation outputs: Can be generated by running provided scripts, but pre-computed results are not committed to the repository - Test/validation data: Available in paper_data/ and test_files/ under CC0 1.0 license - License: MIT (code) and CC0 1.0 (data)

publication.title: NetStart 2.0: prediction of eukaryotic translation initiation sites using a protein language model
publication.authors: Line Sandvad Nielsen, Anders Gorm Pedersen, Ole Winther, Henrik Nielsen

dataset.provenance:
RefSeq-assembled genomes and corresponding annotation data from NCBI’s Eukaryotic Genome Annotation Pipeline Database. 
The final dataset, distributed across five partitions, contains 9 912 708 sequences, of which 1 162 194 are positive (having a translation initiation sites) and 8 750 514 are negative (not having a translation initiation site).
dataset.splits: Data was stratified on a per-species basis and partitioned using GraphPart (10.1093/nargab/lqad088).
dataset.redundancy: Data was partitioned using GraphPart (10.1093/nargab/lqad088). The authors used MMseqs2 for alignment and chose a pairwise identity threshold of 50% (10.1038/nbt.3988).
dataset.availability: Training and test data are available in the web server: https://services.healthtech.dtu.dk/services/NetStart-2.0/

model.interpretability: Interpretable - in the article authors delve a lot into the interpretation of the learned
model.duration: Seconds.
model.availability: The model is available as a web server (https://services.healthtech.dtu.dk/services/NetStart-2.0/) and Python package (https://github.com/lsandvad/netstart2). The licence is: CC BY-NC-ND 4.0

optimization.algorithm: a deep learning metamodel trained on three types of concatened embeddings. Beside two custom embeddings, it also uses a pretrained protein language model ESM-2 (general class: transformer).
optimization.meta: The model uses pre-learned nucleic acid and species embeddings and ESM-2 embeddings
optimization.config: The model configuration is available at the repository: https://github.com/lsandvad/netstart2/tree/main/src/model_config. The licence is: CC BY-NC-ND 4.0

publication.title: PathoFact 2.0: An Integrative Pipeline for Antimicrobial Resistance Genes, Virulence Factors, Toxins, and Biosynthetic Gene Clusters Prediction in Metagenomes
publication.authors: Luis F. Delgado, Júlia Ortís Sunyer, Cedric C. Laczny, Oskar Hickl, May & Paul Wilmes

dataset.provenance:
There are two prediction modules: the VF prediction module and the toxin prediction module. Each module has 2 classes, positive and control.

Control datasets:
The “non-pathogenic” dataset for the ML models was constructed by selecting SwissProt sequences lacking ARG, VF, and toxin keywords [KW-0568 (pathogenesis-related protein), KW-0843 (virulence), KW-0800 (toxin), KW-0046 (antibiotic resistance), KW-9995 (disease)] and restricted to bacteria (taxonomy_id 2), archaea (taxonomy_id 2157), fungi (taxonomy_id 4751), and viruses (taxonomy_id 10239). Additionally, proteins from non-pathogenic organisms to humans  were included from NCBI. MMseqs2 (version 15.6f452) was used to obtain a set of dereplicated protein sequences. We acknowledge that, although there is no standard for creating negative datasets, they play a crucial role in influencing model performance. Therefore, to improve the quality of our “non-toxin” dataset, potential ARGs, VFs (with high probability), and toxins were filtered out of the “non-pathogenic” dataset using PathoFact 1.0 predictions. The “non-toxin” consists of 213,130 non-redundant protein sequences. To create the “non-VF” dataset for the ML VF model, we filtered out any potential VFs (with high and low probabilities), ARGs, and toxins based on PathoFact 1.0 predictions from the “non-pathogenic” dataset. This resulted in a dataset consisting of 41,774 VF protein sequences. 

Positive datasets:
For the toxin related dataset curated training data was obtained from SwissProt, filtered for bacterial (taxonomy_id 2), archaeal (taxonomy_id 2157), fungal (taxonomy_id 4751) and viral (taxonomy_id 10239) toxin sequences (KW-0800, toxin). The dataset was supplemented with entries from toxin-specific databases such as the Toxin Exposome Database (T3DB), which catalogues bacterial protein toxins; the Database for Bacterial ExoToxins (DBETH); TADB version 3.0, which includes protein sequences of bacterial toxin–antitoxin (TA) pairs from types I to VIII; sequences from SecReT6, encompassing T6SS gene cluster components, T6SS regulator (T6SR), accessory proteins (T6SA), effectors (T6SE), and immunity proteins (T6SI); and the prokaryotic antimicrobial toxins (PAT) database. MMseqs2 (version 15.6f452) was used to dereplicate the dataset of 1,112,357 protein sequences (100% identity and coverage), yielding 213,363 unique protein sequences, corresponding to the “toxin-related” dataset. 

For the VF dataset, training data was derived from SwissProt, selecting sequences annotated with the virulence keyword (KW-0843) and expanded using the Virulence Factor Database (VFDB). After dereplication (with 100% identity and coverage), the original set of 32,511 sequences, using MMseqs2, comprised 30,695 non-redundant sequences, corresponding to the “VF dataset”.
dataset.splits:
30,695 VF protein sequences: 24,558 train dataset and 6,137 test dataset
41,774 non-VF protein sequences: 33,416 train dataset and 8,358 test dataset
213,363 toxin protein sequences: 170,789 train dataset and 42,574 test dataset
213,129 non-toxin protein sequences: 170,427 train dataset and 42,702 test dataset
dataset.redundancy: The ML model was trained using an 80/20 split of the dataset, with 80% for training and 20% for testing. The Synthetic Minority Oversampling Technique (SMOTE) was employed to address the dataset's imbalance. The non-pathogenic dataser was dereplicated using 40% identity and 80% coverage while the positive datasets (for VF and toxins) were dereplicated with 100% identity and 100% coverage.
dataset.availability: Yes, they are. They are found in Zenodo https://zenodo.org/records/17593961

model.interpretability: We used RandomForest and XGBoost models, from which the feature importance can be extracted.
model.duration: 500 protein sequences take 3.7s to run on 1 CPU and 1.8s on 8 CPUs.
model.availability: Yes, it is. It can be found in https://gitlab.com/uniluxembourg/lcsb/systems-ecology/pathofact2. The license is GNU General Public License v3.0 or Later

optimization.algorithm:
Several ML models were built using Scikit-learn (version 1.5.2; [34] and tested: RandomForest (RF) and XGBoost, using k-mers 3 to 8 or protein sequence composition features (amino acid composition (AAC), dipeptide composition (DPC), composition (CTDC), transition (CTDT), and distribution (CTDD) [35]) as features. Hyperparameter optimisation was performed, using a 5-fold cross-validation with HalvingGridSearchCV from scikit-learn [34]. The best-performing model was selected based on the Matthews correlation coefficient (MCC) score.
The Toxin ML model is a RF with 5-mer features (default hyperparameter setting: n_estimators=100,max_depth=None, min_samples_split=2). The VF model is a XGBoost with protein sequence composition features (learning_rate': 0.1, 'n_estimators': 2000).
optimization.config: Yes, the hyperparameter configurations are in the paper while the model files are in zenodo (https://zenodo.org/records/14192463)
optimization.encoding: We dereplicated the data to remove identical sequences from the datasets.
optimization.features:
For VFs there are 663 features and for toxins there are 2587847. However, the maximum number of features per sequence depends on the size of the sequence minus 4.
We did not perform feature selection for the VF model as the features are already defined. For the toxin module with k-mer 5 we tested several algorithms for feature selection however the best performance (evaluated on the test dataset) was without feature selection.
optimization.fitting: The VF and toxin-related modules were evaluated across various probability thresholds on the entire test dataset and on subsets of the test dataset. These subset datasets were created based on sequence similarity to the training dataset, with a range of 40% to 100% similarity and 80% coverage. This approach aimed to assess prediction accuracy on proteins in the testing dataset with low similarity to the training dataset, specifically including only sequences with less than 40-100% identity to any training sequence, to minimize overfitting. This way we selected the probability cut-offs.
optimization.parameters: The Toxin ML model is a RF with 5-mer features (default hyperparameter setting: n_estimators=100,max_depth=None, min_samples_split=2). The VF model is a XGBoost with protein sequence composition features (learning_rate': 0.1, 'n_estimators': 2000).
optimization.regularization: No, we did not.

evaluation.method: The VF and toxin-related modules were evaluated across various probability thresholds on the entire test dataset and on subsets of the test dataset. These subset datasets were created based on sequence similarity to the training dataset, with a range of 40% to 100% similarity and 80% coverage. This approach aimed to assess prediction accuracy on proteins in the testing dataset with low similarity to the training dataset, specifically including only sequences with less than 40-100% identity to any training sequence. The performance evaluation is based on the Matthew correlation coefficient (MCC) and the precision (to reduce the number of false positive VF and toxin-related predictions), taking into account the dataset imbalance (a higher number of “non-toxin” and “non-VF” sequences compared to “toxin-related” and “VF” sequences in the test subsets). The MCC is a more reliable statistical measure that yields a high score only when the prediction performs well across all four categories of the confusion matrix (true positives, false negatives, true negatives, and false positives), and it is proportional to both the number of positive and negative elements in the dataset.  We found that probabilities of 0.9 for VFs and 0.6 for toxins provide a good balance between high MCC and precision across different test subsets.
evaluation.measure: We report Matthews Correlation Coefficient (MCC), recall, F1 score and precision. Yes, we compare it to literature, we did benchmarking against two state of the art tools that predict VF (VirulentHunter) and toxins (ToxinPred2) respectively.
evaluation.comparison: Yes, they are. They are compared to VirulentHunter and ToxinPred2.
evaluation.confidence: The VF and toxin-related modules were evaluated across various probability thresholds on the entire test dataset and on subsets of the test dataset. These subset datasets were created based on sequence similarity to the training dataset, with a range of 40% to 100% similarity and 80% coverage. This approach aimed to assess prediction accuracy on proteins in the testing dataset with low similarity to the training dataset, specifically including only sequences with less than 40-100% identity to any training sequence.
evaluation.availability: Yes, they are found in the paper

publication.title: Generalizable machine learning models for rapid antimicrobial resistance prediction in unseen healthcare settings
publication.authors: Diane Duroux, Paul P. Meyer, Giovanni Visonà, Niko Beerenwinkel

dataset.provenance:
The publicly available DRIAMS dataset [1] consists of MALDI-TOF mass spectrometry data collected from patients in the Swiss healthcare system. This dataset includes data from four distinct diagnostic laboratories, collected from 2015 to 2018: University Hospital Basel (designated as DRIAMS-A), Cantonal Hospital Basel-Land (DRIAMS-B), Cantonal Hospital Aarau (DRIAMS-C), and the Viollier laboratory service provider (DRIAMS-D). The MALDI-TOF mass spectra used in this project were originally published as part of the study by Weis et al. [2]. This dataset is widely recognized within the microbiology community and has been utilized in several subsequent studies.

[1] Weis, C., et al. "DRIAMS: database of resistance information on antimicrobials and MALDI-TOF mass spectra." Dryad, dataset (2021).
[2] Weis et al., "Direct antimicrobial resistance prediction from clinical MALDI-TOF mass spectra using machine learning" (Nature Medicine, 28(1), 2022, pp. 164–174)
dataset.splits:
In total, 631,167 observations were leveraged: 11,610 in A2015; 138,132 in A2016; 179,334 in A2017; 123,558 in A2018; 32,377 in B2018, 47,586 in C2018; and 98,570 in D2018. 
Two main data splits were created: 
1. Hospital zero-shot split: Select data from the DRIAMS dataset collected in 2018. Let i, j ∈ {A, B, C, D} represent the hospitals in the dataset. Train the model on data from hospital i. Test the model on data from hospital j, where j!= i.
2. Year zero-shot split: Select data from the DRIAMS A. Let i, j ∈ {2015, 2016, 2017, 2018} represent the year of data collection. Train the model on data from year i. Test the model on data from year j, where j!= i.
dataset.redundancy: To prevent data leakage, each data split was designed so that no pathogen appeared in both the training and test sets. In each split, the test set was drawn under a different condition: a different hospital in the hospital zero-shot setting, and a different year in the year zero-shot setting.
dataset.availability: The MALDI-TOF spectra used in this project can be obtained by downloading the DRIAMS dataset from https://doi.org/10.5061/dryad.bzkh1899q. The accompanying metadata includes information on the hospital and year of data collection, necessary to reproduce the splits.

model.interpretability: The model is black box.
model.duration: Inference for a single spectrum-antimicrobial combination takes less than 1 second to run on a desktop PC.
model.availability: The source code used to train the models and generate the results presented in this study is publicly available at https://github.com/DianeDuroux/ZeroShotAMR. The project is released under the GNU General Public License v3.0 (GPL-3.0).

optimization.algorithm:
In Visona et al. [1], three primary models are explored: (1) encodings derived by applying principal component analysis to mass spectra and chemical fingerprints, which are concatenated and used as input for a logistic regression model; (2) joint representations generated by Siamese networks, subsequently utilized as input for logistic regression to predict resistance; and (3) a classification Multi-Layer Perceptron (MLP) with Residual Skip-Connections. Building on the findings of Visona et al. [1], which identified the MLP with Residual Skip-Connections [2] as achieving the highest performance, we trained this network to predict the probability of resistance for antimicrobial-spectrum pairs.

[1] Visonà, Giovanni, et al. "Multimodal learning in clinical proteomics: enhancing antimicrobial resistance prediction models with chemical information." Bioinformatics 39.12 (2023): btad717.
[2] Szegedy, Christian, et al. "Inception-v4, inception-resnet and the impact of residual connections on learning." Proceedings of the AAAI conference on artificial intelligence. Vol. 31. No. 1. 2017.
optimization.meta:
We compare two pathogen representations: binned MALDI-TOF mass spectra and encodings generated by masked autoencoders (MAEs). 

We compare three types of antimicrobial representations: traditional molecular fingerprints, encodings generated by Molformer transformer-based model for molecular representation learning [1], and SELF-referencing embedded strings (Selfies) [2].

[1] Ross, Jerret, et al. "Large-scale chemical language representations capture molecular structure and properties." Nature Machine Intelligence 4.12 (2022): 1256-1264.
[2] Krenn, Mario, et al. "Self-referencing embedded strings (SELFIES): A 100% robust molecular string representation." Machine Learning: Science and Technology 1.4 (2020): 045024.
optimization.config: The code used to train the models (including the hyperparameter configurations) and generate the results presented in this study is publicly available at https://github.com/DianeDuroux/ZeroShotAMR. Pretrained model weights can be accessed via the GigaDB repository. The project is released under the GNU General Public License v3.0 (GPL-3.0).
optimization.encoding: Data bias exists within DRIAMS-A due to one particular workstation (HospitalHygene), where samples were captured using a different medium and skewed heavily toward resistant samples. Following Weis et al. [1], we excluded data from this workstation to mitigate potential biases. The spectra were binned using a bin size of 3 m/z units. The encodings defined in the section above were used. [1] Weis et al., "Direct antimicrobial resistance prediction from clinical MALDI-TOF mass spectra using machine learning" (Nature Medicine, 28(1), 2022, pp. 164–174)
optimization.features: Different encoding strategies are evaluated (as described above), each resulting in a different number of input features. None of the encoding techniques leverage the resistance/susceptibility outcome during feature construction. The total number of features varies from 1,280 (MAE embeddings of dimension 512 combined with Molformer embeddings of dimension 768) to 30,160 (6000-dimensional spectra combined with 24,160-dimensional SELFIES encodings).
optimization.fitting: The number of parameters is larger than the number of training points. Overfitting was addressed through early stopping, dropout, weight decay, and validation monitoring (see below)
optimization.parameters: The input projections encodes the MALDI TOF spectra and the antimicrobials encodings into 512-dimensional vectors, which are then concatenated. The model consists of 5 residual blocks, including ReLU activation, a linear layer of dimensionality 1024, a dropout layer with probability 0.2, and a BatchNorm layer. The ResMLP is trained with early stopping with a patience parameter of 10 epochs using an Adam optimiser with a learning rate of 3∗10−4 and a weight decay of 10−5. With the 6000-dimensional binned MALDI-TOF mass spectra and Morgan molecular fingerprints, the ResMLP model has 218M trainable parameters.
optimization.regularization: Early stopping was employed to halt training if the validation loss did not improve in consecutive epochs, preventing the model from over-optimizing on the training set. Additional regularization was introduced via dropout within residual blocks (with a probability of 0.2) and weight decay (L2 regularization with a factor of 1e-5) to discourage overly complex models. The best model was selected based on validation performance, ensuring generalizability.

evaluation.method: The method was evaluated under two zero-shot settings: hospital zero-shot and year zero-shot, using four data splits for each scenario.
evaluation.measure: We report three standard classification metrics for imbalanced data: area under the precision-recall curve (AUPRC), balanced accuracy, and Matthews Correlation Coefficient (MCC).
evaluation.comparison:
We use as baseline, the best model of Visona et al.  [1], which utilizes a 6000-dimensional binned MALDI-TOF mass spectra vector representation for pathogens and Morgan fingerprints for antimicrobial representations.

[1] Visonà, Giovanni, et al. "Multimodal learning in clinical proteomics: enhancing antimicrobial resistance prediction models with chemical information." Bioinformatics 39.12 (2023): btad717.
evaluation.confidence: We provide error bars representing standard deviation across training sets.
evaluation.availability: The raw evaluation files are not available.

UK Biobank data are available following an access application process. For more information see https://www.ukbiobank.ac.uk/enable-your-research/apply-for-access. This research was performed under UK Biobank Application Number 50474.

publication.title: EEG-Based Dataset Explicitly Targets the Transitions between Sitting and Standing for Exploring Neural Activation Patterns in Motor Imagery and Execution
publication.authors: Benjakarn Uengsawapak, Supavit Kongwudhikunakorn, Suktipol Kiatthaveephong, Wipamas Polpakdee, Rattanaphon Chaisaen, Poramate Manoonpong, Chanitsada Chuenchit, Gun Bhakdisongkhram, Theerawit Wilaiprasitporn

dataset.provenance: The data was obtained from our designed experiment protocol. 60-channel electroencephalograph (EEG) was obtained from 23 participants performed motor imagery (MI) and motor execution (ME) of lower limb movements, particularly sit-stand movement task. This dataset consisted of 2 classes: sit-to-stand and stand-to-sit movements. The participant performed 40 trials of each class, in total of 80 rounds for both classes.
dataset.splits: To validate the classification of the dataset, leave-one-subject-out cross-validation technique was used. Out of EEG recordings from 22 subjects, the data from 21 subjects were used to train and validate the model, while the data from 1 subject was left out as an unseen testing set. This process was repeated until the data from all subjects were used as a testing set.
dataset.redundancy: We used leave-one-subject-out cross-validation to ensure that the training and testing sets are independent.
dataset.availability:
Raw data https://zenodo.org/records/17561969
Preprocessed data https://zenodo.org/records/17629950

model.interpretability: No
model.duration: Inference time for a single sample took around 0.06 - 0.14 second when ran on high-performance computing cluster.
model.availability: No

optimization.algorithm: EEGNet model was used.
optimization.config: The parameters settings of EEGNet-8,2 are set as follows: number of filters in the first layer $F1=8$, depth parameter $D=2$, kernel size $C1=200$, number of classes $n_{class}=2$, dropout rate $dropout=0.5$. The optimal batch size $b$ and learning rate $lr$ are set to be $b=8$ and $lr=1\times10^{-3}$, respectively.
optimization.encoding: The 60-channel EEG recordings were first filtered with a second-order Butterworth bandpass filter with a 0.2 to 3 Hz cutoff frequencies. Subsequently, the signals were downsampled to 250 Hz. To remove artifacts, independent component analysis (ICA) was performed to decompose independent components (ICs) and eliminate muscle- and eye-related artifacts, using recorded EMG and EOG signals to assist the ICA process.  Following, signals from identified bad channels were removed and interpolated using data from neighboring electrodes.  To mitigate volume conduction effects and enhance spatial resolution, the Current Source Density (CSD) transformation was applied.  Finally, the preprocessed signals were segmented into 4-second epochs ranging from -2 to 2 seconds relative to an onset of EMG trigger event (indicating T=0).
optimization.features:
Time series were used as input with length
The data input shape to train and validate the model is $n_{subject}-1 \times n_{trial} \times n_{channel} \times n_{timept}$, while the data input shape to test the model is $1 \times n_{trial} \times n_{channel} \times n_{timepts}$, where $n_{subject}$ represents total number of subjects, $n_{trial}$ represents total number of trials that each subject performed, $n_{channel}$ represents total number of EEG channels, $n_{timepts}$ represents length of EEG samples.
optimization.fitting: No.
optimization.parameters: n/a
optimization.regularization: Early stopping

evaluation.method: Leave-one-subject-out cross validation
evaluation.measure: Performance are reported in terms of accuracy and F1-score.
evaluation.comparison: No, this study focuses on validate the correctness of the collected data by employing EEGNet, a state-of-the-art and widely used model, to perform classification.
evaluation.confidence: Yes.
evaluation.availability: Raw data https://zenodo.org/records/17561969 Preprocessed data https://zenodo.org/records/17629950
