optimization.algorithm: PASNet (Pathway-Associated Sparse Network) that utilize biological priors from pathway databases, enhancing both predictive performance and pathway-level interpretability
optimization.meta: The algorithm used the activity matrices that extracted from the NetBID2 (part of the workflow), alongside with a table indicating whether the drivers participated in such of pathways from pathway enrichment with Gene Ontology (GO), Reactome, KEGG, and Wikipathway.
optimization.config: The model configuration is available at the repository: https://github.com/BiodataAnalysisGroup/lncAPNet
optimization.encoding: PASNet is applied to activity data, where each feature represents the activity level of a gene and is typically encoded as a continuous numerical value. To incorporate biological knowledge, genes are mapped to relevant pathways using established databases. This pathway information is then used in PASNet to impose sparse connections in the network, allowing the model to capture pathway-specific patterns in the data.
optimization.features:
1st model - case study CLL - Gene Ontology:
To reduce noise and focus on the most relevant features, we retained the common statistically significant drivers present in both the ICGC and BloodCancerMultiOmics2017 datasets, as these shared drivers are expected to participate in the pathways identified in the enrichment analysis. In total, 297 features were used for model training.

2nd model - case study CLL - Reactome/KEGG/Wikipathway:
To reduce noise and focus on the most relevant features, we retained the common statistically significant drivers present in both the ICGC and BloodCancerMultiOmics2017 datasets, as these shared drivers are expected to participate in the pathways identified in the enrichment analysis. In total, 269 features were used for model training.

3rd model - case study PRAD - Gene Ontology:
To reduce noise and focus on the most relevant features, we retained the statistically significant drivers present in TCGA-PRAD datasets, as these drivers are expected to participate in the pathways identified in the enrichment analysis. In total, 1756 features were used for model training.

4th model - case study PRAD - Reactome/KEGG/Wikipathway:
To reduce noise and focus on the most relevant features, we retained the statistically significant drivers present in TCGA-PRAD datasets, as these drivers are expected to participate in the pathways identified in the enrichment analysis. In total, 1490 features were used for model training.
optimization.parameters:
Learning Rate (LR) and L2 regularization (L2), through griding search

1st model - case study CLL - Gene Ontology:
Optimal learning rate (LR = 0.005) and L2 regularization (L2 = 0.0005)

2nd model - case study CLL - Reactome/KEGG/Wikipathway:
Optimal learning rate (LR = 0.007) and L2 regularization (L2 = 0.0005)

3rd model - case study PRAD - Gene Ontology:
Optimal learning rate (LR = 0.01) and L2 regularization (L2 = 0.0003)

4th model - case study PRAD - Reactome/KEGG/Wikipathway:
Optimal learning rate (LR = 0.007) and L2 regularization (L2 = 0.0003)

evaluation.method:
1st case study - CLL [both GO and rest of the databases]:
Cross-validation and an independent dataset

2nd case study - PRAD [both GO and rest of the databases]:
Cross-validation
evaluation.measure:
AUC and F1 score

1st model - case study CLL - Gene Ontology:
AUC = 0.96, F1score =  0.84

2nd model - case study CLL - Reactome/KEGG/Wikipathway:
AUC = 0.96, F1score = 0.84

3rd model - case study PRAD - Gene Ontology:
AUC = 0.84, F1score = 0.78

4th model - case study PRAD - Reactome/KEGG/Wikipathway:
AUC = 0.79, F1score = 0.76
evaluation.confidence: No

publication.title: 2050271008@email.szu.edu.cn
publication.authors: Lulu Qin, Zhigang Pei, Xudong He, Jiarui Zhou, Xianhong Xu and Zexuan Zhu

dataset.provenance:
The CD47-IHCNuSC dataset originates from direct experimental annotations on whole-slide images (WSIs) of esophageal cancer tissues stained using CD47 immunohistochemistry (IHC). These slides were collected from Chongqing Jiangjin Hospital, and 102 high-resolution patches (1024×1024 pixels at 40× magnification) were extracted from 10 WSIs. Each patch was manually annotated by expert pathologists using a cross-stain verification strategy, guided by H&E-stained counterparts to enhance segmentation quality.

Nuclear annotations are classified into seven biologically meaningful categories:
	•	Positive-Tumor (PT): 7,647 nuclei (40.5%)
	•	Positive-Immune Related (PI): 5,594 nuclei (29.6%)
	•	Negative-Tumor (NT): 3,063 nuclei (16.2%)
	•	Negative-Immune Related (NI): 1,687 nuclei (8.9%)
	•	Negative-Stroma (NS): 464 nuclei (2.5%)
	•	Positive-Others (PO): 25 nuclei (0.13%)
	•	Negative-Others (NO): 3 nuclei (0.02%)

The dataset contains a total of 18,483 instance-level nuclear annotations, with segmentation masks and class labels. It is the first publicly released IHC nuclear segmentation dataset with subtype-rich labels for CD47.
dataset.splits:
The dataset is split into:
	•	Training set: 70 images, 15,204 nuclei
	•	Validation/Test set: 16 images, 3,279 nuclei

A separate validation set is indeed used, comprising 16 patches. The nuclear subtype distributions are consistent between the training and test sets and reflect the real-world tissue heterogeneity of IHC-stained esophageal cancer samples.
dataset.redundancy:
The data split was performed at the image level, ensuring that training and test patches are extracted from non-overlapping WSIs to prevent data leakage. Each of the patches comes from one of 10 WSIs, and care was taken to avoid overlap in tissue regions across splits.
This image-level split ensures that the training and test sets are non-redundant, with no overlapping regions between patches. Similar to well-established datasets such as NuCLS and Lizard, which also adopt patient- or slide-level separation, CD47-IHCNuSC adheres to strict cross-slide partitioning to enhance generalization and prevent data leakage.
dataset.availability:
CD47-IHCNuSC dataset—including all image data, instance-level annotations, and predefined training and testing splits—is publicly released at the following URL: https://github.com/LuluQin766/FPNuNet
. The dataset is accompanied by detailed metadata documentation, annotation format specifications, and usage instructions. A license file is also included in the repository, specifying the terms of use. This public release ensures full reproducibility and supports open benchmarking for nuclear segmentation and classification in CD47-stained IHC pathology images.

model.interpretability: FPNuNet is primarily a black-box deep learning model. Its interpretability is limited but partially supported by its structured outputs:  the binary segmentation mask, horizontal–vertical (HV) displacement fields, and per-pixel nuclear subtype maps are spatially aligned with the input image, providing human-interpretable visualizations of predicted nuclei, instance boundaries, and phenotype assignments.  These outputs offer practical interpretability at the prediction level, although the internal feature representations remain opaque.
model.output:
The model performs multi-task prediction, including:
classification (per-pixel nuclear subtype map, K = nuclear classes),
regression (horizontal–vertical displacement fields),
binary semantic segmentation (probability masks).
Thus, it produces both classification and regression outputs.
model.duration:
A single 128×128 patch inference on an NVIDIA RTX 4090 requires ≈18–25 ms, corresponding to real-time throughput at patch level.
Whole-slide prediction time depends on tiling density and batch size but is compatible with routine WSI processing.
model.availability: The full source code configuration files are released at:  GitHub: https://github.com/LuluQin766/FPNuNet

optimization.algorithm: FPNuNet uses pretrained encoders from other ML models (SAM for structural encoding and UNI for semantic encoding). Their pretrained data are independent of the CD47-IHCNuSC dataset used for fine-tuning, ensuring no overlap between pretraining and test data.
optimization.meta: FPNuNet uses pretrained encoders from other ML models (SAM for structural encoding and UNI for semantic encoding). Their pretrained data are independent of the CD47-IHCNuSC dataset used for fine-tuning, ensuring no overlap between pretraining and test data.
optimization.config: The complete code and configuration files are publicly available at GitHub: https://github.com/LuluQin766/FPNuNet  under an open-source license, including dataset splits and training details
optimization.encoding: Input images were processed as RGB channels. Patches of size 128×128 were extracted for training and normalized before model input.
optimization.features: Each image patch provides multi-scale visual features (spatial + frequency-domain) from both encoders. No manual feature selection was used; instead, learned attention and frequency filters automatically select informative features during training.
optimization.fitting: The model is high-dimensional (large p and f) relative to the dataset, so overfitting risk was mitigated by freezing large encoders, using data augmentation, regularization, and validation-based early stopping.
optimization.parameters:
FPNuNet contains 394 million total parameters, dominated by the pretrained SAM and UNI encoder backbones.
During training, only the fusion neck, skip-enhance modules, task decoders, and lightweight prompt-adapter layers are updated, resulting in 5.32 million trainable parameters (1.35%).
optimization.regularization: Overfitting prevention includes AdamW optimizer with weight decay = 0.1, learning rate warm-up + decay, frozen backbones, and data augmentation (flip, rotation, stain perturbation). Early stopping was applied based on validation loss trends.

evaluation.method: Fixed train/val/test split on the CD47-IHCNuSC dataset. Evaluation is instance-level: nuclei are matched by IoU with Hungarian assignment; type labels are taken by argmax on matched pairs.
evaluation.measure: Type-aware Panoptic Quality (mPQ with DQ/SQ decomposition), macro/micro/support-weighted Precision and F1, and per-class {PQ_inst, P_inst, R_inst, F1_inst}. This set follows common practice in nuclei segmentation/classification (e.g., HoVer-Net, SRSA-Net) and addresses class imbalance via macro/support-weighted averaging.
evaluation.comparison: We re-trained publicly available baselines (HoverNet, SRSA-Net) on CD47-IHCNuSC with identical protocols.
evaluation.confidence: No confidence intervals or formal significance tests are reported; results are point estimates. We therefore refrain from statistical superiority claims.
evaluation.availability: Dataset splits, code, and scripts to reproduce all metrics (including matching/assignment and confusion matrices) are publicly released at the project repository (see FPNuNet GitHub, https://github.com/LuluQin766/FPNuNet). Licensing is specified in the repository’s LICENSE file.

publication.title: pyRootHair: Machine Learning Accelerated Software for High-Throughput Phenotyping of Plant Root Hair Traits
publication.authors: Ian Tsang, Lawrence Percival-Alwyn, Stephen Rawsthorne, James Cockram, Fiona Leigh, Jonathan Atkinson

dataset.provenance: Dataset comprised of root images taken by myself. The total training dataset consisted of 83 images of varying dimensions, containing images from multiple plant species: Rice, Wheat, Arabidopsis, Maize, Medicago, Brachypodium.
dataset.splits: 83 images in the training split, and all images were used in validation. The test set comprised of > 200 images, from species including wheat, oat, tomato. For all the datasets described in the paper, the predicted output of the segmentation model was visually inspected for all images. An example of the model performance relative to manually annotated binary masks can be seen in Supp Figure 3 in the manuscript.
dataset.redundancy: Training sets were independent from the test sets. The model was trained multiple times, where upon discovering images that the model poorly segments, I then manually  curated binary masks for those images, and re-trained the model. Those test images would subsequently become part of the training set.
dataset.availability: All training images and corresponding ground truths (binary masks) have been uploaded to the Gigadb private dropbox.

model.interpretability: Model is interpretable. Model outputs segmentations of input images, which can be easily viewed and compared with the original image to determine segmentation performance.
model.duration: ~ 7 seconds per input image of ~ 2600 x 1500 x 3 pixels
model.availability: Model was trained according to instructions on nnUNet's github. Model is available on huggingface: https://huggingface.co/iantsang779/pyroothair_v1

optimization.algorithm: Convolutional Neural Network
optimization.config: Model plans available on huggingface: https://huggingface.co/iantsang779/pyroothair_v1/blob/main/plans.json
optimization.encoding: Images were z-score normalized across all 3 image channels and augmentation was automatically carried out. Full details are available in the nnUNet paper describing the image preprocessing steps: https://doi.org/10.1038/s41592-020-01008-z
optimization.features: 7 convolutional layers with the follwing number of feature maps: 32,64,128,256,512,512,512
optimization.fitting: NA
optimization.parameters: NA
optimization.regularization: NA

evaluation.method: Evaluated based on visual inspection of output binary masks.
evaluation.measure: nnUNet uses mean dice score during training to compute accuracy. I manually calculated IOU scores for a select group of testing images with manually annotated binary masks.
evaluation.comparison: NA
evaluation.confidence: NA

publication.title:
MiGenPro: A linked data workflow for
phenotype-genotype prediction of microbial traits using
machine learning.
publication.authors:
Mike Loomans, Maria Suarez-Diez, Peter J. Schaap, Edoardo Saccenti and
Jasper J. Koehorst

dataset.provenance: The BacDive database REST API was used to phenotype information in JSON format. The JSON results were transformed into a linked data structure, JSON-LD, using SAPP (v2.0).
dataset.splits:
The dataset was split into 80% for training and 20% for testing.
The datasets were randomly split using the scikit-learn train_test_split() function

Regarding Gram staining, out of 6,863 samples of which (4,470) were Gram-negative while 2,393 were Gram-positive.
Motility of 6,388 organisms was gathered, with non-motile (3,348) being  and motile (3,040).
The 12,616 oxygen-requirement entries are aerobes (6,022), followed by anaerobes (3,596), microaerophiles (1,854), facultative anaerobes (979), and obligate anaerobes (165).
In terms of spore formation, the 4,647 analyzed records indicate that non-spore formers (3,414) appear nearly three times as often as spore formers (1,233).

Temperature: The temperature dataset of 14,245 entries is overwhelmingly comprised of mesophilic organisms (12,786), with significantly fewer thermophilic (837) and psychrophilic (622) samples.

dataset.redundancy: The dataset was split into 80% for training and 20% for testing this setup was similar for the other studies we compared it to, to reduce the number of features used we applied a variance threshold of 1 to the training dataset.
dataset.availability: Publicly available under the CC0 license: https://zenodo.org/records/16995284

model.interpretability: The models used are easily interpretable by using the Gini coefficient as we have selected for such models beforehand.
model.duration: A single genome prediction required roughly 3 seconds of wall time on a t15 thinkpad laptop.
model.availability: The source code is public and released under an MIT license at https://gitlab.com/wurssb/migenpro and is available as Pypi package on https://libraries.io/pypi/MiGenPro

optimization.algorithm:
Decision tree classifiers, Random forest classifiers, Gradient boosting classifiers. 
We choose these classifiers for their easy understanding of the feature importance analysis with the Gini coefficent and because other studies have used similar model which we wanted to recreate.
optimization.meta: The models do not use data from other ML algorithms as described in our original data resource BacDive (doi.org/10.1093/nar/gkae959).
optimization.config: Hyperparameters are publicly available under the CC0 license in json format at:  https://gitlab.com/wurssb/migenpro/-/blob/607c0fa29efec66cf162095a9cfcd13a1e561fd2/tests/resources/param_grid.json
optimization.encoding: The data was first retrieved as a linked data resource this was querried usign SPARQL wherefrom phenotype matrices were generated. Features were obtained from analysing genomes that were found in the obtained phenotype matrix and annotated with a custom workflow that produced pfam protein domain annotations which were querried from these annotated genomes and used a features.
optimization.features:
Gram stain: 6938 features
Motility: 6938 features
Optimal temperature range: 6938 features
Spore formation: 6938 features
Oxygen requirement: 6938 features

Feature selection was performed on the data preceding the train test split.
optimization.fitting: The p was much larger than the number of training points in our dataset. The results from five- fold cross-validation show no significant deviations in feature importances across iterations, with importance remaining consistent throughout the process. This suggests that oversampling, and artificial inflation of model performance by overfitting data, is not occurring. A similar trend can be seen in regards to the observed standard deviation in model metrics over five iterations . The consistent results across test sets further support the robustness of the model and the reliability of the predictions made using the current datasets. The biological functions associated with the highest-ranking features support are biologically relevant. Therefore, the model demonstrates resilience against overfitting, ensuring that the predictions are generalisable to new, unseen data.
optimization.parameters:
Decision tree: Tree depth (1)
Random forest: Tree depth, number of trees, minimum amount of samples per leaf, minimum amount of samples per split (4)
Gradient boosting: Tree depth, number of estimators or stumps,  minimum amount of samples per split, learning rate (4)
After careful probing of parameters we saw that these parameters were most important in determining model performance.
optimization.regularization: Feature selection was performed using mutual information based percentile cutoff of 50%, the number of genomes per species was limited to 10 and phenotypes were only taken into account if more than 500 genomes were found after filtering for species abundance.

evaluation.method: The models were evaluated in five fold cross validation studies with randomised train-test splits of 80% train and 20% test.
evaluation.measure:
Accuracy, F1 score, Area under the receiver operating curve, Matthews correlation coefficient.
Accuracy was used as a metric for comparison to earlier studies despite the difficulties in interpretation that arise from using unbalanced datasets as we encountered.
evaluation.comparison: A comparison to publicly available methods was performed we however did use different datasets as the original datasets on which previous studies were performed were frequently unavailable.
evaluation.confidence: The performance metrics have confidence intervals and we do not claim our method to be superior to others as this was not our aim in this study it does perform similarly.
evaluation.availability: The analysis code is public and released under an MIT license at https://gitlab.com/wurssb/migenpro in the folder data_visualisation and our analysis can be recreated using Zenodo archive: https://doi.org/10.1101/2025.08.21.671437

publication.title: Comparison of Deep Learning Approaches for Extreme Low-SNR Image Restoration
publication.authors:
Nasreen Elizabeth Buhn, Sriya Reddy Adunur, Joseph Hamilton, Summer Levis, 
Guy M. Hagen, Jonathan D. Ventura

dataset.provenance: The source of the data is direct experiments. The dataset is composed of fluorescence microscopy TIFF images. The data are in sub-datasets: actin-60x, breast-cancer-array-60x, earthworm-20x-super-extreme, extreme-fish-gill-10x, fish-gill-10x-super-extreme, fish-gill-20x, human-ovary-active-phase-4x, human-ovary-active-phase-10x, immature-ovary-20x-super-extreme, mitochondria-60x, mouse-brain-10x, rabbit-testis-10x, spinning-disk-rat-testis-60x, spinning-disk-rat-testis-60x-medium-extreme and tubulin-60x. Each class has matching high and low signal-to-noise-ratio (SNR) image pairs. Actin-60x contains 23 image pairs, breast-cancer-array-60x contains 1 image pair, earthworm-20x-super-extreme contains 1 image pair, extreme-fish-gill-10x contains 12 image pairs, fish-gill-10x-super-extreme contains 11 image pairs, fish-gill-20x contains 1 image pair, human-ovary-active-phase-4x contains 11 image pairs, human-ovary-active-phase-10x contains 13 image pairs, immature-ovary-20x-super-extreme contains 1 image pair, mitochondria-60x contains 14 image pairs, mouse-brain-10x contains 8 image pairs, rabbit-testis-10x contains 9 image pairs, spinning-disk-rat-testis-60x contains 105 image pairs, spinning-disk-rat-testis-60x-medium-extreme contains 100 image pairs and tubulin-60x contains 14 image pairs. This dataset has not yet been published.
dataset.splits: The images were segmented into 512x512 crops. Each dataset was split into 90% training and 10% holdout split. Within the training portion, the last 5 image pairs, were used as a validation set. The distribution of datatypes between the training and test sets is the same. The distribution is not plotted.
dataset.redundancy: Each dataset was split into 90 percent training, within which the last 5 image pairs were used for validation, and 10 percent holdout testing. All crops were assigned to a single group: training, validation, or testing, and did not overlap. The train/test split was standard.
dataset.availability: The datasets have been uploaded to GigasScience's FTP server.

model.interpretability: Restormer: Black box  CARE: Black box Noise2Fast: Black box
model.output:
Restormer: Regression 
CARE: Regression 
Noise2Fast: Regression
model.duration:
Restormer: Using our Nvidia V100 32GB GPU testing a single 512x512 TIFF images took around .45 seconds.  
CARE: Using our Nvidia V100 32GB GPU testing a single 512x512 TIFF images took around 1 second.  
Noise2Fast: Using our Nvidia V100 32GB GPU a single 512x512 took between 9 and 40 seconds.
model.availability: Restormer: Yes. The source code is available on GitHub at https://github.com/swz30/Restormer (Academic Public License). Our specific implementation for our TIFF images is available at https://github.com/nazbuhn/Restormer/tree/92b532a1ab48ce7c7f495bcfaaf56ac1b61abd31 (MIT).   CARE: Yes, the model is available from https://github.com/CSBDeep/CSBDeep (BSD 2-Clause License). Our specific implementation of training and testing is available at https://github.com/nazbuhn/Comparison-of-Deep-Learning-Approaches-for-Extreme-Low-SNR-Image-Restoration/tree/main/CARE (MIT). Noise2Fast: Yes, the Noise2Fast implementation is available from https://github.com/jason-lequyer/Noise2Fast (Apache License). Our specific training and testing implementation is available from https://github.com/nazbuhn/Comparison-of-Deep-Learning-Approaches-for-Extreme-Low-SNR-Image-Restoration/tree/main/N2F (MIT).

optimization.algorithm:
Restormer: Transformer-based encoder–decoder architecture. The algorithm was published in 2021, and for real image denoising on the SIDD and DND datasets, it outperformed other denoising approaches, including BM3D, the CNN model MIRNet, and the Transformer model Uformer. 

CARE: CARE is a well-established supervised CNN with a U-net architecture. 

Noise2Fast: Noise2Fast is a self-supervised CNN that uses checkerboard downsampling for blind denoising. We chose Noise2Fast because it is self-supervised and does not require paired high and low SNR images for training. It also offers very fast training and inference while maintaining good denoising accuracy.
optimization.meta:
Restormer: No. Restormer is trained directly on image pairs.  

CARE:  No. 

Noise2Fast: No.
optimization.config: Restormer: Yes. Our specific training weights were uploaded to GigaDB.  CARE: Yes. Our specific training weights were uploaded to GigaDB. Noise2Fast: Yes, the Noise2Fast implementation is available from https://github.com/jason-lequyer/Noise2Fast (Apache License). Our specific training and testing implementation is available from https://github.com/nazbuhn/Comparison-of-Deep-Learning-Approaches-for-Extreme-Low-SNR-Image-Restoration/tree/main/N2F (MIT).
optimization.encoding: Restormer: Imageio is used to load TIFF images, which are converted into single channel 32-bit floating-point arrays. All images are 512 by 512 pixels. We use sample_patches_from_multiple_stacks from CSBDeep to extract corresponding patches from the noisy and clean stacks, then apply no_background_patches and norm_percentiles from CSBDeep. The noisy and clean pairs are cropped to target sizes for progressive training. During training, random geometric augmentation is applied. The data are converted to CHW format tensors. Validation and test data use the same loading, patch extraction, and normalization but do not use geometric augmentation.  CARE: The TIFF images were loaded using imageio into single-channel arrays. Non-background patches were then extracted using sample_patches_from_multiple_stacks together with the no_background_patches filter from CSBDeep. Percentile-based intensity normalization was applied with norm_percentiles. During training, the images were augmented by rotations and flips.  Noise2Fast: All TIFF images were read with imread and converted to NumPy arrays. For each image pixel, the minimum pixel value is subtracted, and the image is divided by the maximum value and cast to a 32-bit floating-point array. Checkerboard down sampling is applied to create four images that are converted to tensors.
optimization.features:
Restormer: Each input is a single channel image patch. The model is progressively trained (i.e. patch sizes of 128, 160, 192, 256, 320, 384). Patches range from 16,384-147,456 features. Validation and testing are performed on a full 512x512 crops. No feature selection is performed.   

CARE: Each input was a 512x512 image totaling 262,144 features. No feature selection was performed. 

Noise2Fast: The input to the model was 512x512 images. 262,144 features. No feature selection was performed.
optimization.fitting: Restormer: We used the standard RealDenoising architecture. Both p and f are large. The model trains on randomly cropped patches. We apply random geometric augmentation. We use AdamW with weight decay and L1 loss, and we keep a separate validation split that is never used for training.  CARE: Both p and f are large. We use the standard CARE framework, which trains on multiple sampled image patches and applies geometric augmentations and percentile-based normalization. Noise2Fast: The number of training points is larger than the number of p. Overfitting is mitigated by early stopping.
optimization.parameters:
Restormer: There are 26.11 M. We adopted the default RealDenoising Restormer configuration.  
CARE: 1M parameters were used in the model. We used the standard implementation of the CARE model. 
Noise2Fast: We used the standard Noise2Fast implementation. The model has about 260,000 parameters.
optimization.regularization: Restormer: Random cropping of patches, random geometric augmentation, and AdamW optimizer with weight decay are used to prevent overfitting. We kept a separate validation split.  CARE: We used the standard CARE framework. We trained on patches with geometric augmentation and percentile-based normalization.  Noise2Fast: Overfitting is mitigated by early stopping.

evaluation.method: The models were evaluated using peak signal-to-noise ratio (PSNR) and structural similarity index (SSIM).
evaluation.measure: PSNR and SSIM are reported. This is standard.
evaluation.comparison: Yes, these methods have been compared to other benchmark datasets publicly. We compared them to a novel fluorescence microscopy dataset.
evaluation.confidence: No.
evaluation.availability: For each model, average PSNR and SSIM across all datasets are reported in Table 2 of our paper “Comparison of Deep Learning Approaches for Extreme Low-SNR Image Restoration.” Low-SNR and high-SNR images, along with the trained model weights, have been uploaded to GigaScience’s FTP server. Files for running testing and evaluation are available at https://github.com/nazbuhn/Comparison-of-Deep-Learning-Approaches-for-Extreme-Low-SNR-Image-Restoration.

publication.title: APNet, an explainable sparse deep learning model to discover differentially active drivers of severe COVID-19
publication.authors: George I Gavriilidis , Vasileios Vasileiou , Stella Dimitsaki , Georgios Karakatsoulis , Antonis Giannakakis , Georgios A Pavlopoulos , Fotis Psomopoulos

dataset.provenance:
1st scenarios - Proteomics: Three Olink proteomics count matrices and their corresponding clinical metadata:
MGH 305 samples [225 no-severe COVID-19, 80 severe COVID-19] -- Training dataset
Mayo 449 samples [181 no-severe COVID-19, 268 severe COVID-19] -- Validation dataset
Stanford 64 samples [40 no-severe COVID-19, 24 severe COVID-19] -- Independed testing dataset

2nd scenarios - scRNAseq
MGH 298 samples [216 no-severe COVID-19, 76 severe COVID-19] -- Training dataset [exclude those samples that exist in scRNAseq dataset] -- Training dataset
scMGH 6665 samples (single-cell samples) [5144 no-severe COVID-19, 1521 severe COVID-19] -- Validation dataset
Blish 6500 samples (single-cell samples) [2609 no-severe COVID-19, 3891 severe COVID-19] -- Independed testing dataset
dataset.splits:
MGH -- Training
Mayo -- Validation
Stanford -- Testing
scMGH -- Validation
Blish -- Testing
dataset.redundancy: The training-validation-testing datasets were independed
dataset.availability:
The datasets used in this study can be accessed in the following links:
MGH Olink proteomics: https://info.olink.com/mgh-covid-study-overview-page?hsCtaTracking=fff99a2a-81c1-4e4a-a70d-6922d26503b4
Mayo Olink Proteomics: https://www.thelancet.com/journals/landig/article/PIIS2589-7500(22)00112-1/fulltext#supplementaryMaterial
Stanford Olink proteomics: https://datadryad.org/stash/dataset/doi:10.5061/dryad.9cnp5hqmn
Single-cell MGH Villani group and Blish: https://www.covid19cellatlas.org/index.patient.html

model.interpretability: Interpretable – in the article, the authors extensively explore the interpretation of the learned [model/representations/features]
model.duration:
Proteomics:
Estimated time for Griding ~1-2 days
Estimated time for Training ~ 3-4 hours

scRNAseq
Estimated time for Griding ~ 3-4 days
Estimated time for Training ~ 5-6 hours
model.availability: github link: https://github.com/BiodataAnalysisGroup/APNet

optimization.algorithm: PASNet (Pathway-Associated Sparse Network) that utilize biological priors from pathway databases, enhancing both predictive performance and pathway-level interpretability
optimization.meta: The algorithm used the activity matrices that extracted from the NetBID2 (part of the workflow), alongside with a table indicating whether the drivers participated in such of pathways from pathway enrichment with top 30 pathways from Gene Ontology (GO), Reactome, KEGG, and Wikipathway.
optimization.config: The model configuration is available at the repository: https://github.com/BiodataAnalysisGroup/APNet
optimization.encoding: PASNet is applied to activity data, where each feature represents the activity level of a gene and is typically encoded as a continuous numerical value. To incorporate biological knowledge, genes are mapped to relevant pathways using established databases. This pathway information is then used in PASNet to impose sparse connections in the network, allowing the model to capture pathway-specific patterns in the data.
optimization.features:
1st model - Proteomics:
To reduce noise and focus on the most relevant features, we retained the common statistically significant drivers present in both three proteomic datasets, as these shared drivers are expected to participate in the pathways identified in the enrichment analysis. In total, 250 features were used for model training.

2nd model - scRNAseq:
To reduce noise and focus on the most relevant features, we retained the common statistically significant drivers present in both three datasets [MGH proteomics, scMGH - Blish scRNAseq], as these shared drivers are expected to participate in the pathways identified in the enrichment analysis. In total, 223 features were used for model training.
optimization.parameters:
Learning Rate (LR) and L2 regularization (L2), through griding search

1st model - Proteomics
Optimal learning rate (LR = 0.05) and L2 regularization (L2 = 0.0003)

2nd model - scRNAseq
Optimal learning rate (LR = 0.007) and L2 regularization (L2 = 0.0003)

evaluation.method: Cross-validation and an independent dataset
evaluation.measure:
AUC and F1 score

1st model - Proteomics:
AUC = 0.96, F1score =  0.89

2nd model - scRNAseq:
AUC = 0.99, F1score = 0.975

publication.title: A Pre-Registered, Open Pipeline for Early Cerebral Palsy Risk Assessment from Infant Videos
publication.authors: Melanie Segado, Laura A. Prosser, Andrea F. Duncan, Michelle J. Johnson, Konrad P. Kording

dataset.provenance:
Data were collected as part of standard clinical care by team members of the CHOP site of the US CP Early Detection and Intervention Network in a REDcap database between May 2019 and December 2023. This included the secure uploading of iPad- or iPhone-recorded videos, General Movement Assessments (GMA) scores and demographic information.  Exclusions were applied to intubated patients, those under the influence of sedation medications, within a week post-operative, on ECMO support, or diagnosed with myelomeningocele. For all infants who were between 10-20 weeks post-term age (corrected for preterm birth, if applicable) at the time of a clinic visit, and whose parents or legal guardians agreed to video recording for clinical care, clinicians captured a 1-2 minute video of the infant lying in supine.  

Data classes were defined according to the GMA scores: 
1 - Fidgety (Nneg = 826) 
2 - Absent Fidgety (Npos = 99) 
3 - Atypical Fidgety (excluded = 6) 

The full dataset comprised 1053 infants. 122 were then excluded for meeting one or more exclusion criteria listed above. Six infants with a GMA score of 3 (“atypical fidgety”) were also excluded, since there were not enough infants in this group for model training/testing, and movement patterns differ from those of “absent fidgety” infants.
dataset.splits: The full dataset comprised 1053 infants. 122 were then excluded for meeting one or more exclusion criteria listed above. Six infants with a GMA score of 3 (“atypical fidgety”) were also excluded, since there were not enough infants in this group for model training/testing, and movement patterns differ from those of “absent fidgety” infants. The remaining 931 videos were split into an analysis set (739) and a lock box holdout set (186) (Figure 1, Figure 2). The analysis set was further split into train/val/test sets (648, 93, 186), each of which had a 10-12% representation of the “absent fidgety” movement type. The splits were stratified to preserve the ratios of boy/girl infants, as well as age, and race/ethnicity. There was a total recording duration of 60-120 s per infant.
dataset.redundancy: The true holdout set (n = 186) was randomly sampled from the dataset, stratified by GMA score, prior to any algorithm development, and pre-registered on OSF.
dataset.availability: Pre-processed data has been made available on the OSF pre-registration site: https://osf.io/gztmd/

model.interpretability: The model is interpretable as it is possible to inspect the weights assigned to each of the 38 movement features included in the model. Additional, permutation testing was carried out to allow for intuitive visualization of feature importance.
model.output: The model is a binary classifier.
model.duration: prediction requires approximately 30 seconds on a standard machine.
model.availability: Yes, the source code is available on GitHub (https://github.com/KordingLab/predict-scores-from-video) under an MIT License. A container has not yet been released.

optimization.algorithm: AutoSklearn-2.0 employs a meta-learning approach to automate the selection and tuning of well-established machine learning algorithms like decision trees, random forests, and support vector machines. The final model selected was Stochastic Gradient Descent.
optimization.meta: The model does not use data from other ML algorithms as input. The inputs to the classifier are the features derived from the pose-estimate time-series data, which rely on ViTPose-H.
optimization.config: All hyper parameters are available in the stored model details, which are available on the pre-registration site:
optimization.encoding: All data used for training was numerical, and pre-processed to remove missing values. All other parameters of the data pre-processing and encoding were determined by AutoSklearn
optimization.features: 38 features were used as input. No feature selection was performed - features were determined by medical specialists and pre-registered in advance of any data collection or analysis.
optimization.fitting: The number of training datapoints (> 600) is much larger than the number of features (38). Additionally, AutoML mitigates the risk of overfitting by abstracting away any feature and model parameter selection. Moreover, the trained model was evaluated on a lock-box holdout set of data after pre-registration to determine generalizability.
optimization.parameters: p was selected by the AutoML optimizer based on the classification algorithm selected. The search space was restricted to choosing the best model as opposed to an ensemble, in this case SGD, so p corresponds to the weights given to each of the 38 features.
optimization.regularization: AutoML was the primary approach used to prevent the risk of overfitting.

evaluation.method: Two evaluation strategies were used. First, 10 times 5-folds cross validation were performed on the train/test data to ensure that model performance was not reliant on any one specific data split. Finally, the model was evaluated on a lock-box, pre-registered held out test set of participant data to show generalizability.
evaluation.measure: Two standard measures are report: AUC-ROC which is a standard measure used in the machine learning community, and Preicision-Recall (PR)-AUC, which is more interpretable within the medical literature as it relates to the sensitivity/specificity measures that are widely used.
evaluation.comparison: AutoML already tests simple baselines to ensure they do not out-perform the selected model. Additionally, the model was tested against another available model for predicting risk from infant video (STAM).
evaluation.confidence: Performance metrics are reported with associated cross-validation scores. The goal of the paper was not the claim that the result is superior to that of others, but rather to show that the result persists even when applying strict rigorous ML approaches.
evaluation.availability: All model outputs and CV scores are available.

publication.title: ViralBindPredict: Empowering Viral Protein-Ligand Binding Sites through Deep Learning and Protein Sequence-Derived Insights
publication.authors: A. M. B. Amorim, C. Marques-Pereira, T. Almeida, N. Rosário-Ferreira, H. S. Pinto, C. Vaz, A. Francisco, and I.S. Moreira

dataset.provenance:
The dataset was obtained from the Protein Data Bank (PDB), specifically from viral protein-ligand complexes. 
The ViralBindPredict full dataset contains 3,790,919 residue samples, with 173,320 positive (interacting) and 3,617,599 negative (non-interacting) samples. The ViralBindPredict NoRed dataset contains 21,259 positive (interacting) and 534,683 negative (non-interacting) samples.
The   dataset   is   newly   curated   and   specifically   designed   for ViralBindPredict.
dataset.splits:
The dataset was split into training, validation, testing, blind protein (new proteins), blind ligand (new ligands), and blind (new proteins and ligands) sets. Additionally, several splitting strategies were evaluated, including Cluster90%, Cluster40%, NoRed90% → Cluster90%, and NoRed90% → Cluster40%, to assess the effect of sequence redundancy reduction and clustering thresholds on model generalization.
The dataset is highly imbalanced, with approximately 1 positive (interacting) residue   for   every   21   negatives   (non-interacting).  This   imbalance  was considered in model training.
The distributions and percentages of positive samples are provided in the Supplementary Information.
dataset.redundancy: Independently, all splits were constructed to ensure strict separation between training and evaluation sets. The dataset partitions were designed to prevent any overlap of protein chains, PDB identifiers, sequence clusters, molecular scaffolds, or protein–ligand interactions. Redundancy thresholds (e.g., 90% sequence identity) were applied to reduce dataset bias, and multiple splitting strategies, such as clustering at 90% and 40% sequence identity, were implemented to minimize overlap and redundancy between training and evaluation data. Overall, the dataset reflects the typical characteristics and class imbalance observed in biological datasets.
dataset.availability: The full dataset, including all data splits (testing, blind protein, blind ligand, and blind) for each splitting strategy (BASE; Cluster90%; Cluster40%; NoRed90%→Cluster90%; NoRed90%→Cluster40%), is publicly available at: http://doi.org/10.5524/102798(GigaDB dataset) and https://www.dropbox.com/scl/fo/nq47acmr2ty62iflu9rwn/AJhe9a9gqoKblgHkYDMf_Gk?rlkey=dcivaufhohazumpetifq9chkj&st=zffjuonx&dl=0

model.interpretability: Interpretable, we performed feature permutation importance.
model.duration:
The training time depends on the specific model, the machine used, and the availability of computational resources at the time. 
A new prediction will take a few seconds on a desktop PC or a high-performance computing cluster.
model.availability: The code is available on GitHub, allowing users to run it in their preferred environment. GitHub:  https://github.com/MoreiraLAB/VirHostAI/ (GPL-3.0 license). Users can utilize the repository to generate new predictions using our method.

optimization.algorithm:
A Multilayer Perceptron (MLP) model. It is optimized for viral ligand-binding site (LBS) prediction.
In addition, a LightGBM model was implemented for comparative analysis.
optimization.config: Yes. Manuscript (Methods and Supplementary Information) and Github: https://github.com/MoreiraLAB/VirHostAI/ (GPL-3.0 license)
optimization.encoding: Features were extracted using Mordred for ligand descriptors and ESM-2 or ProtTrans for per-residue protein sequence embeddings. All features were standardized by fitting the scaler on the training set and applying the same transformation to the validation, testing, and blind sets.
optimization.features:
For the full dataset, depending on the configuration (Mordred + ProtTrans or Mordred + ESM-2), 1,280 features were derived from ESM-2 embeddings and 1,024 from ProtTrans. From the initial 1,613 Mordred ligand descriptors, 1,079 informative features were retained after filtering, while all protein embedding dimensions were preserved. Consequently, the combined Mordred + ESM-2 and Mordred + ProtTrans datasets comprised 2,359 and 2,103 features, respectively.
A reduced dataset (ViralBindPredict NoRed) was later generated by applying a 90% sequence similarity threshold, in which 1,073 of the original 1,613 Mordred features were retained, maintaining the same dimensionality for protein embeddings. To ensure feature quality, all NaN, infinite, and zero-variance features were removed from the datasets.
optimization.fitting: No, the number of parameters (p) is much smaller than the number of training points.
optimization.parameters: The tested parameters are provided in the Supplementary Information, along with the selected hyperparameters. The selection of optimal parameters was performed using the Optuna package, which applied Bayesian optimization over 200 trials for each model configuration and feature set (MLP and LightGBM).
optimization.regularization: Early stopping based on the validation set and regularization techniques were applied to prevent overfitting during model training.

evaluation.method: Several dataset splitting strategies were applied to minimize redundancy and overlap between subsets. These included the creation of multiple evaluation sets: a testing set (representing mild generalization), a blind protein set (containing new proteins), a blind ligand set (containing new ligands), and a blind set (comprising both new proteins and new ligands). In addition, scaffold- and sequence cluster–based splitting strategies were implemented to prevent overlap and ensure true generalization across proteins and ligands.
evaluation.measure: MCC, AUC-PR, F1-Score, Precision, and Recall are reported as performance metrics, and the set is representative.
evaluation.comparison:
NA. No benchmark datasets for viral protein–ligand interaction.
Instead, we compared our Multilayer Perceptron (MLP) models with a LightGBM machine learning baselines using the same input features and dataset splits.
evaluation.confidence: No confidence intervals. No available benchmarks specialized in viral protein-ligand interactions.
evaluation.availability: The evaluation results are reported in the main manuscript, with additional details provided in the Supplementary Information. GitHub repository: https://github.com/MoreiraLAB/VirHostAI/.
